description:
This would be a 4+ if I could rate that "plus"! We are staying in the area for two weeks. We chose  the location because of the many restaurants and coffee shops. Its out home base for travels in and out of the city but most mornings and events we are "locals".

As we do often when we travel this way we look for favorites, The combo of food, price and service and ambiance. Yes, we do try new places too, but its good to have a go to spot.

Crepes on Cole  is that. We have had lunch and dinner there. Each time the service is with a smile. The location is fun as you watch the comings and goings of folks on the Muni. And, the food is good.

What stands out is the quality of the soups. I mean  really good! The salads, the meals, the eggs. al good - but now we go lookign to have soup! Loved the white bean and chicken soup the best.

They had a limited but good wine choice and soem great beer options.

I told my son the dessert crepe reminded me on a special meal my mother would make us as kids, this place made me feel good. not fancy and no hostess per se Go to the counter, make friends and enjoy.

A special shout out to the counter guy who remembered I liked the Madeleine cookies.
author: Larry S.

description:
We were actually trying to eat at another place, but upon arrival the line was too long so we decided to come here. 
-American style brunch kind of food. Ordered bruschetta with with fries and salad  on the side. The bruschetta was alright, I wasn't entirely fond that it was on a piece of sandwich bread. I would of liked it on individual cut baguette bread. *note this is just how I don't personally enjoy it. The taste was fine. My fries was a little cold though which was a downer. The salad was quite enjoyable with the vinaigrette it was dressed with. 
- they have one restroom and plenty of room to dine in.
author: Sally L.

description:
A solid 3.5 restaurant. The restaurant style is order at the front, take a number and seat yourself. This means if you need anything after you sit down, there is no table service so you have to return to the front to ask for anything. We had to do that a few times because there was no dressing on the salads, and we only had 3/4 silverware at the table. Not a huge deal but it was a little annoying to keep getting up after we had started eating.

The menu is huge so it can be a little difficult to order because it's so overwhelming - which is not necessarily a bad thing!! I went in a group of 4 and we all ordered lunch combos, giving us a soup and sandwich or a salad and sandwich each. All of the food was fine and filling, but nothing to write home about. However, we did not order any crepes so I do want to return to try them. It is in their restaurant name, so they must be good!

The staff were all very nice and the restaurant itself was clean - including the bathrooms.
author: Bri T.

description:
Meh.
We'd originally planned to stop by another eatery but they had a rather long line.  Upon walking in weren't greeted or acknowledged, which left us wondering what to do.  We just sat down at a table because, I guess that's how it works? We picked up a paper menu and picked out what we thought sounded good.  They have a lot more savory crepes than sweet, I assumed that was because they're open pretty late but I opted for the banana-Nutella classic along with their blueberry pancakes, chai and fresh squeezed OJ. The pancakes and crepes don't come with sides so I ordered a side of egg (1) & a side of bacon (3). This all came up to $42.  Which I think is pushing it for 1 crepe & 2 pancakes and boxed chai. 

The pancakes were good but the blueberries were a little hard, possibly due to being previously frozen. 

All in all , just an "okay" experience.
author: Sydney S.

description: Been coming here since I was a kid. Great cafe any meal. They have done a great job of adding more things to the menu and more beer on tap. Sports usually play here, it's just one of my favorite cute solid neighborhood cafes.
author: Cristiano L.

description:
We came to this restaurant for brunch because the other location we went to the waiting line was too long. I ordered the regulars on the menu, veggie omelet and coffee. They were good nothing super special but the service was fast, the portion was big. Because of large crowd, we had to share table with strangers. Not much privacy there. 

It was a good enough experience and we left with full tummy.
author: Ping K.

description: I love this spot and come back again and again. Great food for reasonable prices. Very good glutenfree options. Nice atmosphere and perfect to sit outside. You can also bring your laptop and work here.
author: Käthe R.

description:
Originally wanted to try another brunch place but I'm so glad that I ended up stumbling upon this place.  Simply just order at the counter and sit down.  My order came out super fast and the customer service was excellent!  I really enjoyed this place.  

Ordered: french toast, coffee, applewood bacon, the paris (omelette)
author: Mikayla M.

description:
The eggs Benedict was 10$ online, so i call im and order.  The price wasn't confirmed over the phone nor my name taken.  I get there,  it's 18$. They messed up,  but still wanted me to pay for it.  I live across the street, the kind of customer that's financially worth it to cut the extra 8$. They didn't.  Never eating here again,  advising everyone i know not to eat here.  

The food,  it was ok.  Not bad.  Not worth $18
author: April F.

description:
The food was fantastic. I had the mozzarella tomato basil meal, and it was super fresh and delicious.

My friend had the salsa crepe and loved it!
author: Jas B.

description: We went over to another brunch spot but line was too long. We wandered over here which reminded me of Crepevine. I ordered the special French toast with marscapone and lemon curd which was so good with hints of orange. No syrup needed because the berries and lemon mixed perfectly. Hubby had eggs Benedict which was a perfect portion. We had lattes as well and only down fall was not sweet enough but that's just me.
author: Nicole A.

description: I asked for something unique and she pointed me to raspberry blintz which is raspberry flavored ricotta with sour cream and apple sauce. It was OK. Nice vibe overall...friendly staff ...cute little old school spot...wood everywhere...plus points for playing Sinatra.
author: Sunil R.

description: I ordered the bruschetta sandwich and everything was bland, almost inedible. Possibly the worst fries I've ever had - deep fried several times over with no seasoning.  Mixed greens were drenched in dressing. Soggy sourdough toast with disproportionate amounts of basil, tomatoes, and cheese. Overpriced, poorly made food. There's a reason this place was empty on a Saturday, and unfortunately I learned my lesson the hard way.
author: Irina G.

description:
This is the crepe place in Cole valley.  I feel like every neighborhood in San Francisco has their own crepe place which are usually super loud and crowded.  Crepes on Cole is very spacious,  and I like that they play very calming music as opposed to blasting salsa music like the place whose name I will not mention in the inner sunset. 

They have a ton of options (see the chalkboard photos I provided) and pretty much anything can be customized to have your way. The people who work here are EXTREMELY nice and willing to make you whatever you want,  even if it'll make you hella fat lol. 

It's a walk up counter where you order and you have to spend over $8 to use a credit card.  My favorite items are the Florentine and the Chicken pesto crepes.  They also jabbed a mean pancake.  Do try the Mexican hot chocolate,  but make sure you run after. 

Overall, a solid place to have breakfast and answer emails.
author: Arman J.

description: Terrible terrible service. We went there just because Zazie had too many people and we were in a rush. We waited here for the order for around 50min. When we went to ask for our order and said we ordered it an order ago, the guy began to blame us that it's not an hour, it's 50min (what the hell?? How can a customer remember the exact time of the order) the food is overpriced and mediocre at the best. Please avoid this restaurant at all cost.
author: Natalie X.

description: We ordered in crepes from this spot and they were amazing! Very fluffy, the perfect amount of Nutella (my favorite) and they packaged a decent amount of whip cream in a small container. The delivery was timely, however a little pricey at $10 something per crepe. Ended up being 24$ with delivery and all! Still really good for that late night craving!
author: Zara S.

description:
8/20/18: My first warning was when I asked for the founders breakfast stout they have on tap and the girl taking my order literally turned around and asked the other girl "do you know how to pour beer?" I should have left then. Instead my mistake was that I looked at their menu and thought that pastrami sandwich sounded good, however when it was delivered to me I took two bites and realized how chewy and over salted this sandwich truly was, at which point I summoned the waitress/server to come over to my table as I was trying to be discreet about why I could not and would not eat this sandwich... despite the two little young ladies working they seem to have no knowledge of Business ethics or food service in general; wow asking for a refund as I had not eaten this "sandwich" explained why I was returning it and was met with indifference and attitude the girl with the rush T-shirt on told me she would not refund me my money for the sandwich and she was going to call her boss the "manager" she did not get a hold of said manager so I politely told her that if I wasn't getting a refund I would contact the Park station police for them to come and resolve this issue finally she did refund me the money but since I had already drank more than half of my beer I wondered head she refunded me for the beer as well? I asked her had she refunded me for the beer she replied yes and because I was trying to be fair I gave her back the money for Said beer only then to realize that she hadn't and I had just given her back money that belongs to me so thanks again for a $10 plus disgusting sandwich that was in edible and I suggest you go elsewhere for decent food in the neighborhood, I knew I should've stuck with burger meister as they have never let me down in this way don't take my word for it, but if you hear somebody say do you know how to pour a beer that should be a huge red flag for you! I will never go back to this establishment ever again it's too bad because I really liked that founders breakfast stout but this establishment obviously does not care about their service And/or quality of their "food" 
you owe me $10
author: Brian C.

description:
We were really craving crepes while in the area and we stumbled upon this place. I tend to only order the desert crepes. Upon first glance at the giant menu boards they have, it looked like they had a great selection of both sweet and savory; a little overwhelming. 

After debating between the strawberry or raspberry, we opted for the latter since the description was unique. It has ricotta cheese and raspberry jam topped with apple sauce and sour cream on the side. Very unique and sounded good. What came out was good and interesting but it wasn't expected and I kind of wish we went with something more traditional. It was wrapped like a burrito so tons of filling (see pic). The ricotta was an interesting choice which made it light/ not too sweet but it was too much stuff inside for the crepe outer skin. 

Plenty of seating inside and a few tables outside. Service was pretty fast
author: Melissa L.

description: The world shall know that this unfairly rated place has the best pancakes I've eaten in this country. Blueberry pancakes, add banana on top. Also, no freaking lines and not bad service. The owner is very friendly.
author: Sedrak K.

description: Dishes are overpriced. Crepes were rubbery and the jam was thin and soupy. Berries tasted like they were from a can. Half the plate was ready whip.
author: Sam W.

description:
Nothing really worth writing home about here but it's all do-able.

There are better options available in the area yet if you are here it will do. Note: any changes/add on's from the $11.45 Basic Crepe of cheese and onion can add up very quickly. Portions are good, potatoes not burned and salad came with the basic. Service is decent, order at the counter and it will be brought to your table.

Beginning with their basic model at $11.45, I added $0.80 tomato, $0.80 avocado, $2.45 chicken and $0.80 marina sauce on top bringing the total price to a whopping $16.30. Add in the $4.75 medium OJ and this crepe and a drink cost $21.05 just for me with out the tip.
author: Caesar A.

description:
The portions are HUGE. So I strongly suggest you split something.

I got the benedict's crepe which was too rich and too cheesy in my opinion. It had swiss or mozarella cheese (generous amount) plus avocado plus a perfectly cooked egg's benedict on top. It was just too much and I ended up leaving about half of my food on my plate.

The french toast is a solid order (what my boyfriend got). They plate it with plenty of fruit - bananas, blackberries, blueberries & strawberries - again very generous with their portion sizes.

Lots of space and seating with sunshine coming in so all in all an okay place.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Ended up at Crepes on Cole after seeing the crazy line at Zazie (you'd think at 2:30pm the line would die down but nope). After going back and forth for awhile on what to get, I landed on the raspberry blitzes. There's just too many good options.

Delicious! I wasn't exactly sure what to expect but this was better. I had pictured the blintz having raspberry jam on top but instead it was on the inside (and not jam), mixed with ricotta cheese! Bonus points for coming with apple sauce and sour cream! I wish the blintz had been a bit warmer (it was luke warm and not hot) - I also could have easily asked for them to warm it up but was too lazy and hungry so I just ate it. I also wish it had come with sides, since both my friends had ordered the Cole Street Crepe, which came with potatoes and mixed greens (I tried their crepe and it was very tasty too). 

Overall, good spot!
author: Ilana B.

description:
Loved how large the menu was and the variety of savory and sweet crepes, blintzes, omelettes, fresh juices and pastries. I was really torn on sweet vs. savory because it's hard for me to turn down Nutella, but ended up getting the Cole Valley and it was great!

The crepe was stuffed with cheese, sun dried tomatoes, mushrooms and pesto and came with a side salad and perfect breakfast potatoes. It needed some salt and hot sauce and I think it would have benefited from a little more seasoning during the prep/cooking process. But overall a solid brunch option that I'll definitely come back for!
author: Sophie S.

description:
Went in with my husband and daughter. She had eggs Benedict's. The first one was ok, the second one was really bad. Soggy bread, the white was runny and it had a weird taste.  Only had one bite.  Said it tasted like chemicals. 
We had savory crepes, they were both ok. Served with salad and potatoes. You could share as it's quite a lot of food. 
The restaurant is nice and well lit with natural lights, large windows. However, it smells bad, like one of those old homes with shaggy, thick old carpet. 
It's also really expensive for crepes. 
We will not return.
author: Anne V.

description:
#121/2016

You'll do a double take thinking you walked into Crepevine: The menu's designed in the same font and style, features similar menu items (though not as extensive), decor's in glossy oak and the vibe's casual.

It's a good thing.

Located on Cole and Carl in the heart of Cole Valley, this spacious casual dining spot features crepes (both savory and sweet), sandwiches, salads and omelettes. There's beer on tap too (the usual suspects including local Anchor Steam).

With eight 2-tops for sidewalk dining (woof!) and conveniently located near a stop on the busy N-Judah line, it's no surprise Crepes on Cole attracts commuter business for dine-in or take-out as well as visitors and residents strolling the pretty tree-lined streets for errands or family fun.

Service was served up with weary ennui; I excused it given the hot weather and street fair that kept them busier than they might've otherwise been on a Sunday.

I had the Bonjour crepe with goat cheese, chicken Apple sausage and veggies with a simple green salad. My little boy had the strawberry and chocolate crepe with lots of fresh strawberries and Nutella, whipped cream on the side. 

We enjoyed our lunch/early dinner meal- and it let me off the hook to make supper in 90-degree heat.

I'd definitely stop by again when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
This review is for their Mexican Hot Chocolate only.  

At first taste, it was very mild.  Kind of like milk with a hint of chocolate and cinnamon.  It wasn't awful, but it definitely wasn't what I had in mind when ordering it.

When I took the lid off, I realized why it was so mild.  The entire cup was plain white milk with giant globs of brown powder (guessing this was cinnamon plus cocoa).  At the bottom, the globs of powder had turned into fat, slimy slugs.  

I don't know how you mess up hot chocolate, but this place did, royally.
author: Sheila C.

description: The atmosphere here is really nice, Sam has the seasons festive holiday decors. The food here is really yummy and big portions. Feels homey and I will come back again!
author: Mei L.

description: My favorite place to eat. Unfortunately today cooks had some fun laughing and as a result they made orders for my kids but forgot to make my order! Only when we had to remind them they made it. That's pretty bad.
author: A C.

description: The food is good and portions are large, but the  customer service was a little slow and the girl working seemed inattentive. They no longer have a large menu posted and instead have blue paper menus. Once my order was finally placed, however, the food came fairly quickly.
author: Ariel W.

description: Had the crepe Benedict and it was excellent! The coffee was also delicious, and the servers were really nice.
author: Courtney W.

description: Crepes on Cole is a solid place to eat. It's not the most memorable food or atmosphere or service, but it's like an old boy/girlfriend with whom you broke up because they were just "okay". But every once in a while you hook up with them and it feels nice and then you remember why it never worked out. I mean, there's nothing wrong with them, and they're totally nice and your friends are like "what's wrong with so-and-so" and you're like "they just weren't right". THAT'S what Crepes on Cole is like. Oh, also, their turnover rate is insane. They have like an almost entirely new staff every other week, so if Soylent Green winds up on the menu, you've been warned.
author: Richard C.

description:
You're run of the mill SF go-to diner with a menu so vast and homey that everyone can find something appeasing. Come in, order from the counter, and find a seat. The turnover of patrons is quick, so you will not have to wait long. And with spotty service, feel free to bus your own table or another table to make the dining experience better.

Try the Crepe Benedict with salad - a fun twist on a classic.
author: Regina D.

description: Very good crepes, potatoes and a super Swedish pancake.   Nice place, after we aborted the last no line at Zazie.  Not disappointed
author: Candace C.

description: Love this place! Great atmosphere with fantastic food.
author: Gaetano B.

description: I've been coming here for years. Like the combo of crepe and potatoes and salad. But man oh man they are so pricey now. $7 for 1 pancake on the kids menu. $8 for a bowl of fruit. $15 burgers. $15 for the crepe.  Cole valley is getting too full of its self.
author: La H.

description: We drove 25 minutes plus 15 minutes to park to get to Crepes on Cole. When we arrived there the place was dead, there were dozens of flies, flies!!!! Flying everywhere. It smelled damp and musty. The waitress was wearing a crop top with her belling hanging out and the hostess had hairier armpits than any man I have seen in a while. If you want to have hairy armpits that's your business, however please do not wear sleeveless shirts in a restaurant setting if you are going for that look. The cook was staring at us as we approached the counter and was standing against the wall with one foot on the wall. The flies, the air and the musty smell were enough to keep us away. Luckily we found an incredible place to eat right across the street: Padrecitos. Good luck!
author: Jo G.

description: Checked out this place for Sunday Brunch. Excellent food, great atmosphere and awesome service.
author: Surdeep D.

description:
Salad did not have flavor,  it felt like bunch of leaves tossed with dressing.  Potatoes did not have any seasoning.  Crepes had too much cheese in.  Carrot juice was freshly squeezed in front of us and was very tasty. The staff was very cordial, accommodating and the owner also helped out so overall felt good place.

If I go again I may try dessert crepe or traditional American breakfast over savory crepes.
author: Vishal J.

description:
Stopped in for early breakfast. Got here just when they opened and I was in a mood for basic crepe. The menu had basic crepe but that's not what I had in mind. The "basic" crepe I had in mind was under dessert crepes. :-)

Tried the banana crepe and the presentation is unremarkable. Lots of whipped cream and crepe with banana was folded into quarters. I would have enjoyed it rolled up and a small portion of whipped cream on top. 

Taste decent.  Remember to ask for syrup, it did not come with the crepe. Oh, the coffee is great!!!
author: Khiang S.

description:
Had a nice tuna melt for lunch with potatoes and salad. 

Pretty standard and consistent food. 

Love the Eggplant Caponata sammie on a hard roll. So good and vegetarian, if you feel like that. 

Great view of the muni stop. You can people watch while sipping coffee or tea.  

Avoid the weekends at all costs, unless you like crowds and lines. 

Open early, closes late. Always a little sticky. Sigh. 

Why no wifi? WHY?! Come on people it's time, you've held on long enough.
author: B K.

description: The food is fine and its a great location. And the girls that work there are super friendly and great. but for some reason they keep jacking up the prices. Seems like every year they hike up the prices. $15 for a breakfast burrito? Talk about SF pricing to the max for a diner burrito. You can literally get a great breakfast burrito across the street at Reverie Cafe now for half the cost. And Reverie takes credit cards now, so not much reason to pay the exorbitant costs here.
author: Edward Y.

description:
If you like the cookie cutter template of Crepevine...Squat & Gobble, you'll like this place. you'll get big portions...and very little flavor. 
  I had the Florentine crepe, large wads of flavorless cheddar cheese...equally bland spinach and cottage cheese inside an overcooked,almost bready crepe. It's totally edible and filling...but  completely forgettable.
author: Fred D.

description:
Remember when crepe restaurants were new and edgy and chains like the Magic Pan dished up a dose of theatricality along with their food?  This is not that type of restaurant.  

This feels more like a breakfast joint, heavy on omelettes and egg dishes with salads and sandwiches thrown in for lunch and dinner.  I'm not really sure what crepes add to the menu.  My food was good - I had the Chicken Pesto crepe, served with a huge pile of mixed greens and house potatoes - but the whole time I was chowing down it felt like I was eating an omelette.  I didn't like the presentation, either - a crepe with fillings piled on top, folded in half and then folded in half again.  It felt and looked like a wrap by the time all that was done.  I envision crepes being light and not as bulky as this one was.  I remember the Magic Pan had a creamed chicken and mushroom crepe, spinach soufflé crepe and a crab meat crepe among others, nothing bulky like this crepe.  Crepes on Cole did cover all their bases with a wide selection of dessert crepes, though.

Service is casual.  You order from a counter and your food is brought to you.  Overall, it's an okay place but not really what I envisioned.
author: Will T.

description:
I used to live in this neighborhood and ate there a lot. It is now a bit spruced up and the menu appears to be branching out. However!! the whole restaurant smells like urine. Possibly because they work there the employees cannot smell it, but it's a simple fix. Use a different mop for the kitchen and dining area than you use in the bathrooms! Being too cheap for this solution has permanently lost you this customer, and as many of her friends as she can tell about this smell. 
It's a pity. 
As a final remark, my eggs were great, but the potatoes were dried out and tasted like last week...
author: Cherry S.

description:
Like many people, we stopped in for brunch at Crepes on Cole because the line for Zazie (1/2 block away) was insane.  I'm not usually a fan of savory crepes (count me in for sweet crepes!), but I was getting hunger pains so I opted for the Cole Valley ($11.95).  It has provolone cheese, avocado, mushrooms, pesto, and spinach (and no, I'm not a vegetarian).  It also came with seasoned potatoes and a side salad.  Let me just say that the crepe hit the spot, and I would definitely come back for it again.  My friends ordered the blueberry pancakes and the banana & coconut pancakes.  While both were good, they weren't very memorable.

We found easy parking at a meter right in front.  By the time we left the restaurant around Sunday at noon, almost every seat was taken and there were lots of regulars.
author: Kristen H.

description:
I just wanted something light so got the homemade granola with nonfat yogurt. A slight ripoff, but I really enjoyed it. It comes in a decent sized bowl, but I wish they had more yogurt on it. Great mix of fruits too.

Their menu is so cluttered that it gave me a headache though. I'd recommend simplify it so that customers aren't standing in decision paralysis.
author: Juliana P.

description: Bought gifts cards there for staff.  Great location and friendly staff.
author: Jessica S.

description:
This was definitely a "meh" experience.

First, I don't understand why all the crepe places seem to use the same menu signage as Crepevine. Is that due to some group discount they got? Or were they all franchised and then spun themselves off? Or is it supposed to transplant you to Paris? Anyway ... that was just a little rant unrelated to the review to get you ready for the crappy review below.

Bottom line, the food wasn't anything I would want to eat again. I'll admit, I got the Salsa Crepe, which probably isn't the best option. It's just that the people I went with seemed so content with going to the restaurant again that I thought it would be good. Anyway, the crepe was kind of mealy, there were bits of rotten avocado (or at least it had gone black and they hadn't bothered to cut those bits out), and a general lack of seasoning. A friend got a salad and she said it lacked any flavor. Several people got add-ons (like tofu or chicken) and they came separate from the dishes and we had to remind them. The clincher was that they got balsamic for one of the salads but forgot oil ... and then kept asking if we'd like oil, but kept forgetting to bring it. Sorry, but that's just silly service.

There are so many place (including Padrecito, which is always tasty) nearby that I can be 100% sure I'll never return here.
author: Akash K.

description: The staff is fun, the ambiance is inviting and the food was Damn good. The parking situation on the other hand (not that they can help it) is horrendous.
author: Andre D.

description: My wife and I love looking for restaurants that specialize in crepes. Crepes on Cole exceeded our expectations! Great menu including "Create Your Own Crepe"! Nice selection of Dessert Crepes too. We ordered breakfast which was exceptional! Great food, good service, clean and charming. Try it!
author: Adam C.

description:
Like squat and gobble except the service is a lot slower. Food came out cold. 

We went here because zazzie had to long of a wait. Now I know why this was so empty
author: M T.

description: I absolutely love this place, the service was great and the food OMG! Everything was so beautiful platted and the fruit was fresh and sweet.
author: Tabatha R.

description:
This is the perfect breakfast place!  I live in the middle of downtown and sometimes forget how residential and sleepy some parts of San Francisco can be.  Cole Valley is one of my favorite neighborhoods, and this cafe has never let me down.  I've gotten pancakes from them, (perfectly round, take up your whole plate, amazing), their challah bread french toast with fruit (drool), and some of their pasta specials (dinner for breakfast, yes please!)

Their fast, their staff are really nice, and it's just a nice place to sit and enjoy your breakfast and not feel like you're rushed because someone wants your table.
author: Kristen T.

description:
They were busy on a Saturday around noon, but it seemed everyone there (myself included) was overflow from the highly rated restaurant Zazie down the street, which had an astronomical line. 
The Bloody Mary- underwhelming! It was very thin and bland with hardly any vodka. After adding a hefty amount of tabasco it was drinkable. What a waste of $7. 
We all ordered different variations of scrambles, which were lacking flavor and overpriced. The vegetables did not taste fresh, and a friend at my table even commented it tasted "like DiGiorno pizza, and it wasn't even delivery". The side of potatoes were extremely undercooked and unseasoned, and the toast was not even toasted, it was simply sliced bread. 
Also, everything on the table was nearly empty- ketchup, salt and pepper, forcing us to steal them from a neighboring table. 
My friend who ordered the San Francisco Benedict and iced coffee is the only one who didn't complain about her meal, so perhaps that is the way to go if you're eating here. 
I wanted to love this place, there was plenty of open seating, and the menu was large with lots of options- but sadly that's where the positivity ends.
author: McKenna P.

description:
nice little place.

pro's:
good food
fair price
outdoor seating
wide range of food

con's:
staff is not very friendly
parking sucks
can be a bit of a wait in line
author: C J.

description: Not impressed. Potatoes sucked, crepe sauce was way too starchy. Eggs were over cooked. If the price was about 1/2 this would be bad, but not outrageous. I won't be back.
author: Seth C.

description:
Totally mediocre food but you know what to expect at Crepes on Cole. There are much better places to eat in the neighborhood but their food is good enough and service is fine at the counter.

Menu is the same as Squat and Gobble/Crepevine. Think chalkboard salads, soups, crepes. Lots of choices for breakfast which is served all day. 

If you're in the nabe and need a solid breakfast/brunch place, this will do. Otherwise, there are much better restaurants  in Cole Valley and Inner Sunset or Haight.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Came in for a typical Saturday brunch with a group of 7. The man behind the register wanted to split us in two separate groups: 4 of us on one number, the next 3 (including me) on a different number. Alright, no big deal.

After maybe 15-20 minutes, the first 4 in our group got their 4 meals. After 10 minutes of waiting for us to get our meals so we could all begin eating, our 3 meals still weren't there so we gave them the go ahead to start eating. While us 3 waited, maybe 8 other plates came out for people that came after us. We thought "oh maybe it's because they got pancakes/crepes, which are easier to make." Nope, some were the same exact meal my friend and I ordered in the later group! 

To make matters worse, once our food finally came (about 15-20 minutes in total later than our friends) I got the special (a crepe Benedict) that didn't even have hollandaise on it, as advertised. Also, my friends' plate in the later group didn't have avocado or sour cream, also as advertised. Not a good look for 2/3 of the meals to be missing an ingredient! 

The food was fine, but the staff/management just needs to get their priorities straight! If you can't get everyone's meal out at the same time, either let them know, or hold all of the plates until they're ready. And additionally, I feel like it's restaurant common knowledge to serve the people who came first, in regards to the dishes that went out to people who arrived after us! 

Trust me, you're better off waiting in line for Zazie's!
author: Tracy C.

description:
I used to come here and have breakfast while I did my laundry across the street. I've noticed that the laundromat is now closed, but this is still a fine place to eat breakfast if you're hungry and don't care about flowers in your food or celery dust sprinkled on top. This is like upgraded diner food, and I still come by every now and then for breakfast or lunch. The bagels are good, the eggs are good, the coffee is fine and the portions are huge. Soups and salads are also pretty good for lunch. I've never had a sandwich here, but imagine they're fine. The kitchen is a little slow, but everyone who works here is nice so nobody's gonna ruin your day.

Very  good value for your money....I came here a lot when I was broke. 

Husband and I stopped by for dessert tonight on a little nostalgia trip. We had a brown sugar crepe. Meh. This isnt really a great place for dessert unless you're a kid.
author: El B.

description: Located in the brunch capital of the city (according to snapchat), Crepes on Cole has an extensive menu where it is near impossible to not find something you will like. Open at the late hours, Crepes on Cole has something for everybody from savory crepes to waffles topped with fruit. Recommendation: Cole Valley Savory Crepe (Provolone cheese, onions, sun dried tomatoes pesto sauce, avocado, mushrooms and spinach)
author: Alina M.

description: Service was great and the food was even better. The owner, Sam was a treat. I got the bruschetta sandwich and was not disappointed, nor was my mom who had the vegetarian sandwich. Love! Will be back for sure.
author: Sharde H.

description: A lot of choices on the menu and you also have the option to build your own so it can be a bit overwhelming. Each plate is served with potatoes and mixed greens so the portion is actually really big. I got the Cole Valley with chicken and it was good. Although, I kinda wish it had more pesto or some other sauce. I also had the Bloody Mary but it was too watery for my taste.
author: Thao T.

description: Possibly the worst chicken salad I've ever had. The chicken is clearly precooked and then reheated in oil on the grill, giving it the consistency of crunchy rubber. Think of an old squash ball. For $17? Pick up your game.
author: Xander O.

description:
One of my favorite breakfast, brunch, lunch spots in the city. Such a hidden gem in Cole Valley.

Their food is home style goodness, except better than I can make at home. Their pancakes are my favorite pancakes ever. Large, fluffy, delicious. Their home style house potatoes are amazing. I could eat this for days, even when I'm not hungry. So good!

I have also tried other dishes and all are great. Their iced coffee is my favorite iced coffee in the city and I come here sometimes just for the coffee... and their free refills :)

They have a very friendly staff and are always very welcoming. Whether it's your first visit or hundredth visit, their service is always top notch!
author: Scott C.

description: Love this place! They have the best pancakes, the best tea- we don't live in SF, but visit a lot and each time we make sure we have our Sunday brunch here before we leave the city- very friendly owner and workers- wish we had this in our home town Mission Veijo Ca
author: Nahil K.

description: I would give this place 5 stars, but the menu online is different than the one at the store. I ordered to go and it was a bunch more expensive. ... with that said, if u like standard crepes u will be fine here. If u want a fifth star from me u should tell me the truth about how much I will have to pay and fix your windows (the place is super drafty)
author: Dan K.

description: Awesome crepes (meditteraan and eggs.benedict) and the gluten free pancakes were surprisingly good. Would definitely go back.
author: Anna C.

description:
I'm here at least twice a week.  At least.  They know me here.  

When the hipster assholes who stand in front of Zazie, waiting for an hour for their table, blocking the sidewalk for pedestrians and completely oblivious to anyone but themselves finally decide to grow up, or at least come to their senses, they come to CoC.  (Yes, I have a grudge.  But if you've ever seen Zazie on a weekend morning, you know what I'm talking about.)

Is CoC the best food ever?  No.  But you go out to brunch because you're looking for comforting food, you're too tired to make it yourself, and you don't want to wait 90 minutes for it.  CoC is family-owned, they have options for EVERYONE, they're friendly, not pretentious, and you get a ton of food.  What's not to like?
author: Samantha W.

description:
While Crepes on Cole offers a great atmosphere, their product that inspires their name is bested elsewhere. 

Star 1: How was the service and atmosphere?

Okay. The building, seating and overall vibe? Great, and while the service is friendly, expect to wait... as in a lot... for something as basic as a crepe. However, I won't say it's unreasonable. Star Granted. 

Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?

One of my fondest memories of growing up on the other side of the Atlantic is crepes, and you know what was so great about them? They were cheap! Alas, as is the American way, all things European come at a good ole' Uncle Sam premium, and that explains the $6.95 price tag on my peanut butter nutella crepe:

http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=51fhyxMVFjrqyjw_wgEKGg&userid=OKX-V5j_qfuOebeHeWGrHg

While it's a premium, it's not unreasonable relative to what you can find in the city. Star Granted.

Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?

It wasn't good. Let's start with the crepe itself. I understand throwing down a plain crepe so that you can charge for things like sugar or salt, but when the crepe to filling ratio is 3:1, a plain crepe turns into a weak point, bringing down the whole dish. My peanut butter and nutella filling was fine, but something that puzzled me (as you'll see in the pic) was a mess of what appeared to just be some runny canned whipped cream on the side. Why? A fresh spoonful? Great, but otherwise why bother? All in all, I wasn't a fan. No Stars Granted.

Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?

Pretty good atmosphere, but with a wak flagship product you might be better off going up the street. No Star Granted.
author: Paul V.

description:
Came here due to the long line at Zazie...next time I will wait out the line.

Had the Benedict and Salmon scramble...totally mediocre and overpriced.

They charge for coffee refills...seriously?
author: Wendy Z.

description:
Crepes on Cole is a great place for any time in the day (although brunch is the best). I've been here a few dozen times because of the great food and the place is almost never crowded.  All the crepes are good. The portion size is large :) and most dishes come with rosemary home fries and a large side salad. The beer and wine are limited but prices are good. 

My favorite crepe is benedict crepe. It's a crepe with bacon and cheese with a poached egg on top.
author: Ryan I.

description:
Went here for brunch with a friend. The crepes were good, and the atmosphere was cozy. Service was a bit slow, and so was the order, but overall it was okay. I did enjoy my crepe, so did my friend, and coffees were the right amount of boldness and warmth to keep us happy as we chatted. 

If you are looking for a place to get your crepe on, and meet someone for some good conversation on the weekend....or even heck, even during the lucky chance you have time during the weekday, this is a pretty good crepe spot.
author: Sonia A.

description: Definitely not worth coming here. There are lots of other places to eat around here that don't serve bad food. The other places will also give you a refund when they serve you bad food.
author: James W.

description:
Subpar food at a RIDICULOUS PRICE. 

I'm use to the expensive costs of SF and I'm happy to spend money on an excellent meal, but this was garbage. A poorly made scramble, a bagel (missing the cream cheese) and a decent crepe for over $40. Their online menu is completely deceiving with inaccurate prices - I mean, we were led to believe our meal was going to be around $20. My fault for not checking on the total before picking it up... When confronted about their mismarked menu and ridiculous prices, the manager rudely laughed it off.

Save yourself from throwing money in the trashcan and go to Bacon Bacon up the street on Fredrick: www.baconbaconsf.com, 1428 Haight Patio Cafe & Crepery: 1428haight.com or the Pork Store: http://www.porkstorecafe.com/, both nearby on Haight.
author: Chloe D.

description:
Very friendly service - he went out of this way to make a strawberry lemonade for the little one we had with us and didn't let us pu- put it on the house. 
- Pasta lunch special very nicely made as well as pancakes.
author: Mona B.

description:
Great family feel place. Choice of dishes ranges for savory to sweet for crepes. 

They have local artists canvas displayed so they can be bought be customers. 

Prices aren't bad and food services is pretty good.
author: Corie L.

description:
You'll probably notice that (unlike Zazie down the block) there are always tables available at this restaurant. There's a reason for that: the food is average and the service is very poor.

On the plus side the location is very nice. On the corner of Carl and Cole and with some okay outdoor seating. 

I've tried the crepes and buckwheat pancakes. The crepes were pretty good, but the pancakes were simply awful and came complete with a long blonde hair baked in the middle. 

The service is pretty bad and comes complete with some hipster attitude. TTables aren't cleaned very often and the place feels a bit ramshackle. Worse, the two times I was there the place was filled with feral children. One boy was running wild back and forth screaming. No one could be bothered to deal with it.

That said, the prices are cheaper than you'd expect for the area. If you have a big brood of kids, aren't too discerning and don't want to wait for your food, then this is a good choice. Otherwise I'd give it a pass.
author: Christopher J.

description:
To be honest I don't understand most of the bad critics for Crepes on Cole... I love this place, I usually go there for coffee and breakfast before heading to work (so conveniently located right next to MUNI!). 

FOOD ---- My go to is their cappuccino and a side of fresh fruit. It is always very tasty and I have never been disappointed so far. 

SERVICE ---- The waitresses are awesome. One morning I did not have enough cash on me so they told me I could just have the coffee and give them the money the day after, what a great customer service!!! 

Keep it up Crepes on Cole. I'll be back and will def keep telling my friends about this place.
author: Sev G.

description: Ordered a cole valley and fish man wharf crepes, as well as strawberry crepes.  The service is good.  Food is delicious
author: J L.

description:
Great place for breakfast! The pancakes are especially good, large and fluffy. The potatoes are also nice and crisp with some spices. Everything else is exactly what you'd expect from a greasy spoon.....

Scratch that. New short order cook... Move along nothing here to see
author: David B.

description:
I loved the location of this restaurant~ I ordered the New York Benedict which came with roasted red potatoes & fresh fruit~ I thought the eggs could have been a tad bit softer to create more yolk. I would have loved the English muffins to be toastier.  The hollandaise was thick and tasty yet it lacked the correct hollandaise flavor. I should have omitted the ham as it had a tangy flavor.  The potatoes were very good, and actually the best thing on my plate. 
The Cole valley crepe was good. It reminded me of a pizza. The texture of the crepe was like a light flavorful pancake.  The banana & Nutella crepe was dessert-like & tasty.  The challah bread French toast with strawberries was delicious~ I think it could have had something more on the plate. All in all it was a good choice for breakfast.
author: Theresa D.

description:
I'm the first person to tell someone their food sucks, this DOES NOT!!! Tried food from everyone's plate. French toast, eggs, bacon, sausage, pancakes all were great!!!
It was a little annoying to not have a waitress though.
Give 'em a try....you won't be disappointed!
author: R W.

description:
Ok, no lie, the following is stated on Wikipedia: 

"Throughout the 1980s the Haight became an epicenter for the SF Comedy Scene when a small coffee house off Haight Street called The Other Cafe (currently the restaurant Crepes on Cole) became a full-time comedy club helping to launch the careers of Robin Williams, Dana Carvey, and Whoopi Goldberg."

Legit link: http://www.theothercafe.com/the-official-other-cafe-story/

So aside from the historical coolness factor, Crepes on Cole also has FRESH SQUEEZED OJ. You read right. Splurge for the large OJ. I ordered a special called Crepes Benedict which was tasty, but not the best breakfast I've ever had. They serve tea in mini teapots, which would be just delightful if the tea inside were any good. It seems they use fresh ingredients and make everything to order, and it's not super crowded in there like the brunch place down the street, so you're sure to get a table on a weekday. 

You order at the counter, but they will bring you your food. Have to bus your own table, but you're also faced with a tip jar at the counter instead of the standard 20%. Prices seemed typical for the area. Overall a good experience with friendly staff, and a decent alternative to the other frenzied neighborhood joints.
author: Erin B.

description:
Compared to other crepe restaurants where you pay up front and grab a number, this one seemed kind of messy.  The tables were pushed around with chairs not tucked in which made it hard to navigate to the cashier.  Most of the table were also wobbly and as I waited for our food to arrive I saw groups do a musical chair number as they tried different tables to test the stability.  Dirty tables out numbered the clean ones which really limited where you were able to sit too.

The Cole Valley crepe I got said it came with pesto but when I dug into it the sauce was marinara.  No biggie though...  Husband's buck wheat pancake was really dry.  We probably won't go back since people watching there ended up being a little stressful! haha
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Dear COC,

I'm not mad, I'm just disappointed. 

I remember a mere year ago when your draft beers were $2.95 (now $4.95, only during happy hour) and there wasn't an absurd ($8!) credit/debit card minimum. 

If I want a shit ton of mediocre breakfast potatoes and a hearty helping of mixed greens with my grilled ham and cheddar sandwich (actually pretty tasty), I'll come running to you. But you're a little shady with your permanent "help wanted" sign in the window and ever-evolving cast of female ONLY cashiers/servers.  

Thanks for the memories and dependable, ample seating. 

Meh,
Adele
author: Adele A.

description:
I ordered the grilled chicken sandwich.  The service and the speed that the food was served was excellent.

The food is a different story. The potatoes and salad were very plain. The sandwich was just the right temperature and the bread had just the right amount of crunch. But again, the sandwich as a whole had no unique flavor.
author: Jibran M.

description:
EWW! My first and last experience was a NASTY one!

First we got a table by the window which was nice. We got to people watch as well as dog watch which was a plus! 

When our food came out, our server had her thumb in our salad which is already disgusting. Not sure what her name was since they have no name tags. She was a brunette with her hair in a messy pony tail. Another server that served us had a red and white striped tank top on. She was a brunette and her hair was short. She had the most hairy armpits ever. It's so bad that we noticed a lot of people talking and pointing it out. It was sad, but entertaining at the same time. 

When we got our food, my food was wrong. I ordered a crepe with eggs, mushrooms, and ham. They gave me a crepe with avocado instead of ham. I went up to the busy counter and told the waitress with a gray shirt and she seemed like she didn't give a sh!t. Another waitress took charge. She was the blond waitress with a black dress. She made sure I got my food right away. She fixed the issue and gave us a complimentary mimosa and iced coffee. She was the ONLY professional worker there. The other girls were just plain slobs! 

Our food was mediocre. The potatoes had no seasoning and I didn't even touch the salad since the waitress thumb was pressed down against it. We had better crepes at other places. 

Even though they fixed my crepe and gave me a free mimosa, The server with the hairy armpits made me lose my appetite. I would never dine here again.
author: Darlene M.

description:
I love this place! Plenty of seating and fast service.  

I usually order the San Francisco Benedict while my friend orders the French Toast w/fruit.    Only problem is this spinach can be a bit salty...

the place can be cleaner....
author: Angelica C.

description:
I thought the food here was alright - I had a Greek Chicken Salad that was filling and pretty tasty.  

The service wasn't all that great...the person taking my order didn't seem to be in a good mood and the server bringing the food also brought a bit of attitude.

I wouldn't make this place a destination, but it's not a bad spot if you're in the area.
author: Ken G.

description: Food is spectacular.  Honestly - best crepes ever.  My favorite is the Basil crepe, and my husband really likes the Cole Valley.  And the dessert crepes are generous - no skimping on the Nutella or whatever.   Also, I've never arrived (maybe 30 visits) and been unable to find a seat.  The reason I can't do 5 stars is that the place is getting run down.  They need to clean it up and replace or refinish some furniture. Needs spiffing up.  Also, you want to walk here or bike or take the street car or bus cause parking is a challenge.  Not as bad as North Beach, but it's a hassle.
author: Cassie C.

description:
Another cute brunch/dinner spot in the city discovered! Went on my weekly food adventure with my good buddy for dinner and decided to try this spot out after passing by it a few times on the bus. Plus, I've always seen this place with people but it's never overly packed so I was curious to see how it compares to other brunch food type places I've been to.

Right when walking into the restaurant, I noticed how quiet this place was for the most part. People come in small groups of threes or fours, and some even come by themselves for a small meal. Interesting! The concept is like the same as crepevine and Squat & Gobble where you order and pay at the counter, get a number, and then pick anywhere to sit. So onto the menu choices...

They have a LOT to choose from. Having breakfast for dinner is even an option! They serve food like omelettes, sandwiches, pancakes, bagels, salads, and of course, crepes! Just because this places IS called "Crepes on Cole", I figured it was appropriate to order a savory crepe for dinner. I got the Fisherman's Wharf (smoked salmon, havarti, capers, dill, red onions, spinach) and my friend got the Bon Jour (goat cheese, eggs, onion, chicken apple sausage). Both ranged around $11-$12 which was alright considering all savory crepes come with potatoes and mixed greens on the side. Overall I thought the food was alright. Not bad for the portion sizes but I don't think it is something to rant or rave about. It was filling at least! 

Only one bathroom but it was really well kept and clean. I would come back here again to try other options and maybe even a dessert crepe. I also really enjoy the atmosphere here. Reminds me of a cafe or coffee shop that looks like it could be in movies.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Chicken pesto crepe, buttermilk pancakes, and eggs with apple sausage. 

The place is fairly crowded but there is plenty of seating as long as you have no more than four people in your party. It's definitely more of a breakfast place. Of course there are lots of crepes to choose from, but there are also sandwiches and omelettes too. 

Everything was fresh and made to order. Sadly though, the chicken pesto crepe was downright bland. There were heaping chunks of chicken breast and it looked great with a side salad but it lacked any serious flavor. 

At least the pancakes were deliciously fluffy with butter and syrup on the side and the apple sausage was good too. You really can't go wrong there. 

If your taking public transportation the N Judah rolls right by this place. There are plenty of spots to try on this corner and it looks like I'll be trying something else next time.
author: Lloyd B.

description: Great food here! I had the chicken pesto crepe and it was great. My kids even liked it - with mushrooms! Crepes were also delicious! They were s little pricey at 7.95 (more than in Paris), but very good!
author: Jason H.

description: Honestly, I've only gotten the burger, which I get every time I come here. It's an awesome deal, tasty, and comes with cheese, avocado, and mushrooms. It also comes with some spring greens and fried potatoes. More importantly, as a caregiver for children with severe Autism, this is one of the few places I can take them and feel welcomed. The owner is super nice and accommodating and we always seem to luck out and get a bench seat.
author: Dawn C.

description: We always come here when in SF and we love it! Half moon bay, french toast or just eggs and bacon, and a decent cup of coffee!!! Give me wifi and I'd give this place a five.
author: Kristina T.

description:
I loved loved loved the chick pesto Salad... Ohhh my god the best I ever had. 

I live in East bay and every time I'm near by I come to this place, the owner Sam is such a nice guy he always take good care of us.

I recommend this place
author: Tareq M.

description: Come here fairly often since it is close to where I live. Nothing special but have never had a bad meal here. I mean cmon.... It's a crepe. There is no such thing as a bad crepe. Especially dessert crepes!:)
author: Brady A.

description: Very good neighborhood breakfast and lunch place. The eggs benedicts are really good. Less than an $8 charge is cash only.
author: makenna n.

description:
Zazie's was too busy, even on Labor Day (well, what was I thinking!!), so I brought me and my starving stomach to the next brunch spot on the same street, and ended up here.

I got a salsa crepe -- the salsa was spicy, the ingredients mushed together flavorlessly in the crepe, and there is salad and potatoes on the side. It's not spectacular enough for me to remember it. I'd rather go to a Crepevine.

This place seems to take people who don't manage to get i to Zazie's. By that time those people are super hungry and will chow down anything served to them.
author: Alice C.

description: Very yummy spot for all meals of the day! Had the banana coconut pancakes for brunch, and they were fluffy and delicious. Good drink menu too. I had a nice mocha. Big variety of crepes(both savory and sweet) drinks, breakfast items and eggs too. While the food is awesome, I can see why the wait might be long on a busy day due to the way they take orders(get in line, order, get a number, then a table). Today wasn't too bad so food was fairly quick, which was nice.
author: Hanna C.

description:
So we decided that we were moving away from Zazie and the long lines. What a pleasant surprise. The atmosphere is great and the food is very good. We had excellent coffee, pastrami sandwiches and real cups of fruit (tasty and fresh). They also serve crepes obviously which we did not try. We noted that they have gluten free options. 
I strongly recommend the place.
author: Joanna B.

description: This was some real good shhh... I got Eggs Benedict which we all know is a very hit and miss kind of dish. You can use poor quality meet or I've had it be too salty. They nailed it--it didn't taste cheap. Prices were decent and only thing is I didn't see any outside seating so it get crowded fast and the spaces are tight, but over all very good food.
author: Rachel R.

description: Great  breakfast place, ducked out of the rain one morning for coffee and breakfast. Service was quick and friendly, Benedict crepe was really good. This place reminds me of a college town coffee house. Nice vibe.
author: Stacie D.

description: This place is just okay. Every time I go I ask myself, why am I here? Food isn't amazing and there are better choices close by. I feel like people come here because Zazie or El Padrecito are too packed.
author: Peter S.

description:
I can't believe how many times i've walked into a restaurant excited to try a new place just to find the same colorful chalkboard menu high up on the wall. It actually makes me laugh now! Is it Squat & Gobble? Is it Crepevine? No, it's Crepes on Cole! I'm unaware of any shared ownership between the restaurants but i was amused.

My eyes battled a serious darting problem. The vast menu and the long line for brunch put some pressure on me. I jumped from a stack of fluffy pancakes to a cheeseburger to the half sandwich half soup combo only to land on the Half Moon Bay dish. There is something here for everyone. I couldn't decide between coffee or a mimosa.... so i chose both. Woohoo free coffee refills! Can't say the same for the mimosas though :( 

The Half Moon Bay was much better than i anticipated. I was trying to keep my brunch carb free (excluding the champagne) and ordered this egg scramble with smoked salmon, worried it might be slightly bland. The goat cheese made all the difference and it was unanimous i had the best tasting plate at my table. I tasted my friend's rancheros special and my other friend's omelette to find myself shrugging and moving on back to my awesome dish.

My lunch rounded out to an even $20. This restaurant had customers coming in and out. Super busy but the turnover was quick! You won't have to wait long for a table.
author: Samantha L.

description: This place is shit.  They live off of the overflow from Zazie. Overpriced.  And less than mediocre.  Potatoes under cooked.  Wrong ingredients in my omelette.  Don't go here unless you're desperate and lazy.
author: Marlin D.

description: Crepes on Cole is a great place to read a novel or park your fanny and get to business with the free WiFi. There are free refills on coffee and a rotation of local artists' paintings adorning the walls - all are for sale if one suits your fancy. The french toast here comes with a heap of butter, powdered sugar, strawberries, and bananas. It isn't too thick and there is enough cinnamon in the eggwash. I have been here numerous times and have never left this place hungry. There is complimentary lemon water and a 50" flatscreen as well. The owner makes an effort to remember and truly engage his regulars; A lost art these days. From eating breakfast with family to catching up with friends with a late-night banana-Nutella crepe, I will definitely keep coming back!
author: Damond N.

description: Sorry to write this review. I prefer writing 5 star ones. I recently moved into this neighborhood and like trying out different restaurants. I had lunch here today and was terribly disappointed in it. Maybe it is because I ordered a Greek salad with chicken, and my friend ordered a caprese salad. But both were tasteless. The chicken was dry and boring and my friend left most of her salad on the plate. On top of that, 2 salads plus 2 diet cokes were over $35. Not good. The final problem was that the bathroom was dirty. I/we will never go back there.
author: Kathy J.

description: Not sure if the idea for the look of the place is suppose to be old but they can use some new chairs and tables. The food was alright, the chicken was under seasoned. But friendly service!
author: Valerie S.

description: Right next to the golden gate park.. stopped there for crepe and ice coffee before bike ride.. perfect weather.. good location.. very sunny.. pleasant sitting.. food was ok..
author: Sua Y.

description: Being new to San Francisco and living on cole street, crepes on cole was the first place that me and my roommate had lunch and breakfast. We enjoyed two meals on same day at the place. Despite of the fact it's a over priced crepe only. But tonight was disappointing, my roommate ordered strawberry-chocolate whipped cream for to go. First of all the waitress's were rude to her and her crepe for to go was packed in a gigantic box. By the time she reached back room, all the cream has spilled and ruined her bag. Please!! Use foil for packing. And smile it doesn't cost anything.
author: Shria D.

description:
Thought it was average. I had the Chicken Pesto Crepe . The gal said that the pesto  was made by an Italian restaurant down the street.
I am a huge pesto fan and was very excited.
However I would say store-bought pesto is way better than this. My husband had the Bonjour Crepe, he said he thought his was probably better than mine. My auntie had the Hawaiian Crepe. I probably won't go back.
author: Tiffany S.

description: We originally planned to eat down the street but it was a madhouse and over an hour wait !! My friends and I were hungry this beautiful day in SF so we walked an ran into this place!   Everyone who ordered enjoyed what they ate!! The fresh orange carrot juice was a treat!!  I'd say the only thing you have to be careful of is getting a big enough table because if you order the side potatoes you might not have room because there HUGE!!  Man on man I'll be back for sure !! Yum!!
author: Jesse S.

description: Not bad - not great. Come on though. A basic crepe does not have to have onions on it, a salad and a side of potatoes does it? Apparently at Crepes on Cole it does. Consequently, all their crepes taste of onions. Yuck. As someone with an onion allergy and a love of crepes: double yuck!! I do not want to have a sugar crepe in order to not have an onion crepe, thanks very much. Sorry, not much of a review - more of a rant.
author: Anne E.

description:
So full disclosure: my friends and I all came here for lunch and NONE of us tried the crepes.  So this rating may not be an accurate representation of this place's full potential.

I did enjoy my salad; I tried the kale salad which is a summer special.  It had kale, spinach, almonds, dried cranberries, goat cheese, and strawberries with a citrus dressing.  It was light and healthy, which was exactly what I was looking for.

The did ask me what kind of bread I wanted on the side and I asked them If I could have anything besides bread and they said that wasn't an option... kind of odd for an SF place to NOT have a non-gluten side option??

TIP: if you get a small coffee to drink there (instead of to go) the mug is MUCH bigger.  

I don't know if the guy helping us was just new (he did give my friend back a $10 instead of a $5 and seemed tad befuddled behind the counter) but hey... I definitely appreciate a few extra ounces of caff in the morning!
author: Kelsey H.

description:
Not bad not bad! Originally me and my friend wanted to go to Cafe Reverie but they stopped breakfast food at 3 so we decided to come here instead.

~ Definitely a bit pricey for a poor college student but oh well. I ended up paying about $28 for my friend and me. 
~ Food came pretty quick and looked pretty.
~ Nice atmosphere and love the seating. Seating next to the window is really nice. 
~ Ordered the NYC Benedict, which was not bad. Potatoes were good, fruit was good and the Benedict wasn't bad. My friend who ordered an omelet tasted pretty good too~

Overall not bad, would recommend, but just pricey so unless you can pay $10 or so for breakfast, go on ahead.
author: Samantha Y.

description:
I found this place on yelp when we needed a place to eat before hitting a club nearby on Halloween.  Thanks to the Yelp community.

So far, I've been here twice.  Once for dinner, on Halloween and once for brunch on the weekend.  Both times, this place was crowded and lively.  I think it's the owner that is usually behind the counter.  He is definitely a character and easily jokes with his customers.  This is a great place for people watching with a good mix of people.  There are groups of friends, families with kids, couples, and even people eating by themselves.

The menu is up on huge chalkboards on the wall behind the cashier.  You go up to order and take a number to your table.  There are only 2 wait staff but they are very fast and efficient.  

I had a glass of hot apple cider.  I can't remember how much it was but remember it being a good deal.  You get a huge glass with a cinnamon stick to stir.  It was soo good on a cold night, nice and sweet with spices warm and comforting.

I got the grilled chicken sandwich.  The portions are huge here.  It came with a nice healthy size of potatoes and a salad.  The potatoes were delish with the herbs. (Fried greasy goodness)  The salad was fresh with mixed greens and a light dressing.  The bf didn't like the greens cuz he considered it weeds.  The sandwich was good.  The chicken was dry and needed seasoning but the pesto sauce was yummy in it.

The bf got a Hawaiian crepe and he liked his meal.

Overall, this place serves lots of delicious food at good prices and huge portions.
author: Judy K.

description:
$2.50 Lagunitas?  Crepes?  YES!!!

Ok, this place was great, even if it was just for the cheap-ass, good beer.  Go here for that, you won't be disappointed.  The food menu looked pretty good but we had already eaten dinner, so I went for a crepe.  The butter and sugar crepe was DELICIOUS.  Warm, gooey, sugary... mmmmmm.  A great dessert.  

This is a short order place, so you order at the counter and sit down to wait for your food.  The atmosphere is nice, quaint but it's definitely quick and not the type of place to go if you're looking to sit down and have a 5-star meal.

Go here, though.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Jenna S.

description:
Right when you walk into Crepes on Cole, they have those huge chalkboard menus...used to be original, but now it's synonymous to almost any crepe place (crepevine, squat & gobble, etc)...

They have a decent selection of crepes and omelettes, but nothing I haven't really seen before.  I ordered the Cole Valley Crepe while my friend ordered the Pesto crepe. Both were served with a heaping portion of home fries. All in all, the meal was alright, it was mindblowingly average.

Service here is okay. When they were delivered to the table, the waiter still managed to switch our orders even though we made it clear who had what by raising our hand when when he announced each one...oh well. All in all, the prices are fair, but there's really nothing here that would bring me back for a second time.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Crepes on Cole is my favorite cafe in Cole Valley. My wife and I come here all the time, for breakfast, lunch, dinner and everything in between. I am addicted to their soups and their sandwiches - the eggplant sandwich and grilled chicken w/pesto are THE BEST.

Their breakfast is fantastic as well. Their blueberry pancakes are phenomenal, though you may have to request extra syrup- they give you a HUGE portion. French toast is up there too, as well as their large range of benedicts that are available. Ask them to toast the English muffins first when you order.

If you want to go the crepe route, you can get one of the pre-configured options or you can make your own to spec. My wife gets spinach, artichokes, roasted red peppers, mushrooms, garlic and havarti cheese, and it's awesome. For dessert crepes, you can't lose with a banana-nutella crepe.

They will also do what my wife and I call the Hangover Cure, which is fresh carrot juice with orange juice mixed in. Just ask and you shall be saved from the crappy red wine your friends brought over the night before.

The owner, Sam, is a great guy and is often there. He can be tough but he demands excellence and he gets it. He wants every customer to have a great experience and it shows. All the server gals are great too, especially when they get to know you.

I think the best thing about Crepes is the atmosphere. Having lived in Cole Valley for eight years I can safely say many of the cafes in Cole Valley are lacking in this respect. Most of them are poorly laid out, loud, cold and cramped. Crepes is none of these.

Crepes is right on the corner of Carl and Cole. If you want to just space out, grab a window seat and watch the N-Judah and the people go by, this is your place. If you want to grab a bite pretty much any normal time of day that is solid and tasty, this is your place. If you want a no-frills breakfast, this is your place. If you just want some tea and a cookie and an awesome space to work, you will love it too.

Note: There is no Wi-fi, and that's a good thing- it weeds out the cheapos who don't want to pay for their own bandwidth and who buy one thing and camp out for 7 hours.
author: Nowell V.

description:
Everyday on my way home, on the N Judah, the train stops at Carl and Cole. On that same intersection is Crepes On Cole. I decided to try it last week since Crepevine was always packed with people after work and this place seemed like a pretty convenient place to grab a bite before heading home to crash out on the couch. Turns out I ended up coming here twice for lunch. I must say that their crepes are not bad. Sometimes a hit or miss, but generally pretty good when there's warm melted cheese stuffed in there. 

The first time I ordered a crepe, I thought I had to eat it like a burrito before figuring out it was a fork and knife type of food. The ingredients would always flop out when I attempted to hold it together with my hands, while people would look at me funny as I did this. It wasn't until I started learning how to make these that I had to use a fork and knife. (haha don't judge me!) 

FOOD:

Caneloni Crepe - Everything you'd find in a pizza in here except for the charcuterie meats, but also smothered in flavorful marinara sauce.  The first time around, I was wondering why I was using a fork to eat this when I could have used my hands!

Bonjour Crepe - Well..I'm glad I didn't find any escargot in here, however, the warm melted goat cheese and chicken sausages stuffed in here were bomb diggity delicious! 

Fisherman's Wharf - Pretty basic smoked salmon, havarti cheese and capers stuffed in here. When I think Fisherman's Wharf here in SF, I think CRAB. Not Kosher food.. Ah well. 

Water - If there was something floating in here, I'd rip this place 2 less stars. 

SERVICE:

Friendly, energetic and sometimes bubbly. When I came here with a coworker, it was okay service. When I came here on my own, I felt the service was better. As a bachelor (and sometimes being a little hom-sup), the females here are pretty damn cute. Is this why I saw a lot of older men in here sitting at a table by themselves eating when I came that second time? Well, well...
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Average brunch place with your average eggs-prepared-300-ways, sweet/savory crepes, etc. The Cole Valley (can't quite remember the name now, unfortunately?) crepe was pretty good. House potatoes slightly undercooked, and a little pricey for how average all the food is. But very, very nice customer service. Plus, I'm of the personal opinion that it's very, very difficult to do brunch wrong. For both reasons, then - the 4 stars.

To give you an idea, this is very similar to Crepevine - which I probably prefer.
author: Dawn N.

description:
Eh, service was a little slow and strange.  I would not wanna work for that guy, especially if i were a female.  The 'help wanted' sign on the front door looks as if it is perpetually there.  I would assume they run through a lotta staff there judging by the minimal witnessing of how the ladies working were being 'spoken' too (in front of customers).  It wasnt horrible, but it was unprofessional.

Food was pretty average, same with the coffee.  Prices were a bit high and i just couldnt find a whole lotta reasons id wanna go back.
author: Seven T.

description:
I came for a Saturday lunch to Crepes on Cole but decided to have the Bruschetta instead of the obligatory crepes. The queue was out of the door so it was a popular spot for lunch, but overall I wasn't that impressed.

Brushcetta is not meant to have mozzarella on it in my book and the plate was too full of empty salad rather than the bread and tomatoes you would normally expect from Bruschetta.
author: Matt B.

description:
Although I'm a good cook, sometimes going out for comfort food strikes. Crepes on Cole has just that- and huge portions. It's relaxed and homey; you can read in peace or feel comfortable conversing with the other patrons or the people who work. Sam is really nice. 
My favorite things to get are their fresh squeezed orange juice and their chicken pesto sandwich, which comes with skillet potatoes (heavenly) and a fresh green salad.
author: Rachel D.

description: Got a great recommendation from an uber driver and decided to try it out. We walked in and immediately felt like peasants. The girl (dirty blonde-short hair-looks incredibly stoned) working the counter looked at us, then looked us up and down, THEN walked away. I literally laughed out loud. I thought she was kidding. Finally when we did get her attention to order, she just kept looking at us like we were from a different planet and we weren't worthy of her time and energy. Just awful service. giving an extra star ONLY because my pancakes were really good.
author: Hannah E.

description: Big portions, but I wasn't too pleased with the quality of the food. I got the tofu crepe which came with mixed greens and potatoes. The potatoes were undercooked and the tofu was marinated in something waaaaay too salty. Also the place was a bit dingy looking and the table I sat at was weirdly sticky.
author: Elena P.

description:
When my sister suggested we hit up Crepes on Cole for lunch, I was pretty pumped. I love a good crepe. And no, I don't pronounce it "crehp." Nor do I say "coo-min." It's "craype" and "cue-min" over here! This is Amurrica, dammit! But I digress.

I'll freely admit that, upon walking into the place, I was totally overwhelmed. The menu is HUGE. And not just "huge" as in "a lot of choices," but "huge" as in "it takes up two whole walls." If you like variety, you won't be disappointed here. They've got everything from sandwiches to burgers to salads to breakfast treats and benedicts... and of course, crepes. Sweet and savory. My first impression was that this would be a great place to bring a really indecisive group of friends. 

My second impression was that-- for the exact same reason-- this would be a TERRIBLE place to bring a really indecisive group of friends. 

I probably spent 10 minutes reading and re-reading the menu, rationalizing my different options and weighing them against others. Have I mentioned that I struggle with ADD? Oh yeah. 

My sister and I finally decided to split a Caprese Salad and a Build-Your-Own Crepe. We opted for goat cheese, spinach, mushrooms, and onions. A winning combination! I highly recommend it. Both items were totally delicious and HOLY COW are those salads huge! 

The one thing that threw me was that the crepes here are served on plates! Crazy. I live in Denver, and crepes are street food there... served from carts or farmer's market stands, folded into triangles and ensconced in little waxed-paper pouches. I felt very posh eating one with a knife and fork on an actual plate. So, an extra bonus star to Crepes on Cole for making me feel all fancy n' stuff. I dig it.
author: Kym G.

description:
I have been coming and going to this place for some time now, and I really enjoy the food! The people who work there are great- the owner who is always there is really nice.

It can be crowded at times, but its worth the wait the food is amazing. I love the Fisherman's Wharf and everything else.
author: Nina M.

description: Crepes on Cole is a jewel in a sea of tasty but non-kid-friendly restaurants in the city.  It's not huge but larger than most neighborhood eateries in the area, which definitely helps with little ones.  The menu is diverse, there's something for everyone and it's all delicious.  My only criticism is that there aren't enough napkins on tables and the menu is so copious, it's difficult to review everything before you start holding up the line, neither of which were worth losing a star.
author: Tracy J.

description:
Typical crepe place. Good for brunch. The portions are huge!
The food isn't too memorable but I would return here if I need a big brunch!
The quality and service is fine. Nothing to complain about.
If you're ever in the area and don't know where to grab brunch or lunch, Crepes on Cole is a safe bet.
author: Nona T.

description: Not as good as Crepevine in Inner Sunset, but nice when you need something fast.
author: Slpgiggles D.

description:
Food was fantastic,  perfect portions and a nice interior space. We met with Sam the owner and he told us a bit about the history of Cole Valley and brought us a free crepe dessert, really nice guy. 

Definitely want to come back to this place next time I'm in the area.
author: Nick W.

description: For the 2nd time in a row, I ate here and ordered my potatoes crispy. They came out barely cooked. I sent them back, and again, they weren't even brown. Do they not know what CRISPY means? Was it too much to ask? FUCK this place.
author: Bernal R.

description:
The "Fisherman's Wharf" has got to be the best smoked salmon crepe ever, maybe even the best thing I've ever eaten. The first bite makes me smile every time. 

I highly highly recommend this place for a late breakfast or lunch thing.
author: Tyson H.

description: This place was just OK, it was really crowded with a weird line system and smooshed together tables.  It is basically like crepevine, they do have vegan options so that was nice.  I wasn't a huge fan of the coffee.  Not to much in the area, so in that respect its not to bad.  Wouldn't be my first choice, but it's not terrible.
author: Courtney R.
