description: We always come here when my husband has to see his doctors at UCSF. I love their omelettes and fresh squeezed orange juice. Their staff is extremely friendly and they always keep the restaurant clean. Can't go wrong with this place.
author: Claire S.

description: I got scrambled eggs, bacon, and a beer and it was close to twenty dollars. They food was okay but for the price I thought it should be better. They tried to make up for it with some ridiculously sized fruit wedges that were completely unnecessary and made it hard to eat anything on my plate. That staff was swell and I tipped them even though I thought I was getting ripped off. It's not their fault.
author: Fred F.

description:
10 check ins so far but I've been here far more times.  I still am unable to understand the poor ratings.  I am guessing its because people are walking in disappointed that Zazie's didn't work out so they had their hopes set and they got squashed?   C'mon my fellow Yelpers-reviewing a place after choosing to bail on another means cleansing the palate, not under-toning with your bummin' about having to 'settle'.

Speaking of cleansing palates...

COC is a great spot.  It's spacious, always has 2.95 beers on tap (if this was in Portland or Anchorage it'd be packed 24/7), it's got outlets, employees are courteous, only 1 bathroom but it's always in good shape, and the food is better than good, it's YUM!

I live around the corner so Zazie's is often an option that I pass on.  
Why?  Because I like nice people with my tasty grub.  

Highly recommend the pesto chicken crepe and the burger is a huge, satisfying plate!  They should add wifi, though if they did- I may never grocery shop again.
author: Ashley W.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, since the line at Zazie is always so long and the other options in the hood are pretty so-so. I wasn't expecting much service-wise--just some good food. 

Three of us came in and ordered when they weren't too busy and figured it wouldn't be too long of a wait. After about 20 minutes we started noticing that everyone who had walked in and ordered after us had already gotten their food. I thought it was since they had ordered crepes and we'd gotten egg dishes, but then I saw my exact meal come to the table next to us who came in 10 minutes after us. 

Our food came after about 30 minutes, and the scrambled eggs were cold to the point where the cheese was hardened and congealed. We sent them back and oddly enough got new eggs within 4 or 5 minutes so not sure what the initial wait was.

The eggs Benedict (I know I know what was I thinking) was very subpar--almost no hollandaise and a weirdly large english muffin for such a tiny egg. The scrambled eggs were pretty whatever. If you can't get scrambled eggs right the first time that's a little disappointing. The pancakes were surprisingly good, so I'll give them points for that. 

All in all it was just a very mediocre meal with not great service. Would've been find if I were at a greasy spoon diner but this place seems to think of itself as a step up. I can forgive long waits and so-so service if the food is worth it but I walked out really disappointed in the food.
author: Molly O.

description:
Food is ok. Nothing amazing, but Ok/good.  The entire menu is crepes, pancakes, benedicts, and other similar breakfast food.  We had huevos rancheros and a savory crepe and each cost around $11.  Pretty standard for taste and quality. 

Portions are generous. I noticed that many of the diners leaving when we sat down left a lot of food behind on their plates. 

Also, a good spot for "people watching": many windows on a busy corner near a muni N line stop.
author: John B.

description:
Great smiling service but come on!!! While you serve good beers (easy thing to do), you should not claim that you know how to make crepes.

We had a couple of dessert crepes and neither one of them could be consider as such. Thick undercooked dough filled with a paste far from tasting like its name and we just wasted our $$$ on what could have been a great afternoon delight.

Who ever is producing this dish should go back to basic cooking school.
author: Peter L.

description: This is one of the worst brunch places I've been to in SF. Ordered the caprese w/ garlic prawns and my friend ordered a salmon burger and cappuccino. My salad was completely underdressed and it wasn't tossed - so I had a top layered w/ vinegar and a whole bottom layer dry. My friend's burger also wasn't seasoned and the coffee was gross. It tasted like they reused grind and just added a layer of fresh on top.
author: Claire J.

description:
I came here on Saturday with my friend and ordered a toasted wheat bagel and my friend ordered an eggs benedict dish.

The place was not at all busy, and we still got our food 20 minutes after ordering. The server comes to me and says, "Um, ah... we didn't have wheat so I brought you a plain bagel". The bagel was stale and cold and smelling of garlic/onion bagel (most likely stored together). If you do not have what I've ordered you should tell me so that I can decide on another breakfast option, not assume that that I will be just as happy with a substitution.

Even worse, my friends eggs were completely under cooked (with runny whites) and his house potatoes were also stale and chewy.

I do not recommend coming here. I wish I had gone to any other breakfast place on Cole Street.
author: Niki M.

description: Delicious food and great atmosphere. A little pricey but worth it for quality and quantity. I got the French toast and loved it. The half moon bay scramble is out of this world.
author: Jasmin R.

description:
I can't eat gluten, so my food choices here are limited, and I was prepared to be disappointed. But I had a caprese salad and a pot of tea, and you know what? It was reasonable, it was good, the place is open late and it's quiet -- it was just what I needed at the time. 
Be aware, the ambiance is definitely not romantic. It's more like a bluehair hangout than I would have guessed from the name and placement. But, sometimes you need that kind of peaceful atmosphere in the middle of a big city.
author: Alexa A.

description:
This is only my second review. Crepes on Cole used to be my go-to breakfast spot, but the last couple times I went, I have been very disappointed. 

Yesterday, I came in with a few friends. One of my friends decided to save a table while the rest of us ordered our food. After we were done ordering, he went up and ordered (several minutes later). 

The three of us who ordered food first got our dishes around the same time. We began eating our food and when we were all about 2/3's done, my friend still hadn't gotten his food. We flagged one of the waitresses down and she said she would look into it. About 5 minutes later she came back and told us she had not found his order ticket and asked him what he ordered. At this time, another friend of mine came in and asked if he could add his order to the order that was lost. She said she could not do that and asked him to go wait in the long line to order. You would think that the girl would say sorry, or try to accomodate my other friend after the mistake...but no, she didn't seem to care.

My friends dish finally showed up. At this point, I wasn't too thrilled at the service so I politely asked her to comp the meal that was forgotten about. She said she couldn't do that but might be able to get us a free drink. A free drink?? I told her we have been waiting an hour for his food since he ordered...the other 3 of us finished our food about 10 minutes ago. 

Sure enough, the waitress never came back to tell us anything. I had to go find her and ask nicely to speak with her manager.  She said he was at the cash register. I have seen him before from previous times coming to crepes on cole...I think he is the owner. I went up to him and politely asked him to comp the meal that was lost. I told him we waited an hour for my friends meal. I also mentioned that nobody even said sorry for the mistake. He turned around to look at his staff and looked at me with an angry expression on his face. "An hour?? You did not wait an hour!." He then said these exact words: "You want the entire staff to apologize to you??." At the same time he grabbed 11 dollars from the register and slammed it on the table. "Here is your refund, have a nice day" in a disgusted tone. I told him I didn't want the whole staff to apologize....then I took the money and walked away.

I could not believe I got that kind of attitude from the manager. It is not like I was one of those angry/entitled customers. I will not be coming here anymore nor recommending it to my friends. Go to Crepevine in the inner sunset instead. Better staff and lower prices.
author: James O.

description:
We came here on a Saturday morning. Wasn't too busy. We ordered a pretty simple meal, eggs and sausage for my husband and a bagel and fruit for myself.

We waited nearly half an hour for the food, and during that time 4 groups who arrived after us were served. Pretty frustrating. 

The food itself was alright but nothing to ride home about. The fruit cup was the highlight as it had actual berries in it too, not just melon like lots of places. 

I like to keep an open mind with new places and other peoples reviews but wish I had listened to my instincts on this one.
author: Sarah B.

description: Witnessed the man taking orders (perhaps the manager or owner) yell at his staff, in front of a full line of customers. The act alone made me vouch to never return again. The food is great, but it's difficult to support a restaurant that treats it's employees so poorly.
author: Lissette V.

description: My husband and I came here for breakfast. He ordered the New Mexico plate and I order the half moon... Both super delicious. The coffee was good too. The only reason why I'm not giving 5 stars is because I didn't feel as though the staff was that friendly. She seemed annoyed when I was trying to order and the person who dropped off the food didn't seem happy either. Other than that... The food was good and the place was cute.
author: May K.

description:
Nasty! 4 cooks, 1 server/runner/cashier, and only 15 people waiting ages for cold nasty flavorless slopped together food. My sandwich was rivaled by the one in the 7/11 refrigerator. My soup was like a cold mash of meat gelatin with no salt. The salad was good except there was no dressing. 
Never again
author: michael w.

description:
Sunday Brunch - hungry, in walking distance and b'cus Zazie's wait was one hour, Reverie's line was really long
Bloody Marys - needed more spice and vodka
Chicken Pesto Crepe - chicken was dry, not enough pesto, crepe was limp and flavorless
Huevos Rancheros - beans were tasty, everything else didn't blend well
Potatoes - looked better than it tasted
Side Salad - nicely dressed 
Staff were friendly
Total - $36
We should have walked a little further. Will not return
author: PreciousSwt P.

description: Crepes on Cole is a lovely brunch and lunch spot. The open seating makes for nice relaxing space to chat with friends or find a cozy spot to do some work on the computer. I ordered a Fisherman's Warf Crepe with an fried egg on top. It was just perfect and exactly what I wanted. :)
author: Marcelle G.

description:
I love Crepes on Cole.  Haven't been here in a while because don't live in SF anymore, but I try to drop in when I am in SF.  I think the food is really good.  Pesto crepes and pastrami sandwich are few of my favorites.  

I especially like Sam, the owner.  He is a great guy and really makes an effort to ensure you are happy and feel welcome.  Services has always been good here in my experience.  Great place for students to study during the day when it is slow.  Plenty of room and good coffee.
author: Shantay B.

description:
The preparation of the food was obviously without  much thought, it seemed like maybe the cook was not good but this was a bad meal, my wife and I came here because the good restaurant also on Cole was very busy. We feel that this was a mistake to eat here based on the taste of the food.

Lots of cheese, nothing nutritious at all.(got the veggie omelet)
author: Ianto J.

description:
House sitting in the neighborhood and decided to give this place a try.
I ordered the Cesar Salad for dinner. It was a cesar salad... Nothing special.
They gave me the choice of a bagel or a baguette to go with the salad. I asked for the bagel, non toasted. It came out toasted... which was fine, except I was the only person in the entire place.. I can understand minor mistakes like that when a restaurant is packed, but come on.. I was the only person in there.

For dessert, I ordered the Strawberry/Chocolate crepe to go. I mean, I finished the whole thing.. but it wasn't anything special. Genki Crepes on Clement is way better.

I'd go back if I needed to.. but it won't be a priority.
author: Rachel E.

description:
It's ok but not more. Good thing about this place is that you usually can always find a spot to take a seat and have something to eat. N-Line station is right across the street. 

The pancakes are good; pesto chicken didn't really have much of a taste.
author: Rudi B.

description:
Go-to neighborhood spot when we want to go out, not spend too much money, and eat something reasonably healthy.

Fun facts:
- The bleu salad with chicken is one of the best salads I have had in the city. Seriously. 
- Good beer (I get Lagunitas) on draft for cheap!
- Tasty soups.
- Generous portions for the prices.
- Friendly service.
- Sometimes good people watching.

I have not actually had crepes here yet. I have only been for dinner, but assume it is a decent casual breakfast spot too.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Stopped by a while back (ok fine it was like three months ago) and unfortunately it was the weekend of Outside Lands, so super long lines. 

Got a Cole Valley crepe which was tasty. Service was relatively fast once you've ordered. Overall it's slightly better than average in terms of SF brunch spots so it's more like a 3.5 stars, but it's a neighborhood spot so 4 stars it is.
author: Rowena L.

description:
We came in here because the wait at Zazie was redonkulous.

JJ and I shared a Meditteranean crepe and Banana/Nutella crepe. The savory crepe was okay - I've had better - and they don't have Tapatio (only Tabasco, which I loathe), so maybe it was because I couldn't spice it up that I felt it was a little bland. The taters were good and the mixed green salad was fresh. 

The sweet crepe was delish, though you can't go wrong with bananas and Nutella. Mimosas are $5 a piece. Can't complaint about that!
author: Mi M.

description: Been coming here for brunch for a long time. Excellent service, excellent food, comfortable space with lovely light.
author: Scott S.

description: Amazing bloody Mary's! It's a must! Along side with the blue salad... Non the less, amazing place for brunch... especially being an out of towner
author: Adrian R.

description:
I think you have to be a real local local to appreciate this place. It is one of my go to places when I'm just too lazy to cook something or there's no food in the fridge to cook anyway. The menu is simple: breakfast (eggs, pancakes, french toast), soup, salads, crepes (of course), and sandwiches. That's it. I think I've got it committed to memory. Add cheap beer, fresh juices, and decent coffee to that as well.

There is always a game on the big screen tv (lately we've been going there to watch the post-season baseball games that we don't get at home since we're too cheap to pay for cable), and my only complaint about the place is that they don't have wi-fi.
author: Lisa W.

description: First place we went to on our tour of this amazing foodie heaven of a city. What a great start! Awesome crepes. I had the fisherman's wharf. Excellent portions and great potatoes. Nice beer to top it off. Person working seemed pretty put of it but oh well. Nice place!
author: Ashley K.

description:
Caffeine on Cole.

Less than $4 for a smooth and potent triple shot Americano with sugar free vanilla syrup.

Namesake might be the crêpes. Brilliance is the caffeine.
author: Jason B.

description: The food was good the people were nice and very helpful. It was a little pricey but worth it. The restroom was a little dirty but other then that it was cool. I will be back.
author: Armando S.

description:
I did not think I could find a place that I disliked more than The Grove in Hayes Valley (see previous review for reference).  How is it so hard to toast a bagel and pour a cup coffee?  Apparently quite difficult at Crepes on Cole.  Sometimes I need to zoom in, and zoom out, so I settle for this (one of the very few) spot.  But like finding a good dude, I have learned after today, to never settle.  

The servers are consistently rude.  Today, the lady may as well have been comatose when taking my order.  The prices however, are nothing short of inconsistent.  One day it's 12 bones for two bagels and two coffees, another day it's 16 bones for same order.  After said zombie bitch waitress took my order, I found out they were out of the bagels I wanted, so I settled for my second choice, only to get it home and find that it was sesame (totes not my second or even 4th choice), AND it was stale to boot.  It also seems that they may frequent to the grocery outlet to pick out some amazing rotten produce, because the sour limp green pieces of shit on my bagel could not have been cucumbers.

All and all, besides the gnartastic soap bagel from the Grove, this really could have been some of the sickest food-like substance I have ever consumed.  I've been trying to give this place the benefit of the doubt over the past few months (even know I've been let down constantly), but today...today was the last straw.  So next time, I'll just wake up a few minutes earlier, walk a few blocks farther, and settle for nothing less less than what I really like.
author: Cims B.

description: I had a lemon brown sugar crepe. While I love lemon this was way too tart. I wasn't able to have more than a couple of bites before stealing my husbands whipped cream.  He liked his banana chocolate crepe. I would rated mine a two and he a four, so averaging out to give a three on yelp. The service was nice.  I asked for my drink extra hot and it wasn't, but coffee was good and they had free refills.
author: Lizbeth S.

description:
Went here on a sunny Saturday at noon when every brunch destination in the Haight had a line out the door.  We went to the counter and ordered some grub while a friend hovered over an empty table until a server cleaned it off for us.  For a sit down place like this I'd prefer actual table service, but you get what you get in San Francisco.

I ordered the French Toast and it was good.  6 big triangles of cinnamon and egg covered toast served with real maple syrup and a nice assortment of fruit.  The French toast itself was good, but standard fare breakfast material.  The fruit, however, was the reason why people love California.  Awesome, fresh, local produce including bananas, strawberries, and blackberries.  The plate was nicely decorated and probably worth the $10 I spent on it.  Coffee was good, too.  I don't mind getting up to refill my own water and coffee (which is $0.80/refill) but I'd rather pay somebody a few bucks to serve me like in a proper restaurant.  

There's also a really cool cheese/wine/deli shop across the street called Say Cheese.  Go in there and buy some fancy, stinky cheese on your way home.
author: Andrew M.

description: Love this place ! The crepes and the salads are so good. My favorite thing to eat here is the Greek salad with chicken and the pesto chicken crepe!
author: Danielle V.

description:
The banana & coconut pancakes were to die for.

Also the best breakfast potatoes. Period.

Will definitely be retuning soon : ).
author: Christian J.

description: A trip to San Francisco wouldn't be complete without a visit.  Fresh ingredients only used to make some very eclectic dishes. Can't decide what to order, go ahead and build your own. Great local neighborhood.
author: Rich G.

description: This was a last minute place for my best friend and I to eat dinner, Breakfast for dinner which is always a sure bet. The place was spacious, brightly lit, quiet for a Saturday but it was just what we needed to discuss our Amoeba finds or in my case, lack of. The prices are cheap and the portions are huge, however, it lacked flavor punch. The lady at the til gave me a funny look when I made a gluten free enquiry.
author: Shila B.

description: Been here a couple times, and usually get the chicken crepe. For the price I don't believe it measures up but it's still decent. Could also be a little more filling. Cute place in general.
author: Alli R.

description: We returned to Crepes on Cole and loved our lunch! The potatoes were cooked perfectly! It was like 1 pm on a Friday afternoon though, so I'd have to try it on a weekend to confirm they've fixed "the potato problem" :-)
author: Osh J.

description: This is a decent crepe joint. Nothing special, but if you need a spot with plenty of space and variety in the menu, especially for the kiddies, it's a solid.
author: Neema J.

description: Was my first time here. It was very affordable and the food was pretty good. There were 6 of us at the table and we all thought the service was pretty good (and fast). What more do we want? It was also very kid friendly. we had two small kids in our party, one 6 years old and the other a toddler. The two year got pretty restless and was playing everything on the table but the waiter was patient.  The owner was actually on the premises and was managing it well. I would definitely eat here again.
author: Pam A.

description:
Crepes on Cole is a solid three star place in every sense of the phrase. You always know what you are going to get, it's never going to be epic, and that is all good.

COC (ha) is similar to many of the other "breakfasty places with huge chalkboard style menus" establishments a la Crepevine, Squat and Gobble, and so on. I love anywhere that you can get breakfast all day every day, so of course that's what I go for - crepes, omelettes or eggs. It's right off the N Judah stop and across from Doug's Suds so I've come over here before to grab a quick beer while my clothes are in the wash. (Not in the dryer, though - people can steal that sh*t).

The food is solidly okay, nothing amazing but always satisfying. Price point is okay, not impressive. The draft beers went up from 2.50 to 3.50 (BOO!) but they do now accept credit cards, so I guess the two cancel each other out.
author: Courtney A.

description:
A Wednesday around lunch hour was a great time to go...no crowds. I thought the service was very friendly and accommodating...and it was an easy place to dine with a toddler. There were ample high chairs and a clean restroom with a changing table. I was pretty in love with my nutella chocolate crepe with strawberries. Having read the cautionary tales of the place being cash only, my one potential problem was avoided. 

Bottom line: solid and easy, but would not wait in line for an hour because it is no different from most places serving tasty crepes. That is no knock on them, just the reality of the SF dining scene.
author: Kiesha R.

description: Scratch the last review, their pancakes are amazing. I also like the atmosphere, not too cramped, perfect for relaxing for a little while. I think their other dishes are better than the crepes though.
author: Bahar A.

description: Underwhelming. This place is very similar to the Crepevine chain. There's one on Irving and one that I just went to in Palo Alto. I ordered the same menu item here and in Palo Alto (Tuna Sandwich) and the results were very contrary. Everything at the Crepevine in Palo Alto was tastier and better done, including the salad dressing. On my salad at this location, there barely was any dressing to speak of. In Palo Alto, it came with a side of dressing that was ample. The lettuce here at this location was actually going bad. On my sandwich the leaves were turning black on the outside. Not to mention, on the menu it said the sandwich came with sprouts, and there were no sprouts to speak of! The slices of tomato are thin. Also, the amount of food was noticeably less than in Palo Alto. I was full after eating half the sandwich there. Here, I'm still hungry after eating the whole thing. There's less tuna and the one there came with avocado. The positives here are that food is quick. My sandwich was out in less than 5 minutes. The cashier also threw in cheese for free. Fairly affordable. It's not that I wouldn't eat here again, it's just that they could do much better (and so could you in you in your dining choices). Plus, it's just sad to see San Francisco losing so miserably to Palo Alto in simple food.
author: Samuel C.

description:
We were on the search for some tasty eats after some Record Store Day madness so we ended up here. The menu is pretty similar to what they have at Crepevine (except I don't remember sandwiches on Crepevine's menu). I ordered a half Turkey sandwich that came with a full plate of salad, potatoes and even soup. It was a pretty filling meal for the price. The sandwich was a tiny bit over toasted but not something that wouldn't make me go back. My BF ordered a Chicken and Pesto sandwich which looked really good too. His came with a ton of salad and potatoes. Both were about the same price so plan accordingly. If you're looking for something that's pretty quick, I would go here.

Cash only.
author: Amy J.

description: Great service, one man behind the counter serving the whole place, while the cooks cook incredible breakfast, crepes, eggs and bacon. Definitely a relaxing environment not crowded and busy like Zazies and food is prepared in the knick of time.
author: Jeremy Y.

description: This is a decent lunch place. Recently the quality has faltered. Had brunch there on an non busy day. Eggs were lukewarm and just un appetizing. My friend had a pastrami sandwich which had only 3 thin meat slices.  They always have help wanted signs up so I guess help is hard to keep.  Anyway try this place with caution
author: Lamb C.

description: After spending the weekend eating hospital food while visiting a very sick family member I decided to take my grand kids out for something different. First impression was not very welcoming. The employes were not friendly and seemed rather annoyed. After ordering, we heard what was the manager or owner yelling at the employees. Weird. The food we ordered two sandwiches, a crepe and bowl of yogurt, no drinks was 34.00! Although good, not that good. We won't go back.
author: Cindy G.

description: Perfectly cooked medium rare Burger, nice atmosphere,  good draft selection. MUST comeback for mascarpone filled French toast.
author: mark S.

description: This is a local institution. Open reasonably late for the area and has healthy and yummy crepes. I really like the vibe-- it's calming and peaceful. The waitresses are very nice. I always get the Cole Valley crepe.
author: L. Y.

description: I can't believe this place is still in business. If you like crepes, don't go here. BRING BACK THE OTHER CAFE: http://colevalleyalley.com/2011/01/09/the-other-cafe/
author: Amity B.

description:
This evening I was in desperate search of a crepe.  I Yelped Crepes on Cole and learned they they were open until 10:30 pm, so I headed there.  Upon my arrival at 10:20, the lights were off and the doors locked.  VERY disappointing!!!

I am certain that once I actually eat a crepe from here that my review will go up- I am a lover of crepes after all.  But I was VERY bummed that they closed early on this crepe-worthy evening.  :(
author: Nora S.

description: Crepes On Cole was a dinner destination during recent trip up to the city for a catch-up with relatives. It has a casual homey traditional restaurant feel that's complimented with a generally older crowd (this was late-evening mid-week). I had their Hawaiian crepe that was served with sides of fried potato bits and salad greens. The food is decent but I've definitely had more refined offerings at other creparies.
author: Francis L.

description: Asked a local for a recommendation near Haight and Ashbury, lucked out on this gem. Four blocks off Cole and Haight, this cozy cafe diner has a plethora of breakfast and lunch options that are all excellent (verified by a group of four ravaging at each others' plates). The two guys working the counter were more than helpful, but in an impressively un-annoying way. Coffee cups were always full and when we were heading out, to go cups were offered free of charge. And it was GOOD coffee. Coffee bar was equipped with any type of milk or sugar you could ask for. Left stuffed and satisfied.
author: Alyssa H.

description:
So this was my first time here as I usually eat at Zazie down the street but they were closing in 20 minutes and crepes sounded really good.  I walked in and asked if I can sit outside and if I order there or at the counter.  I was told to order at the counter and they would bring my food out.  Sounded great on this beautiful afternoon.  The gentleman I placed my order with was older with grey hair and extremely friendly.  I  was in the mood for a dessert crepe after my lunch and wanted to make sure they'd still be open.  He joked that they didn't close until 10pm so take my time.  I ordered a custom crepe and a coffee.  He gave me my coffee in a mug and since I was sitting outside and I didn't want to have to have my server (as I thought was the case) go back and forth, I asked to have it put in a large to go cup.  I paid my bill with a tip for what I assumed would be  for my server.

I nearly finished my coffee when my food came out.  The woman who brought my food was in her mid 30's and put my plate in front of me and took my number.  She didn't bring or offer hot sauce, ketchup,salt or pepper but it wasn't a big deal.  I asked if I could get a refill on my coffee and she took my cup and brought it back to my table.  There was no cream so I asked if I can have some cream for it.  This is where the experience went bad, very bad.  She told me that they don't take care of coffee refills and that I can go get the cream myself.  I thought she was kidding but when I asked her why I had tipped when I paid the bill at the beginning of my order she had no answer.  I told her I just needed some cream for my coffee and she literally walked away from me completely ignoring my request and told me to get it myself.  A few minutes later the nice older man came out with a small pitcher of cream which I thanked him for.  

My crepe was great, the coffee was good but the attitude of the other woman who was working the counter and tables was beyond terrible.  What a turn off.  It wasn't even the fact that she didn't bring cream, it was her attitude as she told me to get it myself.  She had dirty blonde hair and was dressed a bit like Holly Hobby on 3/13 when I dined.  I'm in the restaurant/hospitality business and she's the type that will ruin a perfectly good experience/restaurant with a sour apple attitude.  I liked the place for food, however she doesn't belong around people.  Possibly a spot in the kitchen or as a dishwasher would be more fitting for her attitude.  Would love to try again, but not if she's here.

Kind of sad someone can be so bitter and hurt a business.  4 stars for food,1 star for service.  At least she brought me my lunch!
author: Brian S.

description: I love this place. The food was amazing and the service was amazing. The cannelloni crepe was on point. I will be back for sure. :)
author: Liz E.

description: Everything I've had here is very mediocre. Turkey sandwich tastes like low quality cold cut and tons of mayo - just a basic sandwich I could make at home in 30 seconds. The scramble was watery and lacking flavor. The salads are large but heavily overdressed and the meat additions don't taste fresh.
author: Isaac T.

description: Great food...good customer service. If I lived in San Francisco, I would visit this place regularly.
author: Andrea T.

description: After eating here many, many times, I suppose I should finally leave a review. This is a go-to place for weekend brunch for us. Good crepes, pancakes, etc., without the crazy wait of Zazie. It's also very kid friendly, which is a big plus for us.
author: Pat M.

description:
I'm not from California so I had NO idea that San Francisco was so crepe crazy! 

Had lunch here and thank goodness I had cash I would've looked like a a fool otherwise begging for food. The crepes are huugggeeee and it comes with potatoes and a salad all for under $8. Woo hoo! I've tried the Cole Valley and Bon Jour and both were delicious and flavorful. The only thing that confused me was that the actual crepe was really thick. When I visited France, the crepes both sweet and savory there were much, much thinner. But it doesn't matter, b/c this thicker crepe was hearty and could hold everything together.

Can't wait to visit someday. Until then, I'll just have to make due with my dreams.
author: Tina P.

description: I had a creepe there with goat cheese and it was fine for a brunch. The waitress was nice and I didn't have to that much for the food. I would recommend coming here instead of Zazie.
author: Gergely S.

description:
Went here for brunch since the wait for Zazie was unbearable. Food was good - nothing to write home about, but better than some places I've had in SF. I got one of the benedicts and was pleased with the portions for the price. The environment was chill and the service was friendly.

Not a place where I'll become a regular, but I'm not opposed to going back either.
author: Sara D.

description: Very nice little place in a beautiful neighborhood. I actually had the Salmon Benedict, which was great, and the girl I was with had the pancakes. They were seriously twice as thick as normal pancakes, and there were two of them. All in all, it was a very good meal.
author: Zach H.

description:
We always pass this place when we're on the N-Judah and decided to try it. We walked in..and automatically I though, Crepevine. Not like that's a bad thing, but it's almost exactly like Crepevine. Writing on blackboards, how it's set up. Self order, get a number and they bring you your food. 

We ordered the New Mexico Scramble and French Toast, per suggestions on Yelp and they were really good. I enjoyed the scramble with its avocado (I'm loving it right now) and the french toast was well-made and lots of fruit on it (strawberries, bananas, and blackberries). I enjoyed both dishes. 

There were all these seats available at around 10am for brunch. It was a decent place to try, and now I can mentally note that I've eaten there every time I pass it.
author: Nina Y.

description:
One word... Pancakes.
The servers and friendly, you get your meal in a moderate amount of minutes, and the food is great!
author: Katrina W.

description: As far as pancakes go, they have the best in the City, hands down!!!  My favorite is the banana coconut, omg heavenly!!  This is the perfect spot to grab a late breakfast or lunch, while people watching or watching sports on the new flat screen.  It's also a great place to come around 7ish and study, since its pretty mellow around then.  Super chill vibe and cool mix of people.  This is the perfect neighborhood cafe.  I'm loving the new changes made to the menu and decor!!!
author: Molly M.

description: We have been a couple times now, mixed experienced. The staff here are very nice. Lots of choices, busy place but food came quickly. Will try again :) good home fries coffee and salad was yum. Ok, bagels! Not too many options for those allergic to milk and eggs like me but lots of option to create a veggie something without cheese perhaps :) On my second trip back I had the salmon bagel and subbed avo for cream cheese, it was very satisfying.  I wish they sold the buckwheat style crepe batter which is a lot healthier with less eggs.  More vegan option in general would be nice.  This is a great place for brunch before heading over to UCSF for some serious studying.
author: Coco J.

description:
This used to be one of my favorite cheap eats in SF when I was a college student.  Cheap because one meal there and I'd be good for a day or two.  

The owner is really warm and friendly, when slow he often came by and chatted with me, offering free fresh squeezed orange juice or tea.  

I returned last weekend as I often do when I visit the city, there are no Crepe places where I live now so I need my fix of savory crepes.  I feel like it's not as good as I remembered.  The crepes are a little thicker and slightly more doughy or soggy.  Still satisfying, but not fantastic.  The rosemary potatoes and the salad are nice sides to round out the meal.  Hot tea comes in a little pot so you get 3 cups of tea for the price of 1, and it's loose tea. yay!  

I always go for savory over sweet but my friend ordered the french toast because he had never had a savory crepe and said they didn't sound appetizing (he later freaked out when he tried a bite, said "daaaammmnn that's gooooood!" haha).  His french toast was made from Challah and came topped with fresh sliced strawberries, bananas, blackberries, and maple syrup and butter, it was beautiful.  I only managed to steal a banana but those that sampled the french toast declared it the best ever.
author: Sj C.

description: This was my second visit. Both times have been great! This time I sat outside with friends and enjoyed mimosas and the BEST french toast. Crepes on Cole isn't local for me but IMO worth the drive.
author: Kinner J.

description: Yumo. Great place for groups, families. Lots of options for breakfast. Great eggs and my friends crepes were delicious.
author: Kristin M.

description:
My brother lives in Cole Valley, so we trusted him to recommend a decent place for lunch that would be kid friendly. We had been playing at the playground at Golden Gate Park when it started raining, so we decided it was time to get some lunch. This was about a brisk one mile walk from the park. When we arrived at about 1pm every table was full. It is a seat yourself kind of place, so we worried for a few minutes about finding someplace that would accomodate our party of six with two kids, one needing a high chair. 

Crepes on Cole looks like your typical crepe place right down to the very similar chalk board menus on the wall. I was a little worried because I haven't always had the best luck with places like that in terms of food and my first impression of the service was less than stellar. My husband decided to start ordering at the counter without asking if I was ready and my mom and brother were hanging back looking for a table. The guy who was taking orders was very impatient and brusque when I took a second to name what I wanted. I turned to try and wave my mother over to place her order and he was already giving us our total. There was no one else behind us in line, so I thought that was fairly ridiculous. When my mom had to go up and place her order afterwards, he was similarly rude to her when she inquired if they had french fries. 

My brother managed to snag a table while we were ordering and they did have high chairs, so my youngest son had a decent place to sit. After we were seated everything took a turn for the better. The waitresses who dropped off the food were all very friendly and efficient and our food was much better than I have experienced in crepe places in the past. My crepe was large and filled with yummy chicken, pesto, cheese and tomatoes. I loved that it came with both salad and potatoes and I was not forced to just choose one. My boys' grilled cheese sandwiches also came with potatoes and fruit. My mom got a huge salad that looked abundant and very fresh with nice slices of apples, chunks of blue cheese and candied walnuts on top. She also got a cup of soup that was more like a bowl, with lots of chunky veggies. My husband got some delicious looking french toast and a side of scrambled eggs. My brother's omelette looked fantastic as well and came with more toast than he could finish. I would have loved to have also tried one of the sweet crepes with a side of ice cream, but unfortunately we were all too stuffed, but they looked fantastic from what I saw at neighboring tables.
author: Lisa H.

description:
I've been here 5-6 times, and normally this place would get 3-4 stars from me. Today the service was frustratingly bad enough to get an angry review from me.

I came in with my girlfriend and mother for brunch, and there was a bit of line, but it was moving fast enough and there were plenty of tables.

I waited in line, got to the front, and ordered from an older guy with a mustache (maybe the owner?). It was fine until the server next to him grabbed my table number so quickly I wasn't sure what was going on, and used it for someone else's order. Before I left the counter I checked on this and the guy got visibly frustrated with me like I was playing some kind of trick on him. I told him I didn't go anywhere and I thought the other person grabbed my number. Not really a huge deal but seriously man... check with your staff before you vent on people. I feel like he gave me weird look when I only put a 10% tip on my check, but that could have just been my impression. If you want more, seriously chill out and show some patience with people.

While waiting for the food I saw him repeat this kind of behavior with everyone else in line and figured it was worth mentioning. 

So we waited. And waited. I saw several tables with much larger parties than mine who arrived later get all their food. By the time 40 minutes went by I checked with a blonde server about my order and she said she would go back to the kitchen. Cool, there was hope now.

She came back out and visited several other tables without saying a word. I gave her another 5-10 minutes before I went up to her and asked about the order. "YES! I'll bring it to you when it's ready!!" she impatiently replied. Seriously? I'm being unreasonable here?

It only takes 10 seconds to let someone know what's going on. It makes them feel better when they've waited a long time and they're hungry. I've worked in a restaurant and I can tell when something goes back as a re-fire because someone forgot the ticket. Customers can be really understanding. But this staff apparently can't even spare a few seconds of politeness. When someone's hungry, it's really the wrong time to be impatient or rude. Especially if you want repeat business.

The food came out soon after I checked on it and 2 out of 3 of our orders were good. The french toast was great. My girlfriend thought her Bonjour crepe was pretty tasteless but my mom liked the blueberry pancakes.

I'm really mixed if I'll come back here again. I like the food and usually the service has been adequate but not notable, but I don't feel like being frustrated when all I want to do is pay someone for breakfast. There's a place right across the street with great reviews.
author: Micah S.

description: We were in the area and decided to stop in for a quick dinner. I ordered the grilled chicken sandwich (chicken was not dry at all) and the BF ordered the cole valley crepe. Both came with a side of potatoes and salad. Quick and delicious! We were in and out in about 25 minutes!
author: M W.

description:
Came here starving after work one day and ordered the mediterranean crepe. Had a Kitchen Nightmares moment where I felt like Chef Ramsay on one of his rants when he first tries the food at the nightmare restaurant. The crepe was soggy and the ingredients (cheddar cheese in a mediterranean crepe??) just did not compliment each other.  The potatoes were hard and crusty, tasted like they were made 3 days ago. I took two bites and felt like I was going to be sick. 

If you go there, order a 2.50 pint and eat somewhere else.
author: Amanda D.

description: On a weekend trip and came here as we were walking by. The service was great! They provided great recommendations and were very patient with our large group. As we ate, we decided we would come back the next day for more.
author: Daniel C.

description:
So apparently Cole Valley is littered with rude staff who hate their jobs and hate their customers, this place is not one of them. The people here are really nice and treat you like a valuable customer, but there is one huge, gigantic problem...the food absolutely sucks! 

Today I ordered the "Bon Jour" a soggy crepe with goat cheese and sausage...I'm sorry I can't describe this anymore I might puke. I really want this place to not suck, so much so that I keep coming here hoping that I just ordered the wrong thing and that the next thing I order will be good...wishful thinking. The atmosphere is really nice here with outdoor seating. The beers are super cheap $2.50 a pint, you really can't beat that. 

So I suggest coming to this Crepe spot to order a beer, but stay as far from the crepes as you can! Seriously my stomach has been trying to commit suicide all night, it is traumatized, still gurgling the mushy goop they so inaccurately call crepes.
author: nathan r.

description:
When I lived in SF this was totally my brunch to go spot. It's never too crowded where you are outside waiting for hours. My absolute favorite part of the restaurant was the little owner. He's a loud little man but once you are a regular and he knows you he treats you like family.

Sadly, I've never had a crepe. I was keen on the eggs benedict and the pancakes. Yums to both of those. The rest of the menu is a little generic. I always found it to be more homey than other places like the Stop and Gobble. More space and less crowds.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Gr8 selection

I had the NY Benny. Very good and very fresh. VERY fresh OJ and carrot juices. Definitely a place I'll come back to.
author: Richard S.

description: Affordable good food and service. I highly recommend it for a brunch. The crepes are a must! Zazie has a crazy wait time and I am glad we came here instead.
author: Naresh T.

description:
I had the pleasure of trying Crepes on Cole a little shy of a month ago while visiting San Francisco for the first time. A friend had another breakfast plan, but as I feel might be common in a place like Cole Valley, we had to go with our backup. Parts of my culinary experience were great, others were not my favorite. (My mom always taught me you never say you don't like what others are serving, you just say it's not your favorite.)

Plus: Good selection of savory and sweet crepes. Sometimes places specialize in one or the other, and it's nice to have lots of choices.

Minus: Too much! Overwhelmed! Decision-making fatigue induced! I appreciate a desire to offer options, but similar to Filter in Chicago (I did review them, right?), I just couldn't choose. 

Plus: The potatoes. Delicioso! Well seasoned and crispy while still tender inside. Truly great.

Minus: The crepe. Good fresh ingredients, but kind of a weird combo of flavors (I got the Cole Valley--maybe that's saying something!).

Plus: Quick turnaround after ordering. Much faster than waiter service.

Minus: Potential for hazardously long lines snaking among tables and moving very slowly and eyeing my breakfast jealously.

Plus: Friendly staff! Absolutely everyone was enjoyable to interact with. 

So, kind of a balance. I'm not sure I'd go back again if I go back again to San Fran, only because there are so many options. But, it'll do if you need a backup!
author: Valerie S.

description:
Carrot juice and Raspberry Blintz is the best!
Full house over the weekends for brunch.
author: Irin K.

description:
Love the place!!!! 

My wife and come here very often for coffee and the service is always great. 

Their crepes are really good. Try the special.
author: niaz a.

description:
I would recommend.  Prices were moderate for all the food they gave you.  All dishes come with a side of roasted potatoes seasoned with rosemary salt and pepper, and a side salad with their house vinaigrette.

Their signature burger with the avocados is AMAZING! I have tried other dishes, but I must say I am hooked on this burger, the portion with the sides is EXTREMELY filling.

I believe the last time I passed by they had all their tap beers at $2.75 or $3.00, which is an unbelievable bargain when you are ordering a pint of Lagunitas IPA for just $3 bucks.

One of my favorite places to grab a bite in the city since when I moved here.

I am a regular patron, coming in at least 3-4 times a month.  It isn't as close to me as I would like :(
author: Tom L.

description: Love their sweet and savory crepes, friendly atmosphere and chill staff. I've been here many times and would def. be back .
author: C A.

description:
They have 2.50 draft beers. So 'Yay! I'm a fan.' describes my feeling perfectly. Oh and it isn't crappy bud light, they had lagunitas IPA, blue moon, stella, sierra nevada, and another 2. 

It was super packed when we got there, but we found a spot to sit outside. It was really relaxing and since I live up the road I will be back.
author: Brandon R.

description:
It's kinda like Crepevine and Squat and Gobble...Menu is similar, and once you order they give you a # and you sit where ever you want. I came across this place when a friend of mine moved in the area. The ppl are friendly here, it does get a little packed and I think they only take cash. 
They have a mozzarella, tomato sandwich that is really good, and their potatoes are seasoned just right! This place if in the area is a must! Parking can be kinda hard though.
author: Irma R.

description:
Good:
$2.50 beers on tap, ALL DAY EVERYDAY.
pretty good crepes and such, similar to crepevine or squat n gobble.

Bad: 
all their items on the menu that says it has sprouts, well...doesn't. when sprouts were recalled months ago, they just never brought it back and it's still on their menu

Service is nice, in a convenient location, and overall not bad. Just not anything extra special.
author: Emy s.

description:
On a Sat. morning after learning that it would take an hour to get seated at Zazzies we decided to walk down to Crepes On Cole. The owner was very attentive and arranged for 8 of us to be seated. 

Good menu for breakfast. I made my own omelet with: apple sausages, sun dried tomato pesto, & cheese. It was good! (4 stars). Also ordered the blueberry pancakes which were good, not too sweet. The coffee was okay, and I wish they had free refills. 

Ambiance was nice, pretty bright and spacious. Very cafe looking. (3 stars). 
Service was fast and good (4 stars). 
Parking in Cole Valley is always tough but not impossible. 
Crepes on Cole accepts CASH ONLY.
author: Brendan J.

description: I'm only giving 3 stars for the food, because it's always (by always I mean since the 12+ years I've gone there). The guys that own it are SO SO nice, very friendly and always give me a great big smile - gotta give 5 stars for service. I will say, they should buy new teapots AND they should maintain a cleaner general area (the tables and the counters NEVER feel very clean).
author: C. L.

description:
A neighborhood favorite and often overlooked gem. The food is quite good and the a great value--the portions are generous! While the menu is expansive and maybe a bit overwhelming at first, stick with the crepes. (Although admittedly my favorite is the all-day $2.95 draft beer.) 

The quiet atmosphere makes it a fantastic place to pop in and have a bite while people watching the busy Carl & Cole street intersection. They also have a large screen TV for those oh-so-important game nights.
author: Tony O.

description: This place is two blocks from where I stay in San Fran just a few blocks from Haight, so I had numerous opportunities to try it out It had lots of good Crepe choices and I tried a few. They also have some great non crepe breakfast options.The Pesto Chicken (savory) was a good choice, as well as any of the savory Crepes actually filled with something and come with a side of potatoes. The Apple Crepe was good with apple cinnamon cheddar and sour cream, same with the Cole Valley Crepe. However I was disappointed with the Brown Sugar desert crepe (brown sugar, butter, lemon) and I thought it would come with ice cream but maybe it didn't because I got it to go - so that one tasted delicious but was a little disappointing seeing a single flat crepe with no filling or side for $7.
author: Kevin M.

description: It breaks my heart to give such a low rating, because--until the last visit--- Crepes on Cole was one of my SF faves for breakfast.  This past weekend I convinced a friend to drive across the city just because the place really has a good vibe, great proportions, excellent breakfast menu.  Well, we split a crepe and I watched as she pulled a chunk of wood out of her food.  It had obviously been cooked with the mixture.  I'm not talking about a sliver of wood or something.  This was an actually CHUNK of wood.  When she showed it to the manager (?), he was very apologetic but said that the same thing had happened before.  WTF?  Anyway, he gave my friend a $10 off coupon and apologized again.  However, I don't think she'll be going back any time soon... or EVER.  As for me, I'm not so sure......
author: Morgan G.

description:
Very poor service. The people here are just rude and don't want to be bothered by customers. The food was blah. The prices were too high for blah food. There were tables that need dishes picked up and cleaned and no one was cleaning anything. They were hanging out behind the counter talking instead. 

Go half a block to Zazie and have a great meal with some always friendly people.
author: Shelly T.

description: Imagine a nice scoop of lemon ricotta, wrapped in a crepe and drizzled with honey. Not bad, right? Now imagine another cup of ricotta and a mound of sour cream. Slather all of that with cold applesauce and serve it up 30 minutes later. A little worse. Imagine asking for a glass of water, receiving only a brief nod and then figuring out after you're done eating that you're supposed to get it yourself. Which wouldn't have been a problem if only someone had mentioned it to you. Frrrrpp.
author: Anne B.

description: Just had the bleu Salad with Chicken.  The chicken was soooooo delicioous!!! And the salad was dressed perfectly!  Best Salad I have had in a long time!  Yummy!
author: Marqus B.

description:
I used to come by here on the N-Judah every day and see the sign about $2.50 beers and want to drop in. Finally after many months of thinking about coming in, I had the opportunity to drop by with a friend who lives in the neighborhood.

There is a good selection of micro-brews on tap and they are $2.50. WIN. they also have mimosas and wine, but that is more expensive. I can't say anything about the food, since I am a lush but from what I saw it looked fine.

There is an $8 minimum for cards so if you just go for drinks be sure to bring some cash.
author: Peter V.

description:
5 stars for Crepes on Cole because Josh Harnett filmed 40 Days and 40 Nights here. :) :)

oh, and the crepes are really good. WAY better than crepevine.
author: Carol Y.

description:
Crepes on Cole is pretty good, but for San Francisco I can't say it "stands out" to much, other than the awesome beer special, $2.50/ping.

It's a solid alternative to a brunch place up the street that gets super crowded, so if there's a long wait, saunter on down.  CoC can get a little crowded but I've never had to wait for a table, even during Saturday/Sunday brunch time.  There's also outdoor seating assuming its warm enough and not too windy!

I've had four or five different crepes there, and my favorite is probably the Hawaiian, a solid ham crepe with good sweetness.  The curry crepe is also pretty interesting and tasty if you are in for yellow/brown curry flavors.  Pesto/Pesto Chicken is also solid if a little weird to the tastebuds.

The home potatoes are also really good!

The beer special is great - makes this a solid place to hang and have a brew if you're not up for loud music but are down for brews and solid conversation.  Later in the night there's a solid amount of seating and you can rearrange the tables.  They're also open pretty late!
author: Francis U.

description:
My favorite spot for Saturday morning breakfast and planing for the weekend guerrilla.
I always have the same thing (yes, I eat like an old lady), the awesome French toast made with challah bread, whipped vanilla butter, season berries, apple and cantilope topped with traditional styled maple syrup.
The owner is very amicable, the beer cheap and it is the perfect corner to just watch busy people walk by from the top of my indolence.
author: Bea L.

description:
The crepe I had (self-created with chicken breast, eggplant, mushrooms, spinach, and marinara sauce) was a little greasy and rather bland.  Crepevine (to which this place draws inevitable comparison, what with its chalkboard menu and all...) makes a better crepe.

That said, I couldn't help but admire the French toast and pancake selections on the table next to mine, so I may have to return soon to try one of those...
author: Zain K.

description: Large selection and good prices. Dessert crepes were very good, had to stop myself from ordering more since I had already had a savory crepe as well.
author: Brad M.

description: This place is great. Great service and fresh and delicious food. The only thing this place needs is a little bit more help.  It took a little long for the food to come out but it was worth the wait. A MUST FOR BREAKFAST in San Francisco!
author: Victoria L.

description:
I highly recommend this place. We went there for breakfast on our last day in San Francisco, and it was excellent. 

The place itself has a classic cafe look, huge windows overlooking Cole and Carl streets. Menu options on a chalkboard as well as on menus at each table. You are free to seat yourself and watch the parade of passersby or the large screen television, which was tuned to the Olympics. 

The food was very good We had savory crepes, which are huge, and come with potatoes and dressed greens. The coffee and tea options cover all the bases, and it is all high quality. 

What really makes the place stand out, though, was the friendly service. The cashier also waited on all the tables, and he did it swiftly and with style. After joking with us, he spent some time with another table of visitors who clearly did not know their way around San Francisco. He gave them tips on what to see and how to get around on the Muni.
author: Michael G.

description:
Great food! I recommend the pesto crepe... it is to die for.
The beer is only $2.50 for draft! Biggest selling point for this restaurant since there are a million other creperies around.
The service is either great (when the owner is there) or terrible (when it's just the handful of girls). I still visit it at least once a week.
author: Cory S.

description:
After a challenging 6 mile run I was ready for a big breakfast.  And a crepe breakfast? Oh my oh my...

I like this place.  Busy, colorful menu blackboard and not discriminating.  Considering I was in my running clothes when everybody else were dressed up for brunch.  And nobody really caring for that bum in the corner.  

First of all my hot chocolate was over the top.  With a thick bark of cinnamon and whip cream, I didn't mind it wasn't as hot as I wanted it to be.

I got the pesto crepe, with tomatoes, feta cheese, olives, mushrooms and chicken, sides of salad and fried potatoes.  It was really good with a balanced saltiness.  I had my friend try a piece and he enjoyed it as much as I did.  He was also contended with his egg benedict plate.  

We finished everything off with a glass of mimosa.  Now, this is really a good Sunday morning :)

Our bill ended up to be $18 per person.  Good service in a nice neighborhood, this place is worth checking out.
author: Pam S.

description:
Great neighborhood spot to chill by yourself and yes I have done that before :o)

Don't judge!!

The owner (?) is super friendly and so is the rest of the staff.  Their namesake crepes...? So so, but then again I've only had their dessert crepes. Perhaps I'll have to try the savory crepes before I put a final verdict on it, but the rest of the menu is pretty good. That along with the service and value makes it a place worth checking out!
author: Jammir G.

description:
Stopped by here at 8pm on a Wednesday night.  I was a bit of a wreak after working out, but no one made me feel like I looked.

Chalk menus, cute-cheesy music, lots of macbooks.  I could be describing  any of the dozens of coffee, sandwich, or crepe spots around the city, which is exactly why this place gets three stars:  It's about average.

The place is spacious, I'd feel comfortable coming here to spread out and study or work.  What I wouldn't come here for is the food.  I got a curry chicken crepe, which I was super-excited about.  What I got was merely average. Well-seasoned but overcooked chicken, and a side of wimpy salad and decent potatoes.  For about $10.00.  Next time I'll just go to one of the less popular bars to spend my dinner-time.
author: Bill H.

description: We walked 2 miles this morning to eat breakfast at Zazie, which we had heard was excellent.  Once there, we found a huge crowd waiting on the sidewalk to get in.  Since we didn't have time to wait, walk the 2 miles back to the car and drive to San Jose in time for work, we instead walked 1/2 a block to this cute little crepe place we had passed along the way. It was an excellent decision!  The food was DELICIOUS! No wait and terrific food, gotta love that!  The menu has a large variety of dishes as well as crepes.  I had the Greek crepe, Bob the Half Moon Bay scramble (loaded with salmon) and Tarah had the banana, coconut pancakes. We were all very satisfied.  I would have given it 5 stars except for one small detail . . . . I asked for no onion and Tarah for no butter, but we both ended up with it anyway. I will definitely go there again and I suggest you try it too!
author: Lena V.

description:
Pretty much the same as the million other crepe places around in terms of menu items, price, and execution.  This was less crowded on a weekday afternoon than the Crepevine on Irving usually is, which is a plus when you want to find a seat.  All our crepes and sandwiches were cooked perfectly to our liking, so no complaints here.  

The one thing I did notice is that of the various crepe places I've been to thus far, the staff here was the friendliest by far.  It's always nice to get good comfort food from nice people.  For that reason I'd come back.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
My friend took me to a different crepe/omelet place the last time I was in San Francisco, so I asked her if we could go there again. She suggested this place, which I found to be OK, but I just wasn't as satisfied as I had been with the other one. This surprised me considering how many people were packed into the place.
The staff was friendly. My fresh squeezed orange juice was so great that I ended up getting two large glasses, but the food was just slightly above average. Their potatoes had some rosemary, but it wasn't flavorful and strong. My omelet was above average only because the ham and cheese seems to be more natural than the water-enhanced crap from Perkins. We finished off with the Nutella-banana crepe. It was decent, but I think they used the Nutella syrup instead of the creme.

This place was pricey and served way too much food than a single human being should eat. I wouldn't be opposed to eating here again, but if I had the choice I would go to Squat & Gobble.

Be prepared; they are CASH ONLY!
author: Ericka A.

description:
I used to love this place, would go all the time, every weekend for the last few years.
Until the owner kicked me out in a table banging rant, because I dare ask where my food was after waiting 20 minutes and multiple people getting their food first who had ordered after me. 

If you run a food business - don't yell at paying customers and own up to delays in your kitchen.  

Won't be going back , the food is decent diner food and the staff is really nice -  the owner is just a rude jerk.
author: Charlie D.

description: A really big selection of crepes and other yummies.  I had the chicken pesto crepe.  The crepes come with potatoes and salad - very big portion.  We also had the basic crepe with cheese and ham.  Definitely a great stop for quick high quality meal.
author: Lucy S.

description:
So I didn't actually have any crepes (but their menu has a LOT of other items).  I ordered an egg sandwich with bacon on a bagel and a caesar salad. The "sandwich" came as a toasted bagel with butter on the side, and a plate of scrambled eggs and bacon.  That's cool, I don't mind making my own... but then why call it a sandwich?

The caesar was a huge bowl of chopped iceberg lettuce and kind of dried out parmesan.   It wasn't awful, but it wasnt great either and I'm all about sane portions.  The whole super-size it thing I just don't get, and this was enough salad for three hungry people.

I also ordered an orange/carrot juice.  

For all of this, it cost $18 and change.  Just seemed a little steep when I had to make my own sandwich.

Other than that, the location is good, there are tons of tables, and it's not too "scene-y" which I like.
author: Jessie S.

description:
So it's 9PM and I still haven't eaten and when the word "CREPES" fell in my line of vision there was no stopping me.  Cause when I'm hungry and I see crepes for sale, you'll need an army to hold me back. 

It took me a minute or two to realize there wasn't any waiter service and then I spotted the menu located above the register and was overwhelmed by the variety of dishes. Aside from crepes, they sell bagels, omelets and..well..a whole lot of other things I didn't have the patience to read.

The crepes were OKAY. Not the best I've ever had, nor the worst.

And it's not just the dish I chose, cause I ordered 4 different dishes. The Florentine, Chicken Pesto, Raspberry blintz and the Strawberry and Banana Chocolate...oh yeah, make that 5, I also had a smoked salmon bagel. As simple as that sounds, it was the best of the lot. MMMMMM.

If I lived in the area, I'd probably frequent this place often because the prices are reasonable (cheap), the atmosphere was interesting and I didn't get food poisoning.
author: Meri P.

description: Not sure how good is their lunch menu but their breakfast was waste of $42. We order two omelets with bacon and salmon, one blueberry pancake and coffee. Home fried was the worst that I've ever had. Feta cheese in my omelet tasted like it was hanging outside of refrigerator for couple of days and yes, they are not using real eggs for the omelets. I am giving them 2 stars only for the pancake that you can't really go wrong with it. $15 omelets that I left in my plate was real waste of money and time.
author: Olena T.

description: It's fine, I don't particularly like savory crepes so I stick with the sweet ones.  I got the ricotta one which turned out to be not that great, I have made better crepes for myself at home.
author: Madeline W.

description:
I've been here before and it's ok. I went to go to Zazie but it was packed on a Thursday morning. 

-The owner (man behind the counter) is very nice and jolly. 
-The place had breathing room, soft music and a muted TV.
-The coffee was fresh with courteous and free refills.
-The meal was bland and the potatoes weren't thoroughly cooked.
-Too expensive for mediocrity.
-There weren't any paper towels in the restroom. The owner was always incredibly behind and busy. I finally told him and one of the boys (he was probably 16) went in the restroom, locked the door, put in the towels, used the toilet and didn't flush.
author: Dianne N.

description: One word: Crepevine! I've never been here but I feel like it's exactly the same just a different name. It has the same atmosphere and appearance. The food was decent but nothing special. I was a little disappointed in their Mexican hot chocolate. I would have thought it would have had a kick to it put it was just hot chocolate with cinnamon in it. It wasn't bad but just was expecting something more to it. It wasn't that packed. Tons of tables. The service was good to us but people around us kept on complaining about their meals. I felt bad for one of the waitresses because she kept getting nagged at. I can see myself going there again though.
author: Jessica D.

description:
I really want to like this place. It's such a nice environment, people are nice and it's the type of place where you'll find cute dogs waiting patiently outside.  But the food is pretty blah. The crepes are not particularly flavorful or crisp. They're much too cheesy for my taste, but with not particularly good cheese. The side of potatoes, while generous, is a little on the cold and hard side, though my timing may just be off. 

Cheese blinzes are tasty!  But when are they not!?
author: Teresa Z.

description: Your typical crepe restaurant that is found all over the city of San Francisco. Going on a weekend day always expect a little bit of a wait. Prices are pretty reasonable and comparable to the other crepe restaurants around the City. Overall a good customer service experience with prompt and courteous service.
author: Gabriel C.

description:
Cute spot. Came in with some friends for a quick bite a week or so ago. The service behind the counter was confusing, but very helpful and accommodating to our 'picky eater' in the group. 
The prices were OK. Around $10 a person for a little lunch. The space needed to be picked up and cleaned a little. But I liked the vibe and will soon be moving down the street - I'll be back for sure. 
Food was made to order - we had a veggie crepe that was pretty much "off" menu and I had a pesto chicken sandwich - really good. I didn't want to share. The salad that came with was also a good size and super crisp and yummy.
author: Jena D.

description:
I like this place as a venue to meet people/groups. The food is underwhelming but it's mitigated by the micro-brews on tap. The ambiance is pleasant; similar to a coffee house vibe. 

Accessible by public transportation since street parking is tight.
author: vinh t.

description: Veg crepes and fresh carrot juice
author: Amool G.

description: I wasn't crazy about the meal we had here today. We have a friend visiting and wanted to give them a taste of the SF brunch scene, and I'm not happy we went here. The guy taking the order was kind of gruff, not exactly the friendliest customer service. I got the buttermilk pancakes, but they tasted undercooked. Doughy and tasteless, it was probably bisquick or something. The others with me liked their meals, maybe I shouldn't order the pancakes next time?
author: John T.

description: The portions are huge!! You can always get a table! The food comes out lightening fast. These are all things i desperately need after a long night of partying, I want my food now!! The owner is so sweet and always there. The Santa Fe Crepe is sooo good. So  is the ham and cheese and I always add egg!!! I love this spot (and I can get there in about 5 minutes so that helps too!)
author: Elizabeth J.

description:
Long story short, food was great, service was mediocre, and prices were high.

Unnecessarily long reminiscing story: Back in college I had a housemate with a penchant for making embarrassing requests that would mostly guarantee getting your food spat in. We'd be at greasy spoon restaurants and without fail he'd ask questions like, "Are the pancakes whole wheat?" "Is the orange juice fresh squeezed?" "Do you use goat cheese in your omelets?" etc. And with every disappointing "no," he would sigh, bobble his head, and deliberate over the menu as if he'd been severely inconvenienced and confounded by the obvious answer. He was so oblivious, it was hilarious; the only thing keeping us from crying laughing at him were the crushed spirits of our waitstaff... We tipped extra when we brought him along.

Back to the now, at Crepes On Cole, I took one look at their menu and ordered all the ridiculous things I ever heard him ask for, just because I could. This place had every snooty little thing I could imagine. Goat cheese and salmon omelets, fresh squeezed orange juice, banana coconut pancakes, thick fresh sliced bacon, organic everything, you name it. I ordered it all. That breakfast was downright triumphant! ...but I had to wonder how my housemate would've found a way to be disappointed in their menu, "Uuuh, this is my first time in California, do you guys make -- CONDOR egg omelets? ...No? ...then I'll need a minute." **siiiiigh and bobble**

Oh the good ol' days.
author: James Y.

description: This place is great when you order and have to substitute things. They are very accommodating, and the food is always great. I would definitely recommend this place to others.
author: Anna G.

description:
Busy, especially on that lazy Sunday morning where you want to lounge around and just eat with friends---I definitely recommend getting there earlier than 10:00am!

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
Man. Memories. So many memories. I've been going to Crepes on Cole since high school and over the years I've been going, nothing's really changed. And I hope nothing ever does. It's simply my go to whenever I'm in this area. It has yet to disappoint me. This place is such a cool place to chill, with or without company. Every time I go it's always with a friend or two, and we'd sit around (usually at a table by the window), talk about life, people watch, and stare back at people staring back at us on the passing N trains and 43 buses. 

This is also a really cool place to unwind in after walking up and down the Haight all day long. That's usually how my day goes when I visit this neighborhood. Haight street shopping then resting my bones and feeding my appetite at Crepes on Cole. Usually it's a basic crepe with the side of salad and potatoes and a hot chocolate. .... and then we'd sit there hours after the last drop of beverage has long gone and all that's left on our plates is light grease from the potatoes. mmm....the potatoes. .... and there we'd be. just chillin... watching each 43 Masonic pass us on the left, wondering when we'd finally step outside and catch one for ourselves. Yet we sit and sit and sit... because Crepes on Cole is too good to us. Every single time.
author: MB M.

description:
So looking at the menu, which is essentially a blackboard, I could hardly contain my excitement. I honestly had trouble deciding what I wanted to eat, but eventually decided to get the cole valley crepe. The man that took my order was clearly in a hurry, trying to rush my order. But what the hell does he need to do when I'm trying to give him my money?

The food was incredibly underwhelming. The crepe was "supposedly" filled with sun-dried tomatoes. Didn't see any or taste any. There was a shitload of cheese which should make anything taste better, but the crepe just tasted ugh. The potatoes on the side weren't any better. Everything I ordered wasn't good. At all. No more business from me.
author: Lauren L.

description:
I am giving COC 5 stars not because it is perfect but because it does some key things REALLY well and the owners are lovely people.

Best points:
1. Their soups. Homemade and consistently excellent. If you have a friend home sick, bring them some of this soup.

2. Fresh squeezed OJ. Best in SF, no joke.

3. Ambiance and amenities. Best place to hang out hassle-free with a book-- or a book club. Plenty of space, and family-friendly (changing table.)

4. Delicious dessert crepes.

Worst points:
1. Home fries/potatoes. Bland and mushy. A shame.

2. Coffee isn't great.

3. Wish I could get a cheap glass of tea instead of an expensive pot of tea.

Overall, a wonderful neighborhood place.
author: alison m.

description:
This place is just terrible -- long wait, lousy staff, mediocre food.  When I ate there, I waited more than 25 minutes for pancakes. Turned out they had given my order to somebody else. When the waitress told me this, she did not even apologize for the error.  I understand that mistakes will be made but the least that she could do was apologize! The pancakes were mediocre -- still a little mushy as if they hadn't been cooked long enough. 

Never, never again. This place has nothing to offer it.
author: Cath V.

description: Food was ok we ended up here by default as the wait was too long at Zazie and we should have stuck it out. We were a party of 6 and all received our food at different times and one of us did not get their meal until the rest of us were almost done. We even checked on it several times. The place is ok not bad but truthfully lesson learned for us and probably will not return but wait it out up the street at Zazie's
author: Denice W.

description: Decent food, fresh food, and a good variety, however there is no "wow" factor. Crepes tastes like normal crepes. Good place if you have a lot of people and you need a big place to sit. Even a better place if you don't have time to wait in line for Zazie down the block and you need to chow asap. I wouldn't come back if I didn't have to. I'd stick to Zazie down the street.
author: Vanessa K.

description: Was in the neighborhood looking for a brunch place.. I was going to go to Zazie but it was soo full. Walked down a couple blocks and thankfully came across Crepes on Cole. Loved my delicious Mexican scramble, fresh juice and french toast. Mmm mmm!
author: Dana S.

description:
I joined Yelp practically just so I could review this place and stand up for it in every way. 

I have been coming to Crepes on Cole since I was about five years old. I have lived in Cole Valley my whole life, but don't let my neighborhood bias fool you. I know what a good crepe is. Yes, I too have been to Paris multiple times. So I must be some kind of expert, right?

Enough with the sarcasm. This place serves great crepes, with a delicious side of potatoes and salad if they're savory or whipped cream if they're sweet. The choices are vast between savory and dessert crepes, and even past that there are bagels, omelets, eggs, french toast...you name it. I have tried every crepe on the menu and I don't remember ever being dissatisfied. Sure, they aren't Parisian delicacies, and I'm sure you could find some gourmet crepe shop in the city with more authentic french crepes, but that is not the point. These crepes are filling, thick and heavy, loaded with ingredients; they offer some new interesting combination of ingredients too. 

And, you have to trust me on this, the owner is an awesome guy. He remembers me every time I come in even when I have been away at college for months. He asks how his regulars are doing and treats newcomers like regulars too. He cracks jokes, makes you comfortable, but doesn't overplay the host thing. The staff has always been nice to me. Never rushed me, even if I stay long past when I've finished my meal. It's so comfortable to be there.

On top of all that, add these delicious tidbits:
The restaurant is cozy and always has local art on display. It has a hand drawn chalkboard menu. Big windows for lots of light. The N rolls right past. Heart of Cole Valley.
