Hop skip and a jump from the Haight Ashbury. The building it's in used the be "The Other Cafe" where Dana Carvey performed a lot.

I'm not saying this place is my religion. I'm not forcing you to go there. I just had to stand up for a place that has always been so wonderful for me. Thanks, Crepes on Cole.
author: India K.

description: "Decent" sums the place up pretty well. Decent menu. Decent service. Decent food. This is a good choice if you're looking for a breakfast/brunch spot without a wait in Cole Valley, but there are also more interesting (but busier) places nearby.
author: Brett B.

description:
I gotta say Cole Valley is an area with lots of neighborhood pride and I respect that. The service was fantastic, the layout is similar to the Squat and Gobble menu. 

The food just wasn't great. The price was minimal as well, but there was nothing that jumped out at me or impressed in any way. This was middle of the road.
author: Nelson C.

description: Mmmm Burger on sourdough... yummm. The front desk owner? is really nice and friendly. Solid breakfast/lunch food!
author: Andrew V.

description:
Cheese, pesto, spinach, sundried tomatos, avocado, mushrooms = CREPE HEAVEN! 

How have I not been a crepe lover my whole life?? I had the Cole Valley crepes here yesterday with a side of potatoes and greens and it truly hit the spot. Everything I love most tucked into a crepe blanket, and you can have it for lunch or dinner! 

Can not WAIT to try dessert crepes!
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Meh.  Mediocre.  We had the chicken peso crepe, san francisco eggs benedict, depth charge and a cappuccino.  English Muffins were not toasted so they were soft and soggy under the weight of the moist spinach and poached eggs.  The crepe was okay.  Nothing to write about.  Drinks: cap was just alright - nothing special; depth charge (espresso shot in coffee) was not bad.  Solid 2 stars, no more. 

Didn't want to wait at the end of the long line outside Zazie so we walked in to give it a try.  Not worth a return trip.
author: Liz K.

description:
I like their crepes. They use good chocolate.
I've never been there for brunch or lunch since it's not in my neiborhood and kind of hassle to get there by bus and parking around there sucks.

Good atmosphere and good art, too.
author: Yoko S.

description:
I'm with Mary B--the potatoes come with everything, so why aren't they fresh and tasty? On the inside, they were starchy, and on the outside they weren't at all crisp, and it tasted like they were microwaved in cheap oil. They and the salad needed some salt.

I didn't order a crepe because they all came with cheddar, even the build-your-own, and that seemed weird to me. Crepe + cheddar as the standard? Really? I had a vegetarian sandwich, though, and that was fresh and tasty; yet small for the price (considering that the potatoes went uneaten). The carrot juice is also good and made right there.

The location is convenient to the N and there are quite a few sidewalk tables where one may dine al fresco.
author: Sagruilla P.

description:
I'm not an experienced crepe eater, (read: do not have too much to compare this place too), however, the crepe I ordered was pleasantly tasty. 

Crepes were light fluffy, which I presume is how a crepe is supposed to be served. Detected a hint of cinnamon- take it that is also the norm? I ordered the "special" which consisted of chicken, avocado, cheese, mushrooms- hmm, kinda sounds pizza-like come to think of it. They had a good amount of filling in them.  It was served with roasted potatoes and a side salad with vinaigrette dressing (very tasty). Although good, the potatoes were kind of bland. 

For a Friday night, this place was not too busy, and our food came out fairly fast- although, it was the wrong order we received. This seems to be a more common problem with restaurants in the city, i've noticed. Our order quickly taken away from us just as we took our first bite. There we sat salivating, like Pavlov's Dog....I do wonder where this food goes once it leaves our forks...

Wait staff was friendly, location was great, right off N Judah muni stop in the heart of Cole Valley. After dinner, you can cross the street to Kezar and have a glass of wine or your favorite spirit, or jump on the muni for a night out on the town. Which is what we did. Very convenient. Decent place for the price and amount of food you get.
author: Lisa Z.

description:
This a place that requires a lot of restraint, as there are so many menu items you will want to order! 

All I know is that their hot apple cider is freakin' amazing! Not syrupy and not watered down, I couldn't get enough of it. My friend had the half carrot/half orange blend made from scratch that was also very tasty. If you like carrot juice that is.

We both had the SF Eggs Benedict, which was also scrumpcious. I really wish I had ordered the traditional NY Eggs Benedict, only because I'm one of those people that needs meat with their breakfast and the spinach, while very good, made me feel incomplete. But nothing personal against their food or service, the place is wonderful and has a very comfy atmosphere to it. I will be back!
author: Alita M.

description:
I've been going to this place for breakfast, brunch and take out dinner for over ten years. I order the exact same thing every time (omelet with feta and tomato, toasted poppy-seed bagel, hold the fruit for breakfast, greek salad with chicken for dinner). I love it because you can ALWAYS get a table, its always pretty OK and the owner is kinda nice. The take out is fast, the coffee is good (illy) and its super cheap, and relatively good.

Well, what i don't like so much: The toilets are totally wrong and gross. They have a changing table in the women's bathroom, as if i would EVER put my child on that and i'm not an uptight, germ fearing parent. and the plumbing doesn't work that well.

The thing i hate the MOST, beyond anything, is that when you're ordering at the counter, as soon as you mention a drink they're gone making it, even though your friend might also want a coffee drink and it would be quicker to make both at once. I don't get this AT ALL and after ten years, it really pisses me off.

But its super cheap, its good, basic food, its totally consistent and i keep going back at least once a week.
author: Sarah D.

description:
There are these pretty Christmas lights on the windows that makes it a cute little place to hang out after sundown. The interiors are no different than any other crepe places (i.e. Crepevine), but it is quite spacious: good amount of tables, walking space, tall ceilings.

Ordered the Peanut Butter and Nutella Dessert Crepe. Was restless after 10 minutes, but it was worth the wait. It was nice and HOT when it finally arrived. I immediately slathered the light, fluffy whip cream on top, shoveled a piece in my mouth, and experienced bliss as the hot, crunchy peanut butter melted underneath the perfect crepe blanket.

I must have finished it in 2 minutes, tops.

Warmed me up from the cold outside. 4 stars.

Total: $6.30
author: Julia L.

description:
Great OJ. Amazing on a hot afternoon of running around town, trying to find a key to my apartment!

The eggs themselves were quite good too, but I still remember the OJ. It looked a bit crowded as we approached it, but they were quick to serve us, and we got our tables almost immediately. Nice nook on Cole. Great place to stop before or after visiting GGP.
author: Gurpreet S.

description:
I come here once a month or so, though I'd never make the effort if this place wasn't so close to my apartment. I must say upfront: I really like the staff here. Nice folks. I can tell they care about their establishment.

 Unfortunately, the savory crepes are quite mediocre. Decent at best. I know I'm about to speak foodie blasphemy, but the crepes at crepevine (a bay area chain, eeee!) are much, much better. Crepevine's potatoes are crispier and better seasoned too. I just wish Crepes on Cole's crepes had a bit more flavor. From what I have tasted, many are quite bland. I am looking to make memories here! Let me make memories with you, Crepes on Cole!!!! You can do it. Seems to be a lot of love in this place. 

A fair warning for all: their coffee/lattes are outright ick. I think their crepes are decent, but try to sneak in a to-go cup with La Boulange's yummy coffee from across the street. 

But wait: I've heard good thing about their sweet crepes. Maybe that's a better route? Or maybe I should order the pancakes?

I will likely be back. (So! close! to my apartment!) with a nice owner and okay food. Just not the best, not worth a long drive. My laziness keeps me coming back.
author: Liz F.

description:
Understanding that having to work on Jan 1st might have marked an awful beginning for the cashier, I perked his mood up with a lively "Happy New Year!" He broke out a smile.  Thank goodness!  Needless to say, the service, to me, was considered mediocre.  

Now the food: the chicken in the Chicken Pesto Crepe was very dry.  Thighs meat would have been a better option for the restaurant.  Lettuce leaves for the salad was obviously not fresh.  

Although the food was reasonably priced, when compare to the taste and freshness of the food, I actually felt like it was a bit of a rip off, as I'd rather spend few more bucks at a place where the quality of service and food be at least 2 times better.  Seriously, few more bucks will do.
author: Helen C.

description: We had a fun night out and so slept in. We went to Crepes on cole because they are my weakness. They were very busy but it seemed like fairly organized chaos but when I finally gave my order the girl seemed a bit over whelmed. The receipt she gave me wasn't itemized so i couldn't catch that she forgot to take down my sausage order. I went up when our food was brought out and they said they would bring it right now to me. I ate slowly and still it never came... finally went up at the end and told them to forget it we were done and leaving. The owner was very nice and tried very hard to right the wrong but at that point we were ready to leave. The prices were too high for what it was. Everything was edible but nothing was impressive.
author: Kate H.

description:
Convenient, cute, quality ingredients and delicious = 4 stars!

They have a great menu for breakfast, lunch and dinner! Everything from crepes and omelets to sandwiches and salads. I haven't tried their crepes but I have had their omelets and my absolute favorite which is their bruschetta sandwich. Grilled sourdough, fresh mozzarella cheese, sliced tomato (that is incredibly flavorful) and fresh basil. I think this sandwich is a testament to their fresh ingredients! So simple and so good!

The decor is cute and there is plenty of indoor and outdoor seating! Prime corner for people-watching!!

The service is fantastic and even when I have to take the food to go, they pack it so that it the food nevers gets mushy and stays hot! 

I couldn't be happier that I live around the corner from COC and I plan on making it my go-to for a reliably delicious breakfast, lunch OR dinner!

The only inconvenience is that they are cash only but it really isn't that big of a deal!
author: Liz S.

description: I don't get the negative reviews about this place. It's pretty simple food, and it is a chain (and for a chain, it's pretty darn good)...you get good fast service, decent food, and you know what to expect. Gets a little crowded at key times of the day, but I have always found a seat because there's a lot of circulation. I like the no-fuss process of ordering first and sitting down, so it suits me well. The location is really cute too; one of the nicer crepe places compared to other 'Crepe Places.' The one on irving street is good too.
author: Liz R.

description:
I have ate at HUNDREDS of Restaurant places in several states BUT this is THE best place I have ever ate Breakfast. Although there several things I think could be improved I am a firm believer that the FOOD has to be great before anything else.

Being a French Toast man, i decided to order a round of French Toast and was very pleased with what I received. I liked the fact that the Orange Juice is made to order and not pulled out of a "From Concentrate" bottle. The menu has a few too many items and the line to order and pay a little too long but overall I was satisfied with the experience. 

Great if your looking for an alternative to Dennys!
author: Jacob D.

description: Okay but nothing to write home about. Wouldn't object to going again if a friend insisted (but don't know why a friend would insist) and--with so many excellent options in SF--won't bother again of my own accord.
author: Cynthia J.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed Crepes on Cole!  Man, this is one of my favorite spots in San Francisco.  I just came here last weekend when I was visiting from LA.  It was around 10:30am and we had just missed the breakfast rush and it was nice and quiet.  Sam, one of the owners, was incredibly friendly.   My friend and I sat by the window and enjoyed the "Cole Valley" crepe and um...I can't remember the name but it had chicken and pesto.  We split them and both were delicious.  My only problem is that I love sweet crepes and I never order one because I'm always stuffed from our savory crepes.

I've always loved the ambiance here, both outside and inside.  And like I said, very friendly staff.
author: Joe K.

description: i ordered the curry chicken crepe, expecting it to be lighter and have more curry flavor. it fit the bill for a fulfilling lunch and then some, but definitely wasn't what i expected for a "light" lunch. the staff was interesting and quite entertaining to observe, they all seemed to have a bit of a love/hate relationship with each other.
author: Sarah Y.

description:
Crapes On Cole gets big marks for me for a a couple reasons:

1). Its down the street from Zazie. Everyone raves about Zazie, and I completely agree, its delicious. But its crowded almost all the time. When I went to Crapes on Cole, there was a crowd, but it wasnt packed and we easily found a seat.

2). The Crapes hit the spot. Its a good breakfast at a decent price. I tried the Cole Valley, the chicken pesto, and the Mediterranean. All of them were good, but I'm a sucker for eggplant so the mediterranean wins for me.

3). Super accessible by public transport. Not so important for me, we drove, but I could see myself walking here with guests and heading out for a day in SF via the N.
author: Phil C.

description:
Year after year C.O.C. just keeps on crepe-ing! It's a fairly large place, so lots of seating and also free wireless. I like that they always have soups, and (BONUS)-- today's choice had no dairy or gluten. They let us both order a small plate of chicken on the side (which we added to the soup). I know, you may think that's weird, but it really is a great meal!
The only thing missing was Sam, my favorite neighborhood smile. (see previous review for explanation) te-hee!
author: Roanna Z.

description:
Went for the second time this morning for a late breakfast. The food is great. There's no doubt about that. I had an amazing scramble of eggs, salsa, avocado, cheese... and it came with toast and potatoes. My friend had a huge burger loaded with mushrooms and half an avocado.

The food came really fast and everything was super delicious. The guy behind the register was really nice and joked around with us. The waitress was kind of an ass though, which sucked, because I was having a really great morning until her cold attitude greeted me at the door.

BUT somehow, in 2009, this restaurant doesn't take credit/debit cards. I get it when small/cheap places don't take cards, but this place isn't cheap and does a crap-load of business. They lose a star for that. Telling me to go get money from the ATM across the street isn't a great business practice. It basically means my $10 breakfast costs $12 because I have to pay an ATM surcharge. Thanks.
author: jared c.

description: I really like this place. It's pretty inexpensive and the food is great. I had a salmon sandwich that was amazing! The guy who took my order was fantastic - funny guy with an Italian accent. Free coffee refill. Try it out when you get a chance.
author: Juliana B.

description: Great crepes, especially for what we get served here in Seattle! This place used to be a lot better, ten years ago, but they are still GREAT!! I had to stop-in the last time I was in town for one of each: dinner, and dessert crepe!
author: Trace S.

description: FANTASTIC! The owner, the food, the atmosphere all make this place somewhere I will go out of my way to eat breakfast at everytime I am in San Francisco. I got the tofu crepe and it was delicious!! I went with 4 other people and we were ALL thoroughly impressed. The owner even introduced himself when he brought us our food -- all just adding to the experience. But I guess the main point here is that the ingredients tasted fresh, the food was HOT, and everything was great. Go here!
author: Brittany B.

description:
Great place to go if you are in a hurry and famished. These guys are rocket fast. You order at the counter (with a huge wall menu) and everything looked great, and there's plenty of seating. 

I ordered the smoked salmon scrabble (came with potatoes and toast) and a mimosa. It completely hit the spot especially after a 6-mile walk. Will definitely be back!!!
author: Briar F.

description:
I shared a black forest ham and cheddar sandwich on a baguette today and it was pretty good!  Coupled with an Italian soda, it was a nice afternoon snack.  The restaurant space is comfy and has a nice view of the intersection.  It's also conveniently located in front of the N-Judah stop.

I'll definitely be back to try the crepes.
author: Nina L.

description: I first dined here over a decade ago. It was actually my first savory crepe and I liked it. It was a chicken pesto crepe. Went here recently and ordered the exact same crepe, with a different result. It was okay. Nice size, came with tossed greens and roasted red potatoes like last time. But the flavor of the crepe wasn't great. The chicken seemed pre-boiled and, while seasoned, bordered on dry. The cheese lacked flavor. I didn't taste enough pesto. I did, however, like the crepe itself.  It had a buttery, solid feel to it and was crisped nicely.  I guess the cooks had changed hands since the last time I visited. Too bad, since I felt the service was polite and it didn't really take long for me to receive my order. No wonder the place was quiet on a Saturday afternoon.  I've had better crepes elsewhere since my first visit here so long ago, and I think I'll have better crepes hence.
author: Eileen P.

description:
Delicous - Just down the street from Zazie and no wait on a Saturday.  I almost want to keep this place a secret.

Ordered:
Mimosa, OJ, & Mexican Chocolate
Salsa Crepe, French Toast, & Spinach/Salmon/Goat Cheese Scramble

All were great!  More than enough food for 3 - we shared and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves!
author: Alyxandra D.

description:
Undeniably SF. - sunny corner with sliding windows, some sidewalk tables, and a neighborhood feel. And who doesn't like crepes filled unlimited ways? They also serve sandwiches and breakfast.

Food - with a few tweaks this place can soar. While my mushroom-spinach crepe was pretty good, the quartered potatoes needed to 
crisper to make an impact. Pre-cook, and crisp on grill prior to serving!
Also, the tossed lettuce salad was limp. More of a plate filler than anything else. 

Back to crepes - order from the pre-conceived choices, or build your own. The crepes are between are hearty, and the filling was plenty.

I can see why people line up, especially for breakfast-brunch. If it was
in my 'hood I would be a regular.
author: P C.

description:
Lovely little neighborhood spot with a decent selection of crepe based goodies.  Inside there's a pleasant atmosphere and the staff are very friendly.  

I had the french toast which was delicious - thick fluffy slices of cinnamon covered toast complete with fresh fruit (strawberries, bananas and blackberries) and a mini pot of syrup.  Very tasty!  We sat inside at one of the window tables in the sunshine and watched Cole Valley pass by.
author: Lewis W.

description: This place has amazing breakfast and the portions are huge. It's a great place to relax and enjoy hearty food and drinks - especially with the all-day $2.95 draft beer.
author: Kassie D.

description:
Used to go to Crepes on Cole growing up and recently returned when I was in town to get my 'banana chocolate' crape fix. This dessert crepe was just how i remembered it; warm, and filled with a melted chocolate and banana slices. Also noticed a sign advertising 3$ draft beers!? Yes please!! The menu at COC is extensive, you are guaranteed to find something that you'll like. 

My favorite part of Crepes on Cole is really the atmosphere though, its very casual. A great spot to meet a friend, read the paper, or grab a late night snack. Can't wait to move back to the city and have the opportunity to go more often.
author: Jski T.

description:
I haven't been as disappointed by a meal in San Francisco in a long time. I ordered a crepe to go - the crepe benedict. As it was around the same price as a regular eggs benedict, I assumed it would be a similar amount of food. However, when I opened my takeout box I found that it was just a single egg with the tiniest drizzle of hollandaise sauce perched on top of a small, flavorless crepe. Which is not to suggest that anything else in the box had any flavor. Maybe I should have eaten in and poured lots of salt on everything? 
The food was terrible. No flavor, tiny portion, and a mushy crepe. The service was mediocre. It was a Sunday morning so the restaurant was understandably busy, but all the staff seemed more stressed than would have been justified. This may have been because the owner (manager? Not entirely sure, but he acted like he owned the place) was unpleasant to all of them. Standing by the counter waiting for my food (which was another thing - they had no place to wait for takeout and they didn't take down my name, so I didn't feel like I could wait outside or anywhere other than right by the busy counter), I got to watch him angrily ordering the staff around and telling people off for things that clearly weren't their fault. This made the atmosphere really unpleasant, as it's never fun to be around someone taking out their issues on subordinates. 
It may have just been a bad day at Crepes on Cole, but I certainly won't be going back to see if they have good days.
author: Adam G.

description:
- food: crepes were okay without tasting bad
- atmosphere: order at counter / seat-yourself
- staff: fine / unremarkable
- price: cheap-ish

additional info:
- good for families with small children
author: J. B.

description:
Some meals are fantastically flavored and grand; some are terribly bland and inadequate.  

Crepes on Cole served The Breakfast Lunch Club neither.  Around the table sat The Hunter, The Gentlemen, The Frenchmen, and Nana.  A simple "how is it?" brought back a real good, an ups and downs, an ok, and a pretty good.  With those opinions, The Breakfast Lunch Club seemed content, but not overly excited.

Tables were hard to get this misty morning. The BLC was lucky to have its Hunter, who snagged a couple.  There was no wait, though, besides a short line to order at the cash register.  

Do not be surprised to find the BLC back here, exploring the rather large menu.
author: The Breakfast-Lunch Club o.

description:
I've become a regular at this cute crepes joint.  Honestly, I've never ordered anything besides a crepe here, but that's because I feel absolutely no need to -- the crepes are wonderful!  Perfectly thin, crisp crepe on the outside, and the ideal amount of gooey cheese and veggies on the inside.  The Mediterranean and Basil crepes are two of my faves, but that's probably because I have an unhealthy addiction to feta.  Plus, the people who work behind the counter are *incredibly* friendly and happy to advise you on your selection or give you samples if appropriate (e.g. soup of the day).  Also, if you order wine with your crepe, you get a glass filled right to the brim.  Woohoo!

My only complaint is that service can be a touch slow for an order-at-the-counter-type of place... but that's more than made up for by the deliciousness of the crepe that awaits you!

Bonus: they take credit cards now.
author: Laura R.

description:
Yummy! 

They have good brunch options: crepes, omlettes, salads and sandwiches.  I really like their potatoes as well.  

The place is spacious and good for groups, plus the guys that work there are very nice.  I think you should go.
author: Brittney B.

description: Awesome food and service. My cappuchino was perfect. I asked for a lot of foam and it was great. I ordered the pesto and avocado crepe and it had onions and cheddar cheese in it too. I loved it! Perfect crepe and tasty ingredients. Good sized portion and it filled me up for hours. I like how you order at the counter, get a # and they serve you everything. There is always room and they have outside seating too. I'm going back today!
author: Joanne F.

description:
Service: Very crowded on a weekend morning, but we went because there was a crazy long wait at Zazzie. Everyone was nice and helpful. You order at the counter and then sit down and have food brought to you. I would have really appreciated a coffee refill, but it was behind the counter and crowded. 

Ambiance: It was crowded and pretty loud from all of the people talking. Table wasn't level...I just wasn't thrilled with the experience. 

Food: To be fair, we ordered eggs and note crepes. The food was just okay, all of it was very bland (eggs, potatoes, even the bacon didn't have much flavor). 

Verdict: Maybe stick to the crepes? If you're looking for breakfast wait in line somewhere else!
author: Julie W.

description: My first time. I was thinking sweet crepe when I entered but the Fisherman's Wharf caught my eye. And boy am I glad it did. What a wonderful flavor combination. I'd feel obliged to try something else if I'm there again, but it sure would be tempting to go for the salmon, capers, spinach thing. Even the cappuccino was a pleasant surprise. Yep, all in all not a bad place.
author: Sch T.

description: Making a strong plug here for their Benedicts. Fantastic. Nice people. Fresh food. And don't worry about no wifi here because it is a very strong Xfinity hotspot.
author: Megan M.

description: This place was pretty nasty.  My friend and I went there for dinner the other night and we were both pretty horrified by our meals.  My veggie sandwich had hard flavorless avocado on it, and his cheese omelette was disgusting.  The home fries were undercooked, so it was like eating raw potatoes.  I would not recommend this place any time after 12pm.  Disastrous.  We just kept saying "nutrients."  We received nutrients, but not a good meal.  It used to be good back in the day...did they change owners who ran the place into the ground or something?  On a side note...the new girl whose first day it was that night was AWESOME.
author: Terika T.

description: Good location. I took a Nutella crepe here, it was okay but kind of small. They put tons of whipped cream next to it, which makes it pretty heavy and not very refined. And too bad there is no WiFi!
author: Jonathan V.

description:
We had a difference of opinion on this one, ranging between a three and a four star review, but settled on the lower one in the end.

In terms of the positive, this place has huge portions as they complement their crepes with potatoes and a salad. The prices, while not inexpensive, are very reasonable for what one gets as well (just be sure to bring cash, though). A waiter service component might have been nice, but for some a register order might be more preferable and this location does provide that experience. 

In terms of our crepes of choice, we have gone with the salsa ones (being one of the few locations were we have ordered the same dish). It just seems like the standout entry on the menu, although the salsa itself tastes a little "generic". Not bad, but comparable to the ingredients and slight taste one might expect to find from a store bought variety in a bottle.

Overall, due to proximity, its likely we will be back. Not the best crepes around, but the place offers a unique experience and is far more reasonable with its pricing (since they give you more than just a crepe) than others in SF.
author: Sami R.

description:
When I was living in the Haight, this was my favorite place to eat. I always get the same thing when I'm there. The half bruschetta sandwhich (I recommend asking for the baguette or else you'll get plain sliced bread) soup and salad combo. It's a lot of food, for a decent price. It's a good place for studying because you can study and drink tea or coffee while you digest and then have a sweet crepe for desert. 

And you can hear the N-Judah coming, in case you need to dash out in time to grab it.
author: Bonnie C.

description: The best french toast EVER!!!!! all that cinnamony goodness
author: Sovera N.

description:
Scrumptious!

After the AIDS walk on Sunday, my friends and I were starving and on a hunt for a delicious place to eat!
And by Luck, we sure found one!

Crepes on Cole is a cute little place in Cole Valley!
The menu is simple, reasonably priced & a delightful treat! 
They have pancakes, eggs, sandwiches, soups & salads!

I had the San Francisco Eggs Benedict & a mimosa for under $15!

They also have inside and outside seating. Just know that on a sunny day, everyone will want to sit outside!
I will definitely be returning to try the French toast!

**Just know that this place is CASH only! No credit cards accepted!**
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Just enjoyed lunch here after a long walk with a good friend and the pooch through GG Park. Cute little spot on the corner! 

The good outdoor seating was a plus since we had the dog. I enjoyed the Florentine crepe, which was super tasty. Too bad the person a few posts down got sick from it - mine looked on the up and up and I'm feelin' fine right now. 

My crepe plus diet Coke in the can came to a total of $10.78. I'd call it a good value since the crepe was huge and fresh and the accompaniments of rosemary potatoes and simple spring green salad were lovely. I'm still thinking about the fresh flavor combinations of the crepe - mmm spinach, cheddar and cottage cheese... 

I'll definitely come back (with the same friend!) for more lunch/brunch adventures.
author: Liz K.

description: Several friends and I spent a few days in San Fran and Crepes on Cole was two blocks from our vacation rental.The service was a little slow and I distinctly smelled Ganja near the back on two separate occasions, but the food was good enough to warrant a visit every day. Their meals are fresh and carefully prepared (I admit to being a little O.C.D.) and everyone is friendly and helpful. I highly recommend the Cole Valley Crepe for rough mornings after a night of drinking.
author: Kelly J.

description: It has been a couple of years since I last came here and actually forgot how good the crepes were.  Ordered the banana crepe with an Americano and loved it, you couldn't ask for a better dessert.  Sam, the owner, remembers many of his regular customers like my buddy, who has been going there for over 10 years.  Great place to kick back and relax.
author: Tommy L.

description: I had breakfast here for the first time and have to say that after living in SF for 8 years, it was probably one of the worst meals I have had here.  First the Mexican eggs were so saturated with cheese and salsa, I couldn't tell if there were even any eggs in there. Second, there were egg shells in it. I wasn't sure until my second mouthful that yes indeed I was crunching on egg shells. I brought my plate up to the counter to let them know and although they seem slightly concerned, they didn't offer me a refund of anything. I had not eaten much of the meal so they should have at least offered me something! Anyway, I won't be eating here ever again!
author: jennifer s.

description:
Really 3.5 stars. 

The atmosphere left something to be desired, especially around lunch time. It was crowded, and the tables being different shapes and sizes make it hard to navigate (especially while dodging strollers and laptops). 

Great fresh squeezed orange juice and pancakes. Not original or special. Also its cash only. I'll go back to try the crepes.
author: Halley B.

description: Totally meh. Staff seemed annoyed when we asked a question about the menu, and didn't know what we wanted the minute we stood at the counter. Mind you, we were the only three people AT the counter, so it's not like we were holding up a busy line. Food was OK but the lasting impression is from the un-cheery women at the register.
author: Amanda L.

description:
"Meh". That's what I have to say about the food. It's pretty basic, and there isn't anything on the menu that you couldn't make yourself if you really wanted to. It's nothing too exciting, and a few times that I've been here the staff has seemed really snotty. And in this economy, that is an issue. Because, guess what? If you don't stop being a brat...I won't continue to come here and you won't have a job anymore...or anyone to glare at with disdain any longer. 

The food is fine, I like the potatoes, but I'm not raving. I repeat: I am not raving. Crepevine is better. Yea...I said it.
author: Melissa H.

description: Crepes on Cole is my favorite crepery in San Francisco. The spot is a landmark. They have a great selection. I usually go for a crepe with salmon. Service is minimal and not homey. It's right by the N Judah, and that's the charm. Cole Valley is such a wonderful place to be!
author: Denise C.

description: I wish I could rate Crepes on Cole higher, but the food here is simply unremarkable. The crepes are plain and made without precision; the huevos rancheros lack the vibrancy characteristic of this dish. On the other hand, Crepes on Cole features a relaxed atmosphere for casual dining, and stays open late.
author: Chris T.

description: Their chicken pesto crepe was savory and easy on the eyes. It came with side potatoes and a mushroom (?) salad. It really fills you up, but if you still have room for dessert, you can stop by The Ice Cream Bar which is only  7 houses down on the same block!
author: Tiff C.

description:
Outdoor seating, a hearty meal and pleasant atmosphere. Oh yes, I do like.

For $10, Crepes on Cole will offer you a chance to indulge in a yummy crepe and side salad while people watching on the corner of Carl and Cole. You get the Haight St.-graduates who now push strollers on their way from their Victorian flat to brunch at Reverie or to find cool new post-pregnancy threads at Villians. 

ConC will leave you feeling satisfied, yet healthy (note: I love eggs, spam and rice for breakfast). Try them out. I prefer this locale over the crepe spot on Irving St. in the Inner Sunset.
author: Deann M.

description: Weekly music meet ups every Thursday morning! Server is friendly & they serve tofu on Crepes & scrambles!
author: Aki L.

description:
I went here craving an epic breakfast with some friends and I certainly got that. They make amazing omelets (I recommend ordering swiss and mushroom) and it comes with breakfast potatoes, fruit wedges and choice of bagel or toast- like I said I was hungry so I went with a bagel all for around 8 bucks. 

If I lived or worked in San Francisco I would definitely make this a weekly ritual but for now I will go when I visit friends in the area
author: Cassie K.

description:
Ok, maybe I'm not being fair but one of the things I hate about some restaurants here in the US is the stressful system of ordering your food at a counter, then fighting the crowds to find a table.  

For those of us with children, this kind of place is a nightmare. And if you have a child in a stroller and are forced to navigate the line, order, and then find a table....by the time you are seated, you may be ready to call it a day.

So I am knocking it down a star simply for that vile, unsophisticated system of ordering at a counter. I go to a restaurant to relax, not to compete with my neighbors for a seat.

Plus, the food is just ok.  The portion sizes are un-necessarily large.  What are they trying to prove?  I would prefer smaller portions but better quality.  

Overall, it's my least favorite resaurant in my neighborhood. And I love crepes too. It's a shame.  

Crepes on Cole....I won't be back.
author: Julia Y.

description:
We strolled into Crepes on Cole one day and were immediately greeted by a black chalkboard awash in the colors of the rainbow in a cheerful display of confidence and pride in the quality of their offerings. 

I chose to ignore my self-proclaimed (but externally validated) caffeine sensitivity, throw caution to the wind and just partake in wanton abandon so suited to a lazy Sunday afternoon when I knew I was leaving a huge chunk of my weekend to-do list purposefully (and self-indulgently) unattended to. My friend's palpable skepticism notwithstanding, I went ahead with my order, slightly breathless at the daring, bold move almost out of character! Turns out they were out of my choice of substance. Not one to be let down too easily, I turned back to the inviting chalkboard to start my research anew, in the quest for the perfect combination of cozy comfort and the shot of hyperactive energy I was thirsting for.

Great drinks, amazing service, and fun to just relax on a weekend afternoon. I have to return to actually try the food!

For full details, check out: http://bitesout.wordpress.com/2012/04/06/crepes-on-cole-cole-valley-san-francisco/
author: Naina A.

description:
I feel like the people-watching here would have been excellent, if I hadn't been busy meeting people to go over my Type-A fears about Not Giving The Perfect Direct Examination.  ("But do I have to establish a chain of custody if it's just a photograph?"  "What if everything I do isn't beyond criticism the first time around?  WHAT THEN?!")

More importantly, the $6.75 cheese-and-onion crepe was really good, served with potatoes (with rosemary), and a side salad.  The salad was basically spring greens with a vinagrette, but I couldn't finish all that they gave me, so that's usually the mark of a good food-to-money ratio.  Or I could just have a really small stomach. 

It was absolutely packed when I stepped inside at 1pm on a Saturday afternoon, but cleared out considerably by 2.  The staff seemed pretty nice.  No one seemed to have a problem with us taking up space for an hour and a half.

And I now have a game plan for my direct examination of my arresting officer.  Life is grand!
author: Jennie K.

description:
I'll give you the truth about Crepes on Cole. I know, because I used to work there.

As an ex-employee of this establishment, I can get you the goods... or bads, about this stinky little hole of narlyness, sexism, and the general disregard of their employees. 

Let see, where to start... They will only hire Hispanic men to work in the kitchen. Why? Because they know they can get away with overworking them and sticking them in a little hole of a kitchen without any ventilation.

They pay minimum wage with no chance for a raise. And they never, ever pay over time or time and a half (as the law requires). Ever. Even though they make all their employees work on New Year's Day, Thanksgiving and all other major Holidays. Why? Because they know they will be busy because everyone else is closed.

If you ever have the misfortune of working at this dump, you will be subject to the shorter brother's little temper tantrums, who one day decided to fire me because I had the cook rearrange my breakfast bagel and side of portabello mushrooms  into a sandwich. 

Why, you ask? Because employees are only "privileged" to eat crepes with 2 or 3 ingredients not including chicken, avocado and some cheese (I can't remember which), unless they paid for it. And they are not allowed to have a sandwich, unless they pay for it. But we were allowed to have eggs with a bagel and a side of something. So I order the bagel, skip the eggs, with a side of portabello mushrooms, and asked the cook to arrange it as a sandwich instead. 

Now, I will admit that the first time I did it was to piss-off that little bitch of an older brother (the shorter on with feminine hands). Unfortunately, that day he was in a good mood and just laughed it off. So I guessed it didn't matter. I ordered my breakfast like that from then on until one when he wasn't in a good mood and he went off. He yelled something about sandwiches not being on the employee menu and that made me laugh. So he fired me. Well, "f*ck you, too" I said (ok, so it was a bit more colorful than just a 3 word sentence.)

Other things to know about Crepes on Cole:

The cooks like to comment on female costumer's body parts.
A woman once found a rusty nail in her salad.
If you sit at the large round table by yourself (even if you are a little old man with his grandson) and there is no one else in the restaurant, the bigger brother will try to burn a hole through your head with his eyes and curse you behind the counter.
Their coffee is really bad.
The food is very unhealthy, just look at those big bellies behind the counter. You don't want to look like that, do you?

So that was the bad, now for the good:

...hmmmm....nope. Nothing. Oh, well. I tried.

Thank you Yelp. I have been vindicated!! Whahahahaha!!!!!
author: Carla P.

description: I was visiting my cousin in San Francisco with a friend of mine.  We ended up going here multiple times because we loved the crepes so much.  Also, who doesn't enjoy beer in the morning?
author: Leah B.

description:
This is not so much a review as an inquiry -- an inquiry into Crepes on Cole, Crepevine, The Crepe House, Squat and Gobble, or any one of dozens of other Bay Area establishments with the same, colored-chalkboard crepe/omelet/sandwich/salad/soup menu and rosemary potatoes. 

I have asked the staff at various locations if their creperie, let's call it Creperie X, was in any way related to the virtually identical Creperie Y in the next neighborhood over. I mean, we're talking genetically identical salads and without a doubt the same chalkboard menu letterer -- you can see her handiwork in the way she places that blue drop-shadow in the "S". 

And every single time I have received the too-hasty, Palestinian-accented answer: "No -- no relation at all. None."

Now, let me be clear. These are all good, reliable, consistent places to fill up with the basic food groups, like Florentine or Nutella-Chocolate. I also am fine with good, consistent, etc. local chains -- Pasta Pomodoro being a good example. All I'm asking is, what is being hidden from us here? Why the pretense of individual, unrelated businesses? Is a mysterious, shadowy holding corporation taking over the world, creperie by creperie? Is the CEO of CrepeCorp rubbing his hands an undisclosed location somewhere between Cole Valley and the Inner Sunset, saying, "Yes, my plan is succeeding! Ha ha! Ha ha ha ha! HA HA HA!" -- while unbeknownst to him, Austin Powers creeps through the ventilation duct?

I'm just asking.
author: Douglas G.

description:
Who goes to a crepe place and doesn't order crepes?! 

Umm, me. So I just started back full force on my Eat Right For Your Blood Type diet and on Sunday, my friend (who's also on this crazy adventure with me) and I were in need of some food fuel and so we decided to give this place a go. Only problem with that was we could only basically order a few things. No wheat, no meat, no dairy, translation: no crepes.

But what I did order was deeelish. I opted to go with the scramble dealio with spinach, mushrooms and some goat cheese (I can actually have that!) and all was cooked to perfection. It came with potatoes that I couldn't eat and fruit which I could, but all in all it was a really yummy brunch.

I also really love their iced tea here. Tasty stuff :) I could come back again and it's definitely better than standing in a two hour line and the little brunch spot down the street. Sorry, but I wait for no man or breakfast.
author: Stephy S.

description: Crepes on Cole=favorite spot in Cole Valley. Its cute, convenient, spacious, good service, reasonably priced for their portions, and delicious delicious crepey goodness. Yum in my tum. Grab the Mediterranean or the Greek Crepe. For dessert, I always opt for the banana nutella.
author: Kimmie M.

description:
Definitely think COC takes the cake (crepe?) out of all of the crepe places that are a dime a dozen here in SF. Their crepes are light and fluffy and they have an amazing selection of fillings, like basil!

I was there for Sunday brunch yesterday and although it was crowded, the tables turn over pretty quickly. A friendly member of the staff waved us over when he saw a table open up, and promptly cleaned it up before we sat down.

Some highlights: yummy vinaigrette on the salads and a bunch of fresh fruit on the breakfast plates (we're not talking about some anemic slice of honeydew... I mean several wedges of fresh melon and kiwi! mmmm).
author: Jill M.

description: Excellent! One of the best crepes I have ever had. Ventured out to the Greek crepe and it surpasses all my expectations!  Neat neighborhood and vibe in the restaurant - will be back for sure.
author: Alex R.

description:
Honestly, my first meal at Crepes on Cole left me, well, kinda cold (Cole'd?)

Crepe was okay, but kinda room temperature, kinda undercooked and kinda bland. Coffee kinda weak.

Wish I could be kinda, but I'm afraid it didn't really measure up to my crepe expectations.
author: GIR ..

description:
Crepes on Cole is a great addition to our small neighborhood. When the wait at Zazie is too long and you are in the mood for an even more laid back atmosphere then walk over to Crepes on Cole.

Personally I enjoy the savory crepes, especially the pesto chicken one but I have come here often with my vegetarian friends and they are always impressed with the choices the menu offers. 
Keep in mind they don't only serve crepes but also variations of bagels, waffles etc. The food overall is good.. nothing special but still an alternative to a Zazie breakfast.
author: Doro P.

description:
Sorry, Gil, but I love this place.

It's got your San Francisco-crepery essentials:  chalkboard menus, savory and sweet crepes, woodsy interior.  It's also got a view of the N-Judah, which is what bumps it up to five stars.

The food is really good, and the people who work here are nice.
author: John S.

description:
I am not sure what they are.. but they are not crepes.. more like a calzone or a burrito... 
big disappointment !

I have also tried Le Zinc in Noe.. greasy moroccan crepes.... again a dissapointment !

where can one find real crepes in SF ??
author: Sid V.

description:
The name is yet another shameless cashing in of the self-love of those deluded souls who declare themsleves Cole Valleyans.  The joint is decent, ample portions, low prices, a bit too bright and wide and sterile for my taste, and it raises the obvious metaphysical question, what is crepe?

Whatever they are serving it is not crepes, at least not in any classic French sense.  But they are starchy, fatty, tasty, and a good hangover cure.
author: Gil S.

description:
The menu is just like Crepevine and Squat and Gobble and all those other crepe places. And you stand in line, order at the counter and they hand you a table number to be displayed so that they could find you.

The Boyfriend and I met up with a friend there. Great thing is that it's right at a Muni stop as the BF and I decided to take public transit into the city instead of dealing with traffic. Cute little neighborhood. For a late Sunday morning, it was busy enough that we couldn't find a table by the windows. 

The guy at the counter taking orders was a little brusque and I think that scared the people in front of us a little. They weren't ready to order and looked at us with mildly panicked-eyes and told us to go ahead. Since the three of us were familiar with this menu, we ordered quickly and sat down. We got our food approximately 10 minutes later. Quick, yes.

The girls working there and busing tables were really nice. We told them we had about six more people joining us and they happily obliged in clearing off tables around us when people left and adding them to ours. Since it started to get busy right after we had ordered, this was really great because our friends wouldn't have had seats otherwise.

Food is good and filling. Not phenomenal, but real good quality with lots of flavor. I had the Crepe Florentine and while it was a bit bland, that was actually exactly what I was looking for that morning. The friend had a bagel-wich and they forgot his bacon, but it was good enough that he didn't mind. The BF had some type of a Spanish crepe and ate the whole thing. Vibe is very casual and the space encourages conversations and relaxation. When we're in the area again, we'll hit up Crepes on Cole and have a dessert crepe.
author: Judy F.

description:
Love the crepes here - both the savory and sweet.  Lots of vegetarian options, fresh ingredients.  

Owner is often at the restaurant, very pleasant.  One star off for cash only policy.
author: Sandra W.

description:
You know, you can't go wrong with Crepes on Cole. Food is good, the service can be slow, but when it gets to your table it will be good. The menus might be hard to read if you need binoculars to read a newspaper in front of you.

The N Judah might rattle you every now and then, but be amazed as the crowd that waits for the train just grows and grows. I don't think it ever stops at any point of the day.

I ordered a crepe with havarti, chicken, avocado, mushrooms. Good shit, I swear. But here's where I give this place extra love. I happen to only come here during the mad rushes of brunch. Yesterday I was there at 2PM for a late lunch with a coworker. The place was dead. Only a few seats taken. It felt really awkward to have a conversation, it was so quiet. But I loved it. How can I just give up my job to hang out in the middle of the day, sipping my mocha and read a paper. 

Oh well. Back to work. But now Crepes on Cole has a special getaway vibe for me. Parking on the weekends sucks, but good to go on weekdays.
author: Charlene L.

description:
In the vast sea of crepe joints in the city: I recommend finding another. 

I saw another review that was the same complaint as mine: AWFUL SERVICE.

I recently graduated from college and moved here for a job and saw the restaurant while I was on the N. I LOVE crepes and had a great experience at a restaurant in Nob Hill. 

Well my parents were in town helping me move and when we got into the restaurant we kind of looked around for directions on whether to seat ourselves or wait to be seated. We kind of looked over to the girls at the counter for some indication and out of nowhere, with an annoyed look on her face, the hostess (I'm assuming) rudely calls out "You have to come to the counter!" as though we were SUCH idiots for not knowing to do so. 

When we approached the counter the staff there looked annoyed that we had to actually look at the menu for a bit and didn't know RIGHT AWAY what we wanted when it was clear we'd never been there. Then when we'd ordered and were getting our coffees, my parents and I started talking amongst ourselves but I could actually hear them talking about us and how "irritating" we'd been: "Oh my god, it's so annoying when people don't get it..."

I've had better food - it definitely wasn't worth the money and the self-serve coffee was burnt. To be honest, I might have had a better impression of the place if the waitstaff (I'm sorry the BEHIND-THE-COUNTER-staff) didn't sour the whole experience. 

It should never be the customer's problem if you don't like your job. 

These ladies were, for lack of a more accurate word, BITCHY, and for no good reason, and Bitchy doesn't taste good on crepes.
author: Megan S.

description:
In order to raise the awareness of the importance of a potato as food in developing nations, the United Nations declared 2008 the International Year of the Potato.

Someone should bring this to the attention to the cooks at Crepes on Cole because their abysmal spud preparation seems to be shouting a giant "f*ck you, world!" and slapping the U.N. in its face.  Have they really not noticed their garbage bins overflowing with these sad, uneaten tubers whose lives were prematurely and needlessly cut off?

The vegetable which has saved civilization after civilization deserves better than to be unearthed from their slumber, brutally ravaged by knives, then disrespected by unskilled cooks.  

My boyfriend and I went to Crepes on Cole because the line was too long at Zazie, and after waiting for half an hour in the hot sun, we were hungry enough to eat garbage.  Be careful what you ask for!  ICK.
author: Jenny K.

description:
My friend and I made a detour into Crepes on Cole on our way to do some tourist shopping in Haight/Ashbury, and it was pretty cool.

It had a very attractive front, probably the reason why I had the sudden impulse to get a crepe when we were clearly on a time crunch.

The place itself is very charming, has a home-y feel to it. A good place to get a small snack and spend the afternoon at, browsing the web or reading your favorite book. 

It has a very large variety of selections from breakfast crepes to dessert crepes, and out of these awesome selections, we decided to try the strawberry-chocolate crepe. It was so delicious, and I wish we had a chance to try out some of their other crepes, but unfortunately, we had to run.

I'd definitely come back and try out their other crepes if I'm ever in the city.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Late Saturday afternoon and waking up with fuzzy memories from the night before... couple gals decide to take me to the fabulous Zazzie.

One problem... Zazzie is closed for remodeling. For the love -I'm starving and the last thing I could think about was finding some place else to go eat.

Thank you god! Crepes on Cole was on a hop skip and a jump away. Even with the lack of bacon on the menu I settled on the New Mexico Scrabble. For all that is holy in this world... its DAMN good. That and all you can drink coffee. I said peace out to my hangover and hello to my food coma. 

Lost a star because its cash only. Seriously, I hate cash only places. Requires FAR too much thinking. That and every person who came in to get in line slammed into me. I get it. I'm 5'11 but I'm not freaking invisible!!!
author: Nancy B.

description:
Great weekend brunch spot...I like the SF benedict they serve, and have heard good reviews about their goat cheese crepes and tofu scramble. They succeed in passing off a cinammon stick with hot apple juice as apple cider, but the overall friendly service and reasonably priced good food make up for the faux cider :) 
Remember to take cash with you - they don't accept cards.
author: Shweta V.

description: My chicken pesto crepe was kind of bland, but still good. Others among my party had sandwiches (the chicken sandwich looked to die for!) and everybody was relatively happy with the price, amount of food and quality of the food. Would love to go back for dessert crepes.
author: christine c.

description:
Somehow in my 48 hours in SF I managed to hit 3 crepe places.
This was the best one, The menu is extensivem the dtaff is friendly, and they stay open late on the weekends (especially for a place that serves light fare)

This place proves anything and everything can go into a crepe. Make it hearty keep it light. get it at COC, and you'll get it done right.
author: Becki W.

description:
Oh the hand-wringing and exclamations of violated expectations surrounding the quality of the crepes at Crepes on Cole.  Relax.  One can still have a perfectly pleasant meal here, and to enjoy this place, do yourself a favor and stake out a window seat, let the periodic passing of the N-Judah rumble through your body, and remind yourself how lucky you are that you can sit here thinking gentle, holier-than-thou thoughts about how these crepes are simply ho-hum, which they are.  Let the irony of these small blessings wash over you, for in far away places like Overland Park, Kansas, and Louisville, KY, where bagels are still somewhat of a novelty, let alone crepes (contact with these exotic dishes is pretty much limited to watching Rachel Ray eat them on the Food Network), most people would find the offerings from Crepes on Cole to be pretty tasty.

Forget about whether you're going to get a rockstar crepe here.  You're not.  But that's not the point.  What you will get is a relaxed meal, with perfectly good, if not outstanding food, and you'll eat it in a clean, comfortable environment with warm, genuinely friendly service, in a great neighborhood, in a great city.
author: Hugh B.

description:
Fresh, fast, friendly, great for solo or with a group of any size, open long hours, and affordable.  I sometimes run into the owner when he is out taking a break (usually going for walks around the neighborhood) and feel good about giving him my money.

The flavors are nothing fancy or exotic, but ingredients are good quality, dishes are straightforward and the portions are almost too big (thank goodness they let me replace the bread and potato side with more salad or fruit - I could never eat such a large meal)! I love the omelet with salsa, pesto chicken sandwich, and the greek salad.  There is a broad menu and you can make your own combinations, so everyone I've brought here has been able to find something to eat, whether they are kosher, vegan, cutting carbs, or just plain picky.

I've held meetings here, had heart to heart talks with friends, read in a sunny window spot, and frequently take out of town guests here for breakfast.  For such a popular spot, I've never had to wait long and by some miracle a table always opens up before my food is served.  The constant rotation of artwork can be scary at times, but every once in a while they get some good stuff up. It is casual enough for runner's clubs to plop down fresh from the streets at a big table for hours.

I love that it is simple, healthy food in a very neighborly atmosphere.
author: Jenny W.

description:
My recent trip to SF was somewhat hindered by the fact that I arrived with a cold.  The ensuing windstorm didn't really help, but Crepes on Cole did.  

On our way to the Haight, my friend and I decided to hop off of Muni and grab a bite to eat here.  I opted for one of their soups, which was absolutely delish.  It really hit the spot and soothed my slightly sore throat.  The tea helped as well.  This might be TMI, but after all of those liquids, I was in need of a restroom, which can be hard to find in the city, but this fine establishment also boasts a very clean loo if you're in need.  

The prices were also very reasonable, and I liked the cozy atmosphere inside.  The only downer is that it's cash only.  Buyer beware.
author: bridget h.

description:
I love this place. When I lived in Cole Valley, I used to eat here almost every single weekend - but now it's only on special occasions. I went this weekend and got my favorite crepe - the bon jour - with chicken apple sausage, and veggies - delicious. Crepes come with salad and potatoes and everything is really fresh. 

When they ask you what your name is - just say it's Steve. They call our your name when your food is ready and when the guy says Steve he says it like: eeeeeeeeeeessssssssssssssssssttttttteeeeeeeeeeeeeveeeeeeeeee....this happened like 3 or 4 years ago and my friends and I are still saying it....so funny - at least to me :)
author: meagan m.

description:
Good News...

Love the Florentine Crepe: cheddar, cottage cheese and spinach sans the onions.  Comfy neighborhood spot and a big plus for being open on New Year's Day.

Bad News:

While engaged in conversation with my friend, the server takes our plates when we hadn't finished eating!  When I notice, she's walking away plates stacked with her finger in my mimosa glass.  I look at my friend, "She took our plates!".

I follow her to the counter and politely tell her that we are not yet finished.  She looks at me with surprise and says, "There was nothing on your plates."  While pointing to the plate, I say "There's still potatoes left.".  Then she lifts up my plate and shows me my friend's plate with...her food still on it!!!  

I also tell her that I was still drinking the mimosa.  She fishes out the glass from the kitchen and holds up it up displaying the half ounce left, "THIS is all that's left," and motions to hand it to me as if I would still want to drink it when her finger was in it.  (Granted it wasn't much but, the fact was, I was not finished.)

Luckily, the man at the register (the owner, I believe) asks what was going on while a few other staff members are listening.  He tells her to give me another mimosa after he hears our conversation.  She also gives me a plate of potatoes with, I feel, a bit of reluctance.  However, I don't understand why she was bothered because there was still food there and I was still eating:(
author: michelle s.

description:
I dig this spot.

Some of the reviewers were actually COMPLAINING about the big portions? Really?

My crepe was nice and large with tasty potatoes. Food came out quick!

It's nice to watch Muni roll on by. Big windows!

My only gripe is that it's very similar to many other spots in the city. I don't really dine here that often because I am lured away by much more interesting cuisine in the neighborhood. But, when I do dine here, I'm pretty satisfied with the solid meal they deliver, which is big enough to turn into 2 meals via leftovers.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Overall its ok. The coffee was not good. Bitter and burned tasting. So much so it covered up the mocha I was having.

The fruit bowl I had was delicious. Delicious.

The atmosphere is nice. I haven't been in the building since it was The Other. They did a nice job with the interior.

But $8 for coffee and fruit seems a little pricey.
author: Marz W.

description:
This is a great neighborhood Cole Valley joint and is the perfect place for weekend brunch.  We also like coming here for coffee or beer late night when we have work to do and don't want to be stuck in the house.  On weekends the place can get extremely busy but the turnover at the tables is generally fast so if you take a little stroll and come back you should be fine.

My favorites are the basil crepe and the french (freeedom) toast  with fresh berries.

The service is quite fast and they have outdoor seating, which gets extra points from me.  It can get kind of noisy when the place is filled but it's not intolerable by any means.

Recommended!
author: Steve B.

description: The breakfast here was decent and of moderate price but I was not impressed with anything that I could not find in most any other breakfast restaurant in this city.  The latte was a little weak and the potatoes could have been cooked a little less because mine were a little mushy but the omelette was good.   Overall its ok and I might return if I was nearby.
author: Matthew R.

description:
I completely do not understand the massive appeal of this place. Brunch is a madhouse for the same boring-ass, TIRED, crepes/omelets/whatever menu that every other place has.  After the brunch rush however, it can be a pleasant place to get some lunch. Not spectacular, but nice. You can watch the N-Judah go by or waste time while doing laundry across the street (usually the only times I've been here are while doing laundry). 

Coffee is positively awful & almost always burnt. The Illy name is basically meaningless in this instance. And they are cash only, which is very annoying.
author: Maria D.

description:
for a crepes, egg and sandwich plate this place is pretty outstanding.
The service is effervescent and thorough.
We had lots of details in each of our orders and we were confused more than they were.
They have an abundance of choices to put in their omelettes and an abundance of energy in their staff who operate with little room
author: Sean S.

description:
lol, I didn't know a movie was filmed here, 40 days and 40 nights! This is my first time here and i always eat a lot of crepes!!!! A very nice COLE VALLEY neighborhood hang out which is sometimes crowded and very popuar with the locals. Again, this is a nice place to bring your kids and your babies (hint hint to my friends who live in SUNNYVALE). 

Like the Squat and Gobble and the Crepevine, you order at the counter and they give you a number on a stick, and then you choose your table. lol, I wonder who's behind creating that colorful chalk board that I see everywhere at crepe restaurants?
author: herm p.

description:
More like CRAPS ON COLE...

Honestly, this place sucks...  Walk a few blocks and go to Squat & Gobble on Haight & Masonic if you really want a crepe...  The food is just plain awful and overpriced...

Also, the guy that manages the place puts up this facade of politeness, but when you hear him talk to his employees he's a f%$king d&%k...  He's also pretty creepy...

Stay Away
author: Alexander T.

description:
Chi latte was good.  Savory crepe was bland, not enough cheese. Also kinda expensive to boot.  Did get a nice big side salad with it though.  My friend got the Greek salad which was huge and lots of lettuce, but not enough of the "Greek" stuff.

Nice dark wood decor, great people watching counter.  Big round tables for groups.  

One obnoxious 20-something gal talking loudly into cell phone for 30 minutes while she sat alone eating lunch....we weren't even sitting near her and she was too loud.  I know, the employees can't really do much about someone being mildly annoying, I just wanted to rant.
author: Victoria M.

description: Don't know what I was thinking the first time I went here, but have been back MANY more times since and I am still amazed at how great the pancakes are! It's hard to find a better pancake anywhere! And the french toast is also the bomb! I've since met the owners, who are very caring and friendly (maybe they were absent the first time I was there, or maybe it's changed hands?). The artwork on the walls is always changing and nice to look at. Comfortable space and very kid friendly, too. A+
author: Yodel A.

description: Was decent, the chicken crepe i had would of benefitted from thinner slicing to ensure more flavor distribution.
author: H F.

description:
This place is great.  I tried it for an alternative Easter brunch, and will definitely come back.  The food is great and the place is very open and airy.  Prime location to walk people walking up and down Cole.

It's cash only, so pick it up ahead of time, because the ATM across the street goes down a lot.
author: Denise V.

description:
My husband and I enjoyed a wonderful breafast here when we were in town last weekend.  We both ordered the Chicken Pesto crepe and it was delicious.  It's made with provolone cheese, onions, pesto, chicken, mushrooms and tomatoes.  Along with the crepe you also get a side salad with a vinaigrette dressing and a side of potatoes. The portions were really huge.  

The servers are really friendly here too.  The only negative is that they take cash only. 

I would definitely dine here again when I am in town.
author: Rowena D.

description:
This place will always be one of my fondest memories of when I first moved to San Francisco and one of my roommates recommended this place to me. Oh, and apparently it was in the movie '40 Days and 40 Nights.' Movie, so-so, restaurant, good.

I've only had the savory crepes here and from what I remember, they were delicious. The prices are not too bad either; Anywhere between $7-12 depending on what you order. It's a very casual place where you go up ,order, pay and find a seat, then they bring your order to your table.
author: Cindy W.

description: location is nice, but my friend found a bug in her salad, which seems to have happened on several occasions based on several other reviews. the owner came by to apologize and replaced her dish but appetite was lost. i think he should have just offered her a refund. needless to say, won't be going back!
author: Uali M.

description:
The Good.
Perfect spot to meet a friend for lunch or coffee.  It's located right on the N line, and it's fairly centralized, plus you can walk off your food + coffee to Haight.  Plus 40 Days/40 Nights was filmed here. 

The Bad
I was disappointed by the thickness of the crepes. Personally I'm a fan of thin and crispy crepes, the crepes here are more like pancakes.  Not good.

The Ugly
Since it is right off the N-Line it is almost impossible to find a place to sit during rush hour.
author: Brian H.

description: A complete waste of money. Coffee was bad, my wet mushy omelette was worse ( the new Mexico). I lost my appetite just by looking at it. Don't do it!
author: Iche S.

description:
My fav is the Hawaiian, it's the only place i order! My mess with perfection? 

Well I take it back, I had the Mediterranean salad once, huge!!! very good.. I like that they're not stingy with their servings. 

Good service, fast and friendly
author: Monica S.

description:
The fruit bowls contain more than two types of fruit! Strawberries, kiwi, mango, raspberries, blueberries, they've got it all! I was so impressed that they were fresh and not syrupy or straight-from-the-can. 

Ordering from the front, I saw that pancakes were about $7.85 or something and I wondered, "All I get are pancakes and it's over seven bucks?" But I got them anyway and it's worth it!

I had the blueberry pancakes when I went, actually, since I was craving breakfast food. They were two giant, fluffy cakes of deliciousness filled with blueberries. My friend had the buckwheat pancakes, and they were great as well, with a rough texture and slightly nutty. We also got a side of peanut butter which was chunky (the best kind) and left quite satisfied.

They lose a star because it's kind of hectic in there, with all the people and a find-your-own-seat vibe. They are quick, though, and it's actually kind of nice to be able to just get up and go after the meal since it's already been paid for!

Oh also, I'm sure this has been mentioned already but just to be sure it's a CASH ONLY place.
author: Anna H.

description:
This place gets one whole extra star for Sam, the uber friendly owner.  He was working the register when my homegirl Anne and I went there for lunch on Saturday, and he's such a sweetie. He made sure to introduce himself, find out if we lived in the neighborhood, and even came out to our table later to make sure we had enough coffee. He adds a warm personal touch to what would otherwise be a fairly generic crepe house.

The food is good- you'll get a solid crepe or omelet here, which will be tasty while you eat it and which you will promptly forget after you walk out the door. Prices are in the $7 -$10 range for plates that include sides of both potatoes and salad. The potatoes are served with caramelized red onions which is a delicious little touch. The coffee is great and you get as many free refills as you can take. 

Be warned this is a cash only joint.
author: Angie R.

description:
For some reason, I'm always more dedicated to writing scathing yelp reviews than positive ones. But the fact that I'm actually sitting here and typing this must surely show my dedication to how much I enjoy this place.

I like crepes. I like French crepes and I like Japanese crepes. I've never been much for American bastardized crepes, but sometimes it's just too late to go downtown or to Japantown for a crepe so I go here. Only a few blocks away, I usually bring the dog and sit outside while my boyfriend orders for me. Usually the servers bring out a small container of water for the dog which never gets old for me, so I'm constantly impressed. I've never gotten sass for sitting outside with the dog, which is also surprising.

But sometimes it's too cold to sit outside, so we call up and order for pick-up. One time we ordered thirty minutes before closing time and got there almost five minutes 'til 11PM. The guy who ran the place (assuming the owner) said something like, "We try to get ready for closing twenty or thirty minutes before closing time, but we thought maybe you'd show up so we stuck around a bit." He was really sweet about it even though I'm sure he had a long day and wanted to go home.

This place satisfies my crepe cravings (which are often) without being too far away or expensive. Sure, the crepes aren't authentic and sometimes the potatoes that come with the crepe are kinda tough, but I can't argue with convenience. Their mimosas are okay too.
author: Grace-Monday B.

description:
I really dig the atmosphere here. It's quiet and warm, perfect for sitting down and having a cup of coffee over good conversation or blending into the background and getting some work done.

The food and coffee are ok. Nothing great as most of the reviews have already stated. Free refills on the coffee are a nice touch though.

My biggest complaint is the lack of wifi. Come on guys, it's 2011. You have the space to support more customers. You would be a beacon of light in the wifi-less main strip of Cole street. I would certainly spend more money and time here.
author: Ryan H.

description: I say two and a half stars.  I have definitely had better egg's benedict before, but on the plus side beer is $2.50.  I would go back again, but I can think of much better places to go for brunch.
author: Eric H.

description: Great place for breakfast, lunch and dinner.  The food is always fresh and the service is good.
author: Arron F.

description: The prices on the menu listed here are not accurate. I went to Crepes on Cole because I thought it was a little cheaper than similar places like Crepevine, but it was actually more expensive (everything is about a dollar more). It was really nice inside--fairly empty and sunny--and there was nothing wrong with it aside from the cost. But since it does cost a little more and is similar to all the other creperies, I probably won't be coming back.
author: Amanda V.

description: Really love this place. I'm vegan and they let me create my own meal of vegetables and pesto. Lovely. And the coffee was great.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Not too bad. Our gracious host in SF who lives nearby brought us here for a hungover Saturday brunch. It feels cozy and homey and comfortable.  It's fast-casual, so you order at the counter from the chalkboard menu (they have paper menus all over the place so no worries) and sit down until your order is brought to you. 

I glugged 2 sub-par mimosas as I was the only one of us sans-hangover. I had a horrible time deciding which of the many delicious-sound repes to get, but I think all 3 of us ordered the Cole Valley crepe. The portions are quite substantial. The crepe itself was standard omelet-sized AND served with a small salad of dressed field greens AND potatoes seasoned w/rosemary. The crepe and its contents (I wish I could remember, avocado, mushrooms, cheese?) seemed good and fresh enough. BF ordered the minestrone and that wasn't too bad either. 

I always love going to a casual place that has a bit of bustle and being able to order, get fresh food, and get out in a relatively short amount of time. Added bonus-they had a bunch of copies of some local doggie newspaper!
author: Joan K.

description: Food's unremarkable but Joey "Hi YOU doin'" Tribiani's uncle works here.
author: Inigo M.

description: Like a little Swiss ski lodge. Not a bad place. Not insanely good either. Crepes are a little on the soggy and expensive side. Not the most inventive, but solid.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I like this place for a couple of reasons

1. They have a good selection of fillings to make your own crepe (sometimes I feel like I am more creative that what places have to offer, it's true).
2. They have good hot loose leaf teas served in wonderful little pots.
3. Good outdoor sidewalk seating for warm sunny days.
4. They let you sit there to read and hang out long before your meal is done.
5. The staff is very friendly. 

Good neighborhood joint for a day spent at a caf.
author: Alicia J.

description:
I ended up here yesterday because i had some time to kill before a doctor's appointment at UCSF.  

The staff is definitely friendly and helpful.  They put my order in for me even though I didn't have cash and run out to an ATM for a refill.  

The crepes themselves didn't excite me too much.  They didn't have the crispness to them like the ones I've had in France.   As another reviewer said, they are a little too thick here.
author: Beau G.

description:
This place is a good deal in a neighborhood area with some nice options.  It's more laid back and chill that the other spots around here and perfect for a laid back late breakfast of off-hours lunch.

The prices are decent, and the food quality is good.  Nothing out of the ordinary though.  Bonus for being a local business!
author: Gene X.

description:
In general, I think these crepe places are all the same. The first one I ever went to was the Crepevine on College Ave. in Oakland maybe 7 years ago and I really liked it. The crepe thing was novel and the food, although not all stellar, was satisfying. I have to say that Crepes on Cole may be the worst of any of these crepe chains that I've tried. 

While it serves the "usual" crepes, I think the items inside their savory crepes tend to be undercooked (mushrooms especially... if they still crunch, it's not a good sign). My BF likes omelettes and will eat most breakfast food and he had a hard time eating the omelette at Crepes on Cole. Apparently the eggs were browned (eww), the mushrooms undercooked (surprise, surprise), and the whole thing generally unappetizing. The salads at these crepe places tend to be an afterthought sparsely coated with vinaigrette and Crepes is no exception.

The dining area always strikes me as slightly dark, which seems incompatible with light California crepes. Maybe that's just me... I'm pretty sure if I went there right now and had a Nutella crepe it would be delicious, but let's face it, Nutella straight from the container is 5 stars.
author: Amanda C.

description: Sorry...I must not be a total food snob. Geez yelpers...why would you eat at a crepe place if you hate crepes? We found this place on our way to Outside Lands. The staff was friendly and helpful. The food was good and fresh. They had a nice selection of beers. What's the problem? I wasn't expecting Thomas Keller here. It was a nice place to stop for a bite with friends.
author: Victoria A.

description: Horrible customer service! I ordered a cheddar, egg and spinach crepe . They forgot the chesse, when I told them, they just slapped some cheese slices in it and it looked like they microwaved the crepe, it destroyed the spinach and made it look and taste nasty. When we told them they were not very helpful, just saying "what do you want me to do about it?" But they did provide more potatoes, but they weren't worth the 10dollars I paid for my meal. I just really wanted a cheesy crepe! :(
author: Ms. O.
