description: The straberry crepe was really suggy. I'm a fan of crepes and this so far was the worst straberry crepe I had.
author: Angelica P.

description:
Good food and quick service. Most importantly, I found the staff to be really friendly and accomodating, which is just so rare these days.

I really wish my neighborhood had a place like this - I'd be there all the time!
author: Walter L.

description:
Food: Reminds me of Crepevine on Irving St. The menu is pretty much the same! I ordered a plain crepe with just cheese and onions which also came with a side of salad and potatos. Food was not bad

Price: The prices are not bad here and you get a nice plate full of food.

Service: Service was okay...not very friendly 

Location: Located right on Cole across from EOS and near Burger Meister. Street parking is tough but the N Judah and 43 bus runs right by it.

Atmosphere: Indoor and outdoor seating, not bad but there were a bunch of flies flying around inside.
author: Miss H K.

description:
So my favorite thing to enjoy when I don't mind getting fat is a dessert crepe. .. I saw this place from the N-Judah and and decided to stop in one day. I ordered a nutella with banana crepe and I loved it! The crepe was warm, the wiped cream was served on the side (without me asking) so it wasn't all poured over the place, and the staff was quite friendly. I went with a friend on a Sunday afternoon and it wasn't busy and actually pretty quite!! 

Minus one star because the crepe did have a hint of onion taste in a few places.... clean the griddle all the way maybe? Also b/c I don't usually carry cash and they only take cash.... connivence of a card? These two reasons though won't keep me from visiting again.... very soon!!!
author: Richard M.

description: got pastrami sandwich on sourdough... pretty good. it came with salad and potatoes. thank you, i did not know that would happen :)
author: Drawing G.

description: Don't even get me started.....  owner refused to refund after they forgot to make my order.  I had to leave.  I had to raise my voice to demand a refund.
author: Christopher F.

description:
I went here today for Father's Day with my parents.  I've always had a good meal here.  The crepes are perfect for a brunch or lunch.  I had the Bon Jour (goat cheese, eggs, onions, chicken apple sausage and bell peppers) which went well with the mimosa with fresh squeezed oj.  The goat cheese and chicken-apple sausage really stood out for great flavor.  
The parents went with the Cole Valley and Pesto, which got great reviews.  

We walked right in, ordered and got a table immediately.  Cole Valley was packed for Father's Day but CoC was really fast, comfortable and, most importantly, tasty.
author: Chris M.

description:
Came here after still feeling hungry post-EOS which is across the street.  What a delightful little place!  Their crepes are generous and delicious.  Cozy atmosphere, and the staff are very friendly.  We had dessert crepes and they definitely did not disappoint.  I would be interested in coming back to try some of their savory crepes.

Beware of rampant spelling mistakes all over the menu.
author: I-Chant C.

description: My friend took me here. I had the Chicken Pesto crepe. I thought it was good. He had the Nutella Banana. That was better. This is a casual place with lots of cheese and eggs. I did not see any beef on the regular menu, but saw it listed on the specials on the board out on the sidewalk when I was leaving. I think I would enjoy trying the pancakes, granola and salads on future trips. The salads looked large, so I'd find someone to share it with. I think I would prefer this place for dessert crepes rather than a main entrée.
author: Lia H.

description:
I wrote my first review of this place 4 years ago. Gee wiz where does the time go? I still like this place but I've expanded on my breakfast/brunch spots. Their crepes are good, but not the best. Their blueberry pancakes used to be out of this world but the last couple of times I've gone they were overdone. New cooks? Still good, but I don't like mine that dark.

I went here today with a friend and our pancakes were very well done. Hers moreso than mine so she sent them back and said they were too dark. They brought her a new batch and they were still really brown. 

I used to marvel how they they were cooked to perfection: done in the middle but not too dark. Not anymore. Next time I go I'll tell them when I order that I want them *light* and hopefully that will fix the problem. 

Oh, the coffee is really good here. But it's annoying that they don't take cards. Everyone takes cards!
author: Holly E.

description:
Them is some tasty crepes. Certainly better than what's going on over at Haight. So it is worth the walk, though there are plenty of places to eat. 

A great spot to grab a bite to eat and work on things, or just eat and run.
author: John S.

description: Found this based solely on an impulsive "Yelp" search.  We were killing time around Haight waiting to drive to the airport on a Sunday morning and just strolled up Cole, waited in line and were pleasantly surprised.  Great food.  Average wait and service.  If you're not in a hurry, it's worth the stroll.
author: David V.

description: The waitress let my soup sit on the counter for 5 minutes. The chicken and rice soup was too salty and served to me cold. When I asked the waitress to warm it up she rolled her eyes and proceeded to loudly talk about me with her colleague. She proceeded to talk with her friend about some book instead of helping customers. You're better off going to Crepevine on Irving and 8th avenue or burgermeister across the street.
author: Lia B.

description:
A contingent of us local parents meet up here on Friday mornings.  It's a roomy enough space for all of us, and our kids, and all their gear (strollers, etc.)  And there's a changing table in the bathroom, which makes it so much kid friendly than most places in the neighborhood.  One of the owners, Sam, is always there and makes us feel right at home.  I take that back: it's like home, but better, since I don't have to wash the dishes.  My kid needs some avocado slices to abate the onslaught of an impending meltdown?  Sure, Sam will say, no problem. 

In terms of the fare, I've had lots of different savory veggie options, all of which were quite good.  I've only had one dessert crepe - the apple and cheese one -- which was divine and large enough to share.
author: Susan L.

description: Consistently good food. A place you can count on for a tasty breakfast/brunch/lunch or even dessert crepe! It won't blow your mind, but it's great that it won't blow your wallet either. Yum!
author: Bae L.

description: This place is great! I love the New Mexico...it's amazing! My friend ended up trying the french toast and they were also AMAZING!! I definitely recommend this place for breakfast and the price is average.
author: G H.

description:
The crepes here are not anything special, and a little smaller than other places. They are good, and tasty, but I wouldn't make an effort to eat these particular crepes, say over any other average crepery.

However, the service here makes all the difference.

I, on occasion, am that person who orders something off the menu, but makes so many changes, they may as well create a new dish and name it after me. Knowing this, I really shouldn't let someone else place my order as I dash into the potty. When I came out and inevitably discovered that my order was placed wrong, I tried to catch someone to let them know I needed changes. Albeit slightly embarrassing that everyone working at the place is now aware of my aversion to tomatoes, they however didn't make me feel like the p.i.t.a. that I am. With concern, and I think a tinge of amusement they made me another crepe to my "needs" and were beyond pleasant about it!

Nice, nice service.
author: Dixon T.

description:
After doing laundry at the ghettomat, I decided to take my chances with a large Greek Salad w/chicken from Crepes on Cole.

Since I had my thongs and panties in my hamper, I figured I should eat my greens at home, so I got it to go.  Was I surprised when I got home!  The box was BURSTING with salad!  Can we say salad explosion?!  Big leafy greens, thick chunks of feta, olives (with the pits, so be careful). red onions, and cucumbers PLUS nicely sized cuts of hot steamin' piles.....of chicken.  It was way too much for my waifish frame, so I decided to save some for lunch the next day. 

Did it hold up, you ask?  Even with the light vinaigrette, it did!  I was able to get two meals out of one.  

Convenient and reasonably priced.  My fav combo.
author: Paul D.

description:
Saturday afternoon. Hungover at 4pm. Haven't eaten yet. Not sure what happened last night, but I know that if I don't eat soon it's going to be bad. I get in the car & drive around in the rain & wind up in Cole Valley, somehow. Through the wipers, I see a shining light.

One large bottle of San Pelligrino & a Chicken Curry Crepe later, & I left feeling like a million bucks. Okay, a thousand. Or maybe a hunnid fitty. Better than when I came, definitely. It's a little on the expensive side, but it'll hit the spot.
author: Pete J.

description:
Really good place for simple breakfast and lunch food.  Went there a few times while visiting friends recently and was pleased with the portions.  I can't say too much about the food since our menu selections were minimal (turkey sandwich and a bagel with cucumber and tomato) but what we had and saw/smelled was d-lish!

Good place to grab a cup of coffee and hang out too.
author: Anna T.

description:
AT the N-Judah Carl/Cole stop. I like to go there after work since I use the MUNI to commute from downtown to my home in outer Sunset.

Excellent crêpes, very original fillings.

Only missing point: they don't serve cider. Cider is the traditional drink in Normandy (crêpe is the traditional food there) and it usually goes with crêpes very well.
author: Yanik C.

description: I love crepes and this place used to be good. It has definitely gone downhill. They served me terrible cold coffee and when I sent it back they changed it to terrible hot coffee. The honey lemon blintz didn't have any honey or lemon. It was just bad with applesauce on top. We sent that back and tried the raspberry blintz per our server's recommendation. Yucky. We couldn't eat it and left. Really disappointed since I had been coming to this place every so often for many years. I won't be back.
author: Lynn G.

description:
I'd give Crepes on Cole 3-1/2 stars if I could. My husband, on the other hand, he'd fly to the moon for their coconut-whatever pancakes. I'm no expert to begin with, and I almost always get an omelette anyway, so I can't say for sure how the crepes stack up.

One thing you should know is that every Sunday afternoon whole hosts of people run around town working up a good, nasty sweat and then bop in here. I would never dream of sitting down to a full-fledged brunch in my running clothes, but maybe I'm old-fashioned. Nope; I think my mama raised me right. :)
author: Christina S.

description:
Strangely tasty, and despite its mediocre food, I would often land myself here almost every Sunday for brunch. Ze fresh pressed orange and carrot juices add a very healthy touch to an all-too-Americanized meal. When I want crepes, I'll skip across neighborhoods if I have to, just to visit this joint.

The crowd here is quixotic San Francisco, a wonderful mix of everything under the sun. In this restaurant, peoplewatching is just pure fun. Don't be afraid to bring your laptop, your stilettos, or your baby. You'll fit right in.

A note on their curry crepes: Do not expect a velvety smooth paste inside. Instead, they dump curry powder into the crepe. When my lunchmate took his first bite, it was so shocking that he almost sprayed it out all over me. Yikes.
author: Daniel C.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to take my mom out for lunch. Often we'll meet here when I am visiting the city and eat delicious crepes and hang out for  a bit.

The crepes here are the best I have found in the city, always fresh ingredients which are always cooked all the way (none of that half-ass crepevine stuff). The Basil crepe is by far my favorite. The only down side here is that you really get more food than you can comfortably eat. I've yet to finish all my side potatoes even though they are so good (again, fully cooked unlike crepevine)

They always have really good coffee drinks and hot chocolate on a cold day. I would never recommend eating outside, the N goes by which is pretty noisy, not to mention by being on the outskirts of haight, it's a little... dirty at times. Maybe it's just me, but the height street stench isn't always the more appetizing. 

When I lived in S.F. and was in High School, I used to really enjoy coming here and getting a late lunch and working on school work. It's a very nice quiet atmosphere, and really only gets loud and hectic at lunchtime or weekend mornings.
author: Allyson S.

description:
If you enjoy eating your weekend brunch next to sweaty joggers, then this is the place to be.  They're mostly unavoidable as they seem to have a convention here every Saturday and Sunday.
[1 star on the weekends]

If, however, like me, you don't enjoy sitting next to marathoners whose tank tops and shorts are still wet... I suggest coming during the week.  The food (mediocre at best) actually tastes better when it's not jam-packed.  Next.
[3 stars during the week]
author: kat i.

description:
Funny. For a place called 'crepes on cole' their crepes are GARBAGE! Oddly enough though, they make GREAT salads! Their greek salad kills. I'd drive from the mission just for that. 

I really like the place, not just for their food, watching the manager dude shamelessly flirt with every chick who walks in there is amusing and disgusting all at the same time. I'm pretty sure its why they have such trouble holding on to their help.

But, a damn fide salad indeed!

Bully!
author: Lord Mandrake P.

description:
I think they are misspelling this... isn't it Craps on Cole?  

We have given the place a couple opportunities and, alas, it flunked each and every chance to impress.   For example, just tonight, we were there and all I wanted was overpriced coffee with too much millk (AKA non-fat latte).  It  was bitter and burnt.  Sent back.  Next one was worse, if you can believe it.

My dining companion was doing just that - dining.  But not for long!  He ate the chicken sandwich for as long as civility and his taste buds could endure.  Unfortunately that didn't take him all he way thru to anything like a clean plate.  Now that's just a waste of money.  

So if you were wondering why there were outdoor seats at Crepes and nowhere else... wonder no more.
author: Stephen M.

description:
I'd been dying to stop by here cause I always go by it when I'm on the N. So naturally, I had a day off, time to kill, and a friend who wanted to try the place out. Place didn't accept cards so I had to run across the street to a laundry mat and take cash out (a nice fee to use that atm and a fee from my bank as well)

I ordered a smoke tofu breakfast scramble, which was absolutely delicious.

What was not so delcious, having a slice of melon served to me with a nice huge bite already taken out of it.
author: Leila N.

description: I never realized I needed a neighborhood crepe place until I moved to Cole Valley. On weekend mornings when the line is inevitably too long at Zazie I'll end up here and be 75% as satisfied with 10% of the waiting time. I'm not an economist or statistician or whoever it is that measures things like that, but it seems like a good tradeoff. In fact, Crepes On Cole has become my default choice for a quick cheap meal when I don't want to cook. I haven't had anything bad yet, and the Bon Jour crepe is fantastic.
author: Mark A.

description: Had a delicious artichoke heart, tomato, avocado and swiss omelet with a double espresso here this morning.  All in all, I got exactly what I ordered, not the most memorable; the 4th star is for general ambiance, plus efficiency behind the counter.
author: Brandon C.

description:
I really like this place, reminds me of my favorite place in Davis (Crepeville- actually the owner of Crepeville used to own Crepes on Cole).  I know this because the owner of Crepes on Cole is really friendly and talks to his customers.  

I actually don't eat Crepes but everything else is really good especially the granola and fruit, bagels, egg dishes, potatoes, and coffee! 

Definitely a go-to breakfast place in Cole Valley!  They only accept cash- but it's SF so get used to it.
author: Karen B.

description: Breakfast with the girls and one of them suggests this place.  Parking was super hard to find but this place rocks.  I had the Fisherman's Wharf crepe (havarti, red onions, smoked salmon, capers, & dill) total total total yum-o!  It came with a fresh side salad and roasted potatoes.  I loved it.  I also tried their Bon Jour crepe (goat cheese, onion, eggs, chicken apple sausage, bell peppers & mushrooms), this was good too but loved the Fisherman's Wharf one better.  This place was super busy on a Sunday morning, looooong line but moves fairly quickly.  There's only one bathroom which is not too great.  Standing in that line was longer than standing in line to order your food.
author: Emy B.

description: Crepes are great. Duh!? But, they also have a variety of others such as omelletes and such. The place is spacious but no Wifi for all the coffee Wifi weekend afternoon seekers. Great location right in the heart of Cole Valley. Right off the N and walking distance to the Haight.
author: Eric R.

description:
Definitely not a traditional french crepe (try Ti Couz), but an easy, generally-pleasing place to meet friends for dinner. With a variety of options (savory crepes, sweet ones, salads, egg scrambles, sandwiches), we were all able to order something that struck our individual fancy. Prices seem high (crepes are $8+); but the portions are large. All on-tap beers are $3.75 (and that includes Guinness!). Interior atmosphere is much like a big coffee shop: nothing amazing, but it's easy to find a table. 

I wouldn't go out of my way to get here, but it's a totally plausible option if you're in the neighborhood. 

Cash Only.
author: Erin M.

description:
This venerable Cole Valley creperie has been packed for weekend brunches for at least ten years. I like their chicken pesto crepe, but I always ask for crispy potatoes, because they'll be soggy otherwise. Now crepes come with home fries and salad. Other that that innovation, the place still seems like it did seven years ago when I lived around the corner. Of course, the prices have gone up.

Lots of UCSF students and a mix of locals and regulars frequent the place. It's a more pleasant, less grungy vibe than the Squat and Gobble on Haight.
author: Timothy O.

description:
Yeah, I thought this place was pretty cool.  Good art.  It's surreal and pastel-like.  And the crepes are pretty good and have lots of different things in them.  The apple cider kind of sucked because the cinnamon sticks were kind of old and didn't smell like anything and it doesn't work if you try to use it as a straw.  Not that it should.

Coming from the Financial District, it's funny to see what the carefree quaint rich life is like as opposed to the stuck-up corporate rich life.  It's like the people are saying, "well, we're rich, but it's not like we really CARE about money.  We're here for the crepes."

Good crepes, good place.
author: Cassio P.

description:
When I first went here, I was unfamiliar with crepe places in san francisco and I thought this place was so unique. Sweet dessert crepes...savory crepes with home fries....cheddar filled crepes with apples and sour cream...huge salads. all good stuff.

But now that I've had a chance to settle in and live in san francisco, i have come to the conclusion that this place is like every other crepe place...crepevine included. yeah i said it.
author: Tin-Tin E.

description:
Both the sweet and the savory crepes are delicious!  They also have amazing beer specials, like $2.50 pints for good beer! 
 
I got the curry crepe last time and I would really recommend it!
author: Alexandra W.

description:
A cozy place to enjoy delicious crepes, in an atmosphere great for conversation.  Yummy espresso drinks made by friendly folks *to very precise specifications, if you need*...[my dining pal and I both requested a Mexican Hot Chocolate, Soy Mocha with extra whip.]

They do savory and dessert crepes equally well...I recommend the Basil Crepe and the Banana & Nutella Crepe, respectively.

Eat up and be well!
author: Beth G.

description:
Any of my SF friends can attest to being dragged two places with me on EVERY visit. Crepes for breakfast and El Far for dinner.
It just can't do wrong in my book. Every meal you order is great, the ambience is a perfect respite from bustling sf, and the soy mexican mocha is just a delight!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Love this spot....really good after a run in the park or a bike ride around the city.

Although the omelettes are good, the crepes are my favorite, especially the one with ham, cheese and teriyaki sauce...yum.

I think its really a bargain as well, as you get a side salad and potatoes, all for around $8.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Tomato soup was the best I've ever had.  It makes me want to be a soup-a-holic.  It makes me wish that I had some right now. It's cold, it's rainy outside, my BF is watching something really loud on TV and I'm stuck in this thought that if only I had some tomato soup, the world would be sunnier.

That was nearly as cheesy as some of the crepes I've seen here.

Is it just me or does $9 for a big thin pancake, folded over and with some sandwich fixings seem like a lot?  I think that's my Asian talking.  I can't help but think that it's a rather lot for the equivalent of a sandwich.  That I have to eat with a knife and fork.  It's so dainty.  So Refined.  

It's opened late for this neck of the woods.  Orien and I have studied there.  We're the two really stressed out looking law students that keep drinking tea, abuse highlighters and re-adjusting our headphones.  Too much noise, too much music, too much noise, too much music.  It never stops!!

I like the fact that it's right around the corner from my all time favorite sushi place in the world that makes my mouth jump with joy.  I also like the fact that they have a water spout right there and a pile of slightly clean plastic cups for you to help yourself.  The lemon wedges are there too!  

Tuna sandwich: delicious.  Re-kindled my love of mayo and fish.

Home fried potatoes: eh.  A bit mushy.  I always think these things are a bit mushy.  I want it caramelized with lots of garlic (practically raw), onions (also caramelized), sprinkled with a dollop of plain yogurt (tastes like sour cream but so much better for you), sprinkle of chives and green onions.  Strips of bacon are a plus.  

Salad: meh.  I ate it.  What does that say?  It says that it was better than the potatoes.  And it was green.  And I was feeling like it's about time I had something from the vegetable food group.  That was not deep fried.  

But I'm not judging.  As long as you stick to the tomato soup, you can't go wrong.
author: Christina C.

description: I got the salsa crepe and it was pretty good. I'd say it was a bit too cheesy and oily for my preference. You only get a small cup of coffee when you order coffee and refills are $1. Everyone I was with thought the food was pretty good though, and I'd be willing to come back and order something different.
author: Amy S.

description:
Two words:  1. Orange 2. Juice

If for no other reason whatsoever, stop by for a glass of what has to be just about the best OJ anywhere.  We once bought 22 large to-go cups for brunch.  Try this and you'll kiss Odwalla buh-bye...
author: Josh M.

description:
CASH ONLY**CASH ONLY**CASH ONLY!!!

luckily i had $21 in cash to pay for a 2-person meal (2 crepes and a mocha).  i like this place better than ti couz b/c it's more laidback and there's more stuff on the menu that appeals to me (buckwheat waffles!  omelettes!  fresh-squeezed OJ!).  yes, breakfast is my fave meal of the day.  each crepe comes with fabulous home-style potatoes and side salad w/vinaigrette.  
don't wait to be seated; go up to the cash register to order.
ppl seem to like to bring babies and kids here.  plus it's a great spot for cole valley ppl-watching (which, ok, might not sound super exciting, but i'll watch anything that moves).  my fave part about eating here is sitting by the window, which gives me a perfect view of ppl waiting for or disembarking from the muni stop.  ppl in cole valley wear really nice wool coats.
author: Zoe L.

description:
I went here with my boyfriend and two of our friends for a quick, inexpensive dinner.  That's what we got.  It was fine-- not great, but fine.  I can't remember which crepe I ordered... the one with cheddar, cottage cheese, marinara, and mushrooms.  I had them add spinach, which they did gladly.  My friend ordered the pancakes, which she had them make with blueberries and pecans.  They didn't seem to mind customizing our order at all.  We got a caprese as an appetizer, and what we got was a huge salad topped with slices of tomato and fresh mozzarella, with sliced crusty bread on the side.  Not what we were expecting, but ok.  

My crepe came with herbed homefries and a salad.  I wish the salad had been on a separate plate.  It got kind of warm and soggy, which is kinda not that appetizing. However, the portions were huge.  

I wouldn't take a crosstown bus to get there, but since it's around the corner from my boyfriend's house, I'll totally take it.  Plus, I think it's cool that they left the marquis from when it was The Other.  Neat.
author: L. M.

description:
Yesterday, I went to Crepes on Cole to have lunch. It's a restaurant located in Cole Valley near Haight Ashburry and just in front of the N-Judah stop.

The menu proposes crepes, sandwiches, omelets and salads. Some tables installed outside because the weather was wonderful. 

You have to order your menu inside the restaurant, and you pay when you order. The guy behind the register is nice and we didn't wait for a long time to have lunch.

We ordered an omelet and two crepes created by ourself because there is the possibility of choosing your ingredients in your crepe.
Everything was delicious and to have lunch in the sun is very pleasant. This place is not noisy even if the N-Judah is close.

This restaurant is not expensive, about ten dollars a meal.
I recommend this restaurant especially to eat outside.
author: Cloclo R.

description: Excellent Eggs Benedict: some of the best I've ever had. Hot, fresh and hits the spot.
author: Molly E.

description:
I've lived around this area before and this is the first time I've stepped into this creperie. I wonder if it's the same owner as "Crepevine" and "Squat and Gobble"?  

I realize I am not a savory crepe fan, esp the crepe is so heavy and not crispy.  I ordered the cole valley crepe with pesto, provolone, spinach, sun dried tomatoes and I thought it was okay. I liked the potato and light vingerette salad that came with this dish though.  $8.25 for the crepe.

$2.25 for a small fresh squeezed carrot juice.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Crepes on Cole is a nice place to eat, but unfortunately I didn't order a crepe that day as I wasn't quite feeling the crepe for dinner. What did I choose instead, an omelette-hah! So I ordered a regular cheddar cheese omelette with mushrooms and it was good, but not enough cheese for me. The potatoes were good though, and there was enough of that, along with the toast, to satisfy the appetite.

This place only takes cash, so make sure you aren't the type of person who never carries cash. It also took quite a while before the omelette was ready, which is surprising because an omelette shouldn't be too difficult to make. When you're ready to go, just look out the window and see if your N train is waiting (that's what I did, and it was great!)
author: Yosie G.

description:
This has always been one of my favorite breakfast spots in the Cole Valley/Haight area.  The crepes are always tasty, and as a bonus you get both potatoes AND salad.  You have to be patient on weekends, because it's always packed during breakfast/brunch time, but be patient...your table will come.

- 1 star for only accepting cash.  While that's usually OK, it can sometimes be an inconvenience. This place has been open long enough, and has enough business to start accepting credit cards.
author: Kathleen P.

description: I know I've already put a review up but I must say how much I love the owner. So they take cash only and of coarse I never have cash and he offered to an IOU!! He's all o o trust you to come back and all! I just wanted to give him a hug! But of coarse I didn't take him up on it because I'm just not someone who likes to be in debt but ya love that guy and the food and the coffee
author: stephanie c.

description:
food was okay.
blueberry pancakes were undercooked but good.
potatoes were good.... big portions. 

3 stars because they gave me a very small cup of syrup but the portions were large and it was quiet that saturday morning. ill be back to try other things.
author: David C.

description:
A lot of people swear by this place and I honestly think they're deluding themselves.

Whenever I've eat here I've been blown away by just how bland and average their food is.  I think people just want to like crepes b/c they're somehow special.. but I've had awesome crepes in Paris and decent crepes around the city (the place on haight st is pretty good) but crepes on cole crepes are just not there.  Their bagel sandwiches suck.. their home fries are basically boiled potatoes with a few herbs thrown on, I've even been disappointed by their salads.  I just stopped going, I'll even walk several blocks to get coffee b/c I don't want to give them my money.
author: Brett L.

description: This is one of the best crepe places in town.  You can make your own, which many of the others around town don't offer.  It is in a good location and you can walk to haight street or golden gate park after, or hop on the N and go downtown.
author: Jonathan U.

description: When I moved to the neighborhood a year ago I went to check this place out. I've been about half a dozen times. The owner was consistently rude and the food tasted a bit funny. Considering there are several nice breakfast/pancake spots nearby I can't see going here under the current management.
author: Aaron D.

description:
Good crepes.  Sluggish service.  Dull decor.  

The Florentine crepe hit the spot, and I was suprised how much I liked the cottage cheese in the mix.  The day's special, though, came out on top: a mix of lime, cheeses, avocado, and chicken that was really unique (in a good way).

Alas, time dragged on for fifteen+ minutes until our order arrived, which is slow as far as creperies are concerned.  And the Mels Diner interior didn't really provide an interesting distraction to pass the time.
author: MScott S.

description:
I feel bad giving this place two stars, because the guy who must be the owner seems so nice, but, c'mon, guys, you can do better.  Go visit a few other places, taste their food, see how it's done.  A few specific gripes:

- No salt in the salad dressing.  I can't believe that this omission comes from a concern for public health, based on the rest of the menu. Management: Please see recipe for "Basic Vinaigrette", any cookbook, anywhere.

- Home fried potatoes. Props for at least not using frozen shreds, but I am not sure what they are trying to accomplish with these. Crispy browned edges or mealy, soft chunks? I think it is the former, but each sad mound of greyness is typically the latter.  They clearly don't realize that the whole POINT of home-friend potatoes is the satisfying crunch of nicely browned crust against the creamy interior.  I would actually rather have the Pork Store's processed shreds (at least they are well-fried) than these.

- Bagels: Skip it.  Go across the street to Reverie and get a bagel there instead. From the taste of it, not even sure if theirs have been boiled- taste more like rolls with holes. [UPDATE JUN 08: Since Reverie is closed this week for renovations, got my bagel here this morning, and what a lovely surprise to find that they have a new, and MUCH better, bagel supplier, hooray! This was a real bagel - chewy, not too big, just dense enough with the perfect crust. The bagel-lovers of the world thank you, CoC, for no longer perpetrating bagel slander.]

- Salad greens: The same anemic "mesclun" you see in low-end, trying-be-gourmet places everywhere.  Much better to get a nice fresh head of good old green leaf or romaine than the tasteless, limp, wan pile of dispirited fluff they serve with everything. [6/9/08 UPDATE again: the Greek salad is a good bet - lettuce is crunchy & fluffy, piled high, nice feta]

- The real test of a crepe is how it tastes when you have nothing but butter, sugar, and lemon juice on it.  (Of course, it's all about the batter, and the flour it's made with.) Theirs: Underwhelming. If you are going to name your place after a dish, at least get the most basic thing right.

- Finally, not a food thing, but I thought worth mentioning - Styrofoam takeout containers. SF being SF, even the street vendors will probably soon be serving up food in waxed cardboard instead of styrofoam.  For a place trying to be moderately upscale (it is a creperie, after all), you'd think they'd be willing to make the switch. [These are no more as well, of course, and CoC uses the waxed paper that everybody had to switch to. Thank you, SF, for banning them!]

All that said, it is a casual and convivial place for people-watching, reading the Sunday paper, etc., and the atmosphere is neighborly.

[I upgraded them from two to three stars based on the improvements I noticed today....and, you know, neighborly counts for a lot. - Jun 8 08]
author: Mary B.

description:
The crepes here are great. You really can't go wrong with the selection, and if you do, it's your fault since you can build your own and substitute/ modify. 

The only negative is that they only take cash, as many places in SF do. I seem to forget this every time I go there and I end up having to run across the street to the laundry mat to withdraw from their ATM, which ends up costing me an extra $2 or something.
author: Lorry T.

description:
I love this place!  

Let me put it in math terms:  awesome location + great hours + spacious dining area + friendly staff + good music + bottomless cup of coffee + free wireless + a good amount of power outlets = a happy Rick.  Most cafés in the area close at 8:30, so it's nice to have a place open late.  

I know, I know, it's a crepe place.  I admit, I haven't yet had (the money to try) their crepes yet.  I'll post an update when I have the desire and/or funds to do so, but for now this place is just fine for me.  

It sucks having to be a bridge and tunnel patron here, though.  I'm determined to move to Cole Valley after college, if for no other reason than this place right hurr.
author: Rick B.

description:
So i'm new to SF and this is one of the first places i've checked out since being in my new hood. My hood is Cole Valley btw.

This place is good.  The servers are very nice..well...the counter people that is and the food is pretty tasty.  I tried the Pancakes with Bananas and Coconut and it was damn good.  

I go here a lot to just use the free internet and I enjoy the atmosphere as well.  Chill place, good food, nice people so I give it the thumbs up.
author: Noah b.

description: Crepes on Cole is great for a filling delicous breakfast before a morning of browsing throughout haight street! It is your typical crepe restaurant, where there are both meal crepes and dessert crepes! My two favorites are strawberries and chocolate with corn flakes or nutella and strwberries and of course they come with whip cream! there is alot of seating here both inside and outside! The potatoes are also fantastic (they come with egg crepes and such)!
author: Noelle L.

description:
My usual: Greek with no onions and a coffee.  If you save enough room, the apple and cheddar cheese dessert crepe is wonderful too!

Granted, I haven't had a lot of Crepe in my life (until I moved here) but it's great enough that I try to make my way here about once a week.  Sam the owner is great.  He always tries to recognize/remember his regulars and he often offers us a dessert Crepe on the house.  The menu is HUGE and the place is always open which is definitely convenient.  Also, there are basically limitless refills on the coffee (at least for me and my roommate).  Every time I have company in town, I go because it's one place in the city that makes me feel more like I'm at home.
author: Emily M.

description: Friendly but pretty average food albeit in generous proportions.  Good deal on beer but not really worth it with so many other good alternatives.  Often has an off putting odor.
author: Scott D.

description:
Affordable. 

Crowded on weekend mornings/midday times but worth it.

If you want to sit/linger longer, go on a weekday evening and get a salad and a glass of wine.

Favorite:  BASIL CREPE AND A DIET 7 UP.

Bathrooms are kind of ick.  Go before you head over there.
author: Megan G.

description:
Slightly better than Average food. The advantages are quick service, decent prices, and big portions. I survived art school eating here...so I shouldn't be too hard. The food is mostly ok...and a great bang for the buck. The quality slips hard on crowded days...but that is the best people watching time...so it is up to you to make the call about what's more important.

OF NOTE: I ate brunch next to Tom Waits here a few weeks ago.
author: Michael H.

description:
I really enjoyed this creperie, jambon y frommage; damn. Carrot juice, yum, i am now looking for a "put in kitchen at home" juicer, haha.

Only thing was that I am a little afraid to try their dessert crepe. Someday i'll see whats up.
author: Douglas C.

description:
If I ever leave SF this will be the place to hold most of my breakfast memories. I did spent many afternoons there also, but 8 am mimosas...whether they are followed a horrible night shift, or a good one,  there is just nothing like it. And Sunday branches, and late night coffee with 
chocolate/strawberry crepe.
I've been coming to this establishment for over 10 years! And for the last 5 it's been providing fresh, healthy dinners to the entire department of St.Mary's ER. 
Their salads are the freshest of the freshest and did I mention that they have the best fresh squeezed OJ you'll ever try.
Owned by the same lovely family for over a decade!
author: Mila Y.

description:
came here on a weekend since zazie had a long wait... should have expected that. i didn't know what to expect here but once i saw the menu, i knew this place was like crepevine but they had certain items crepevine didn't have.  it was a beautiful sunny day and the place was 3/4 full.  we quickly ordered our crepes and a order of pancake and found a table.  the food came out fairly quick and it was good.  it was pretty much like crepevine, nothing special.  my favorite here is the fresh carrot juice =)

this is definitely a cute place hidden in this neighborhood.  if u want some place different for a change, come here! (there are outdoor seating too - it's PERFECT for a sunny day!)
author: Kapo T.

description: Easy, fast and delicious food.  I've only been for brunch, but love all the great menu options, fast service and the fact that it's big enough to always have a table open.  Great options if you are watching what you eat - egg white omelette is fantastic, as they give you a million options to put in them.
author: Betsy C.

description:
loved that place before

 BUT got very disappointed - was Very bad last night : over- OVER- salted salmon and burned crapes
author: Lena M.

description:
I'm only going to give these guys 2 stars, even though I go here quite a bit.

The fact is, the food here pretty mediocre.  A few of the crepe dish are good, but don't venture too much out of the basics, they don't do creative food very well.  The coffees are ok, but my capuccinos here often come with runnier foam than I normally like.  The salads are, however, super yummy.  Also, the portions are huge, so my husband and I can be cheap and share a meal here.  The casual dinning atmosphere lends itself to this kind of eating as well.

The service is decent in light of the fact that you have to order at the counter yourself.  They do bring it out to you.

Crepes on Cole is mostly good because they have a large dinning room for this neighborhood, so there's always a place to sit and people watch out the windows.  The other eateries on the block are very small, and crowd easily (better food as well), so if i'm up for a leisurely cup of coffee and a book, then I'll go here.
author: Tatiana R.

description:
Being from Ohio where crepe locales are not prevalent, I LOVE this place when my friends I visit take me here. 

Many choices, cute cafe atmosphere, and delicious food. Large portions make it even better!

I always look forward to visiting this place when I'm in town! Basil Crepe is my fav!
author: Jen T.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to have breakfast. The only thing that sucks is that you have to get lucky to get a table outside because weekend mornings are dog parade time and everyone with a dog is sitting out there. I hate sitting inside in the morning bc it is hot inside and you end up smelling like the place when you leave. 
The eggs benedict is bomb, a real fave of mine, but with regular bacon, not canadian. Its only given me the dia twice and i've been there a billion times and only get that. Once I had a strawberry crepe, and it was good but i'm not really into crepes, so yeah. the ex liked the pesto crepe sandwich and pancakes. I like the tea, its like interesting. Theres some vicious pigeons outside that i throw my fruit at to get them away but ends up encouraging them.
author: Lacey P.

description:
Good enough for Breakfast!

An occasional stop for breakfast, they have a great selection of savory crepes and omelettes and other things for breakfast.  If you're like me and wake up hungry but can't figure out what sounds good you should be able to find something here.  They also have a good selection of traditional sweet crepes if thats what you're looking for.  Specials change regularly as well.  The coffee kind of sucks though!

The counter service is efficient and usually quite friendly.  The inside is basic and hasn't changed much in years.  It could use a little sprucing up.
author: Steve D.

description:
The food here is pretty good, but so overpriced. What's with the kiwi, melon, undressed greens, and other random fruit that comes with every order. It's not enough to justify the high priced omelets.  

Since I lived across the street, I was often tempted by the available seating and quick service, but I could never manage getting out of this place without dropping more than I wanted. 

I do like the owner. He is a Cole Valley institution. I seem to always see him walking around the neighborhood.
author: Leo H.

description: Very delicious dishes with great coffee and incredibly friendly service. What more could you ask for? (:
author: Chung N.

description: I don't recommend this place.  Why?  Because I got food poisoning!!   I got really sick.  I ordered the Florentine crepe with mushrooms...thought that was safe and healthy, but I guess not!   Maybe the cook didn't wash his hands.  I hate to think what made me sick.  The workers behind the counters were not friendly either, especially the dark haired woman...she was a bit rude to us (I forgot to get her name).  We felt like we were bothering them...guess they don't care about getting business or not.  They also don't take debit cards or any cards at all; you have to pay by cash only!   Who carries cash these days??   Especially if you have a large group...are we supposed to carry $100 bills around?   So, don't eat here unless you want to risk getting sick!
author: K. P.

description: They are friendly, and the crepes are good. I remember paying too much for an extra bacon, though, so be careful if you want a custom crepe. A good spot, in all.
author: Emmanuelle P.

description:
crepes on cole is a solid neighborhood spot...great for studying (they're open until 1030), a cup of coffee, bagels....however, i think they're crepes are nasty.  there i said it. and i feel better.

its run by two brothers - one is super nice and the other is a total jerk.

anyways, i'm just about in love with their sesame bagels, scooped, toasted, with plain cream cheese and pesto...yummmyyyyy
author: Brooke M.

description:
To be simple for once.

French toast with fresh fruit?  

Delicious.

...
weird tasting orange juice
author: Brian H.

description:
I've worked in many places in the city, including this one.
That was years ago though, so things might have changed.

Basically, it's one of those places that's a cool hangout, but that lacks discipline on hygiene guidelines.

Cole Valley's grungy spot!
author: xavier v.

description:
I've only been here once and their service left a little to be desired. Their build-your-own crepe had a base which I think was cheese and onions or something like that, then it was $0.75 to add other ingredients. So I go to add chicken and they charge me $1.50. After they told me the total, I asked them why it was so expensive ($8 for a crepe?), and they said "Because it's chicken so it's more." Now on the board there's 30-something ingredients listed as $0.75 and when I asked to add chicken I wasn't told it was more expensive. But I was hungry and didn't want to argue. When I got the crepe it was pretty decent and the potatoes were good. Definitely not outstanding, but not bad either. 

My main complaint: If you're going to charge meat as a double topping, you should have it up on the menu or at least say it's an additional cost when you charge the customer rather then just ringing it up and leaving me to wonder why my crepe just ballooned up in cost by 15%.
author: Bryan Z.

description:
First of all I have to admit that crapes are not my favorite thing. I have had some good ones but unfortunately not at Crapes on Cole. They seem to always forget to put enough spices on there, making the different Crapes kind of always taste the same, which is not much. However, there are always people there so perhaps it is just me.

As far as the service goes though, there is absolutely nothing to complain about. Friendly people all over and they will bring out your food with a smile on their face. The place itself seems to be very well kept and you actually can see straight into the kitchen, which I always find like a good sign - they have nothing to hide.

So, if you are into crapes then give this place a go but I think I have been there enough. There are better places around in the neighborhood.
author: Jonas B.

description:
Never been a fan of salty crepes, but this place was decent. Came here for lunch and didn't know what to order. I ordered some crepe with spinach and cheese and it tasted good.  I liked that they served salad with it, but I wish they gave me more salad than potatoes. 

Overall, not a bad place.
author: A L.

description:
Both the savory and dessert crepes are well-priced and pretty damn tasty.  I wish they wouldn't lather cheddar on so many of the savory crepes, but the problem is easily solved by either asking for a substitution or ordering a custom one.  The included side salad and potatoes are a nice touch, and their fresh-squeezed OJ and carrot juices are top notch.

I haven't had their coffee or lunch fare, so I can't attest to their quality.

My biggest complaint with this place is that they're cash only.  Bloody irritating when all you've got in your wallet is a bank card and sixty-five receipts.  Also, when they say they open at 7, it means that the owner is there at 7 ... not the grill guy.  He's almost always late.
author: Susuk L.

description:
Crepes on Cole has become one of my must-eats during my visits to SF!
I'm not much of a crepe person, and have had the same meal during each of my visits, but it has been consistently excellent!

We recently came to Crepes on Cole on a beautiful Sunday and took advantage of the outdoor seating. Their beverage menu includes a delicious orange juice and a solid coffee, which we purchased. 

For breakfast I always get their french toast and my boyfriend gets the banana pancakes without the coconut. The french toast is scrumptious, covered in fruit. The banana pancakes are full of flavor and are extremely filling (in a good way). It would be nice if there was a little more fruit garnishing the banana pancake plate (there were only two strawberries).

All in all, Crepes on Cole is a great-eat. It's a little pricey, but a wonderful treat for every once in a while!
author: Danielle T.

description: Place so clean and simple. No wait. So many things on menu to choose from. Got a fruit bowl, carrot juice, basil crepe, and strawberry/banana french toast. Such a lovely brunch! Oh, and I'm not sure why every other review says cash only... they take the major 4 cc's.
author: Daniel R.

description: My crepe came with a big bug sitting in the middle of it. Will never ever go here again.
author: Amy G.

description:
I used to live in the hood and avoid coming here.  Somehow there would always be a reason....usually that Zazie was packed and I wanted breakfast food.  Way overpriced and just not good.  The food is consistently blah.  I mean really blah.  
The people are super nice though, there is always a place to sit and it's usually very quiet and mellow.  But make the food yummy!  It's such a great spot!
I notice that this is true of all of these crepe places though, like the new one on Valencia.  Same blah-ness.  A waste of money.
author: J E.

description:
amazing food, always a great place to go. Its a laid back place. The prices are a little high but the food is worth it. I usually get the chicken sandwich... it comes with awesome potatoes and salad. Yum... i want some now that i'm writing about it. I think i'll go over there and get some now... 
 Parking is a b*tch around there though... lines can get kind of annoying on sundays and they dont take credit cards. There is an ATM across the street but.. this place would get 5 stars if only they took credit.
author: Triana L.

description:
I frequented this place toooo much when first moving here, now I keep it to a guilty pleasure minumum. While the 1/2&1/2 combo is a good deal for a healthy meal, I can't help ordering the slightly pricey for too small a crepe dish- strawberries/whip cream....SO good.

Additionally this place makes you feel comfortable to stay even after you finish eating...bring a book or laptop and get some work done..they are open pretty late for that sort of thing, which is great. Nice owner too. 5 stars for service, menu options, tasty menu items, location, hours...beware of CASH ONLY:-/ kind of annoying..still 5stars
author: s m.

description: Eating here right now. Great variety. Also, the best French toast I have ever had!
author: Teri R.

description: Great crepes, so-so sandwiches. This place is perfect if you want to grab a quick casual lunch.  Outdoor seating, although limited, is a perk especially on those rare sunny days in the city. I've come here quite a few times now- usually with friends or family. I prefer to make my own crepe (feel free to steal it :) cheddar, spinach, pesto, and avocado. The crepes come with a lovely mixed greens salad and rosemary potatoes. On the downside, staff is not overly friendly and no waiter service. Hard decision between 3 and 4 stars- I know it's not too fair to go for the lower end based on their sandwiches, since, hey, this is a crepe place, but they are pretty mediocre.
author: Robin L.

description:
Best pancakes in SF! Best bacon and eggs! Best sandwiches! And the fresh orange juice is actually 100 % fresh (as opposed to all these places out there that mix fresh with concentrate). The omelettes are delicious and they are happy to make them (and anything) else the way you want them.

The service is good and the owners are seriously nice!

Someone complained about prices in their review. I don't get that. The prices are better than the other places in the same area and since you don't order table side you don't have to leave a steep tip. And best of all - the portions are nice and big so you can share if you want or just take the leftovers with you.

Love this place!
author: Anna D.

description: I had the golden rasin and pecan pancakes today and boy were they goooooood!~ A bit pricy for pancakes (close to $8), but good for a treat every now and then. My green tea came in a pot which was a refreshing change to those little dinky bags I usually get. I was seriously eyeing the savory crepes section. I've never had them savory style before, but I expect to be back again to try them out. The lady working there was also very nice and the atmosphere was casual, comfy and warm (which was a plus since it was storming outside).
author: G C.

description: Savory crepes (the pesto chicken is a favorite) are served with house potatoes that are sometimes tasty, sometimes greasy, and often bland, so request extra salad instead. Other menu items include French toast, a fresh fruit bowl, sandwiches, and - of course - dessert crepes. Outdoor seating might contribute to making everything seem it's slightly better than it really. Weekend brunch is usually packed, so get here early or expect to wait.
author: Gourmet G.

description: if u are hungry and want a delicious meal that fells u up and makes u happy ... your best choice is Crepes on Cole ... I love that place and all the delicious meals they make!!
author: Yousef H.

description:
So, I'm sitting here inside the restruant thinking, hmm.. I really should review this place. So, here goes.

The breakfasts are just ok, I had the Half Moon Bay, eggs with smoked salmon, goat cheese and spinach.. It's just ok.. The eggs were a little runny, and the salmon wasn't evenly distributed throughout the mound. The potatoes were pretty good though. 

The wife had the salsa crepe which actually looked decent. She commented that a savory crepe should probably have the crepe part be somewhat savory as well.. Not the sweet crepe for deserts. 

I think the biggest problem, which is why I'm only giving them 2 stars is that the service was horrible. The women behind the counter obviously don't want to work here and treat their customers like annoyances more than paying people who keep their paychecks coming in.  Not that people should be overly gracious at a cheap crepe joint, but there should be some sort of customer/employee respect here that they just lack. Makes me think that if we were in LA they were only here till they get their acing break.

On the upside, they have internet and don't seem to mind people using their laptops. 

Another plus is that their espresso is all illy.. too bad their drip isn't.
author: Mark C.

description: I hate to give a bad review, but this place was SO mediocre for breakfast. The smoked salmon was even bland. I would suggest CrepeVine if you are in the mood for something a bit more delectable.
author: Tam C.

description: Really great location and very cool atmosphere.  Okay, there are your two points.  As for the rest, honestly I think you can skip this joint.  We went there Friday evening.  It was not crowded at all but it took forever to get our crepe.  And as for the crepe.  Bland, tasteless and uninspiring.  Maybe this place would be better for breakfast, but in my opinion, probably not.
author: Sean O.

description: The Cole Valley crepe is delicious! I just moved to the area and love that there's a crepe place right here/there! Just when you didn't think things could get better...you stumble upon a neighborhood crepe joint. YUMMY!
author: Cat T.

description: Killer lemon and sugar crepes. *MY FAV!! and it's actually better when it cools down cause then the sugar carmelizes!! Hardly ever a line, and you can get seating here right away. Have yet to try a savory crepe from here though....
author: Marina K.

description: I recently enjoyed a short 4 day trip to San Francisco. Crepes on Cole was convenient and the food was tasty I ordered the chicken pesto crep for brunch -prretty good entre. I wish I went by the place later in the day or evening so I would be up for trying one of the dessert crepes - those looked awesome from what I could see on adjacent tables. Alsmost forgot, this location is awesome for people watching....
author: David G.

description: My book club just celebrated its 2-year anniversary. I believe our success is due to the fact that we don't make people host and cook for everyone (ok, we sometimes do that, but my one attempt involved a fireball shooting out of my ancient Wedgewood stove) -- we always hold meetings at one of the supposedly non-affiliated but strangely similar crepe places throughout the city. Everyone can order separately and you can chill at a table and be literary for as long as you'd like.  This is my favorite one, as it's in my neighborhood.  And you can have breakfast for dinner, which is always fun -- I recommend the pecan and golden raisin pancakes.
author: Laurel N.

description: I am a huge crepe fan but this place turned out to be quite a disappointment.  The banana crepe was bland and unmemorable.  The side of house potato was flavorless.  The soup my friend had was as thick as gravy.  We were not at all impressed.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
My favorite casual breakfast place in San Francisco -- I'm obsessed. Good for lunch, too. Great omelettes, crepes, sandwiches, etc. Extremely friendly owners. Lovely vibe. I highly recommend this place! 

Try the "make-your-own" omelette option -- lots of fresh, quality ingredient choices.
author: Heidi B.

description:
A little overpriced for what it is, and service a little slow for what you pay for.  Food is average, location is convenient, with plenty of street parking close by.  Interior is warm, large and inviting.

It served a great second choice since Zazie's down the street had a lineup :-)
author: That's For N.

description: I had the most perfect Sunday and it had a lot to do with this place.  Its very casual, you order and sit down and wait for your food, but the crepe that I had was the best.  Its called a bon jour and it involves goat cheese, chicken apple sausage, eggs, onions and mushrooms, and let me just tell you that its heaven.  They have several variations of sweet and savory crepes as well as salads, soups and sandwiches.  Its entirely glass windows so on a beautiful day it was perfection.  My friend did order the bleu salade and she said there was a lot of lettuce and not a lot of dressing just as a side note.  But I will definitely come back here whenever I am in the neighborhood.
author: Lindsay P.

description: I've been going to this place for years and yes they have decent Crepes (crepe place on haight and ashbury is better), but their salads are always pretty disappointing. Today, I dealt with their poor customer service. I called for a take out order: 2 Chicken Caesar salads with dressing on the side. My father picked up the salads and the cashier said, "dressing is in the bag." Because she said that, he did not second guess her. He gets home and the bags are missing dressing. I call back informing them of the mistake. I ask them to refund us or if they could deliver the dressing. She asked where we lived and would call her boss. She calls me back 15mins later and says she cannot deliver the dressing but we could come down to pick up the dressing. At this moment, our chicken on our salads are getting cold. However, they would not refund us for our time, gas, or effort going all the way back to their place. She did not even apologize for the inconvenience. She even said, "I put the dressing in myself!" Well that can't be true because where did it go? Are we magicians? She did not take any responsibility. Now, of course my father could have looked in the bag before he left the restaurant, but Crepes on Cole handled it incorrectly. Their customer service was poor. They just needed to handle it a bit better. They couldve thrown in a dessert or 10% off for us coming back the the restaurant but they gave us nothing. Instead, they just blamed it on us. I will not be a returning customer.
author: Juliet C.

description: Don't miss the opportunity to make your own crepe! This place re-affirmed my faith in the quality of restaurants with a chalk-on-slate menu!
author: Arnab B.

description:
what more can i say??? with all these superior reviews about this place, i have nothing much more to imply that are different from the rest of the yelpers!

oh wait......

i have to state at least my very OWN EXPERIENCE....

i was dazzled by the spacious, warming atmosphere this place provided me the moment i went in!!
the egg whites omelette with spinach and mushrooms were nicely folded and fluffy..and it tasted really wonderful. the egg benedicts were also delicious on top of fresh, delightful spinach!
the homemade potatoes with fresh rosemary was also nicely done.

they use illy coffee which was really smooth and bold and you get a refill for free.

the staff was quick and really helpful.

however, i was just not quite happy how they charged you an additional 0.75 cents to each item you want on your omelette. i wish they have a fixed dish of omelette you can choose from.

in general, this place is a fantastic place to get your breakfast...and the savory crepes will be yet to be tasted on my next visit!
author: Nelle A.

description:
When I worked near here, it was definitely a neighborhood lunch favorite for our team.  The crepes are unique and the variety abundant.  I love their potatoes and the simple set-up of the place. 

Their menu is visually appealing and can have guests standing there for minutes on end simply trying to decide what to order (this isn't a bad thing).  I have yet to try their dessert crepes -- yum.
author: Christine T.

description: I think this place is depressing.  It's all nice and cute and French looking from the outside, but you walk into a world of dead brown.  The floor, walls, tables, bar ... all dark and unattractive.  For such a prominent location, I was surprised it didn't have a hint of posh.  The food was meh. My friend got a salad and it was full of canned sliced tasteless olives.  I got a crepe with cheddar and basil and it was pretty much tasteless. I prefer my crepes a little on the crispy side, but this one was just mush that had to be eaten with a fork.  The counter girl was pretty slow also. The food did come fast though.  Meh.  Save your money for EOS (Eos? eos?) across the street.
author: Cassandra W.

description: The crepes are really more like omelets, but I they're tasty nonetheless.  They always give you more than enough food to fill you up and I think the prices are reasonable.
author: Casey M.

description: All I have to say is: Mexican hot chocolate. Absolutely perfect. Cinnamon stick, and cinnamon powder on top in a giant mug...ohh it certainly does remind me of home-style hot chocolate. We sat outside to eat because it's rather crowded inside. I look back on this place with fondness.
author: Val E.

description:
This was the first place I ate at when I moved to San Francisco.  I remember ordering the Cole Valley Crepe and noting the large portion of food I was served--huge crepe stuffed to the max, nice handful of greens, and an overflowing pile of house potatoes.  The crepes may not be the most authentic; however, they sure are tasty!  I appreciate their creative fillings.

In addition, Crepes on Cole has one of the most personable owners in town.  He walks around to each table and chats up customers when he is not working the register, and you can usually find him in the restaurant from early in the morning to late in the evening, long after all other Cole Valley eateries have closed.

I would definitely recommend this place for a quick breakfast or morning latte if you're ever in the neighborhood!
author: B H.

description: I grew up in this neighborhood and can count on one hand the amount of times I've been here.  The crepes are HORRIBLE!  They are just plain nasty, I got better crepes from street vendors.  To their credit, their eggs are decent.  I would suggest Reverie for breakfast, brunch or lunch.  If you want crepes go someplace else, it's a big city.  Try TiCouz in the mission or if you see someone selling them on the street I suggest you try them before you come here.  Seriously, I don't know who writes these reviews but I don't think they have taste buds.  This place does not have even decent crepes.  Which is sad because they aren't difficult to make.  Once again, just go someplace else if you want a crepe that rates better than "I didn't gag".
author: Shani H.

description: I remember traveling from downtown after school just to get my mouth around one of their banana nutella crepes. Delicious! The other types of crepes are really good too, although it's very hard to take me away from the banana nutella. The ingredients are fresh, and the overall crepe, any style, is just amazing. The only downside is that they're a bit on the slow side, but it's well worth the wait. This is a good place to take some friends, wait around for awesome food, talk and catch up, and then devour!
author: Casey Z.

description: Was in the mood for a dessert-type of crepe (banana and chocolate) and it was alright. They have a wide selection of breakfast/lunch items and the place is quite spacious, a great place for studying. Price is okay...I'd prefer going somewhere else for a better tasting crepe.
author: Janel Y.

description:
If you are foodies, I don't think this place will satisfy you.

If you like hearty breakfast and are really hungry, this will be great!
They will give you a big plate!

Never go there for quality crepes.  Crepe dough(or whatever) are very bland and to compensate, they throw LOTS of stuff in it.  Some people love it, but I didn't.

People are nice and the casual atmosphere is very nice in the weekend afternoon.
author: mice o.

description: Nice crepes. But the woman who served us had the sadness of the world in her eyes.
author: Allison L.

description: This is really like every other crepe place in the city -- it's just OK.  I don't get the rave reviews from others.  And it's kinda pricey for crepes.
author: S J.

description: As a relatively new SF resident, I don't fully understand the abundance of crepe places. I LIKE it - I just don't understand it. My experience at Crepes on Cole was really average - the filling was a little too cheesy (read: greasy) and the accompanying potatoes and salad were nothing to write home about. I honestly think I'd rather go here for the other breakfast offerings - a nearby table had some pretty awesome looking pancakes.  Until then, I think there are a few neighboring creperies that I'd prefer to support.
author: Beth T.

description:
I've been going here on and off for almost 13 years; the crepes are California crepes (like what you would find at Crepevine), not French crepes (like what you would find at Ti Couz), but are consistently flavourful and i've never found the staff to be anything but friendly.

It's not the end-all-be-all to creperies, but the location v. staff friendliness v. people watching potential v. usually not super crowded v. flavour v. cost sits in a good spot within 6-space (which is the reason that i'll continue on into the 14th year).
author: eerie q.

description:
Agree w/ Lisa H - this place isn't that clean.  If I didn't have a munckin, I'd never enter this establishment - good thing for them that it's easy to get take-out.

As for the food, what can I say - it's not that good.  Crepes are so-so, potatoes are blah, and salads aren't very tasty.  

Decent coffee.
author: WP D.

description: I had a salmon crepe that was disgusting. The salmon and potatoes were waaay undercooked. I don't know that I would ever try this place again.
author: Kaitlyn M.

description: This place was totally mostly just kinda okay.  The crepes were good enough.  The bites of mine with goat cheese were quite good, othewise it was a little boring.  The vinaigrette that they use on the greens was tasty.  Odd that it's a cash only place I thought.
author: Jason M.

description:
living in LA, i always feel a little sad when i eat here - will somebody in LA please tell me of a place that at least comes close to Crepes on Cole for it's crepe-ity goodness?!

example #1 - the cole valley crepe, with spinach, cheese, onions, pesto, and 2 other ingredients i've forgotten. the crepe is chock-full of tastiness, so thick, that it doesn't look like a crepe anymore - more like a sandwich with some damn tasty bread.

example #2 - potatoes. other crepe places serve potatoes with their crepes, but CoC's are the best. just the right amount of rosemary, and just crispy enough on the outside, while just barely firm enough on the inside. not too hard and undercooked, but not too squishy and gross. right in between at the epicenter of perfection.

example #3 - juicer - granted, it would be cool if they had other ingredients to choose from, but this is NOT a juice bar. and, in SF, you'll find one in 5 minutes. however, the juice they do make - fresh carrot/orange juice - is the perfect compliment to the crepe dish before you.

example #4 - vegan cookies! my favorite cookie (and i'm not even vegetarian) is the epsresso chip, from the Alternative Baking Company. CoC sells that, plus many of the other varieties from this cookie company...

and, it's set back far enough from the haight that you feel like you've found a sorta quiet oasis in the city. always on my check-off list of "places to go" when i visit in SF. now, will somebody hook me up with a place at least half this good in LA?
author: scourge k.

description: Not bad. I usually get the special of the day, which is a good sized crepe loaded with this and that and comes with a salad and potatoes. Prices are a bit steep in my opinion, but it's SF, it's understandable. Lots of sitting room and outside seating as well. It's not bad but not worth going out of your way for. A typical crepe place to say the least.
author: Jasmine O.

description:
overpriced and not that good but somehow i went here all the time when i lived in san francisco. explain me to me.

they have great water though. 

i forget if they're patient or impatient when you are ordering, but they're definitely notable in one direction or the other.
author: elise d.

description: "Had the Bon Jour Crepe; goat cheese, chicken apple sausage, mushrooms, bell peppers, onions. Pretty good; slow service though. Great little neighborhood"
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Went here last night around 10:30pm for some last minute dinner on our way back home. From what I heard, this place has been around for a long time, and it had that well seasoned look to it that made me feel like I was in for something good. Ordering was simple and we got our choice of seating since not many people were out eating after 10:30pm.  The walls were decorated with gorgeous paintings of trees and landscapes with amazing color and some jazz was playing softly in the background.  It was a real comfortable setting.  We shared the special, which was loaded with mushrooms, havarti, chicken, spinach and tomatoes.  It also came with some of the best potatoes and a heap of salad greens.  Overall, this was a great last minute meal.  Next time I'll have to try the fruity crepes for breakfast or dinner.
author: Rachel R.

description: This place is pretty disgusting... the crepes are overloaded with bad cheese and flavorless meat. I've tried to give it a chance a few times. They take way too long and they they almost always get my order wrong (which is infuriating when you do take out and they charge you extra for stuff you never got).  I will never eat here again.
author: Juan J.

description: Ok, I'm guilty of not ordering the crepes, because I thought the omelet would be a better cure for the common hangover.  While the omelet was pretty tasty I didn't think it exceeded the expectation for the fare (~$9). It was definitely filling though. So usually this might warrant a 3 rating but I definitely enjoyed the atmosphere. Find the perfect sunny saturday or sunday to have brunch here on their smaller tables outside. You'll thank me for it later.
author: Tom B.

description: Food was great but the peeps who worked there were a lil sketchy, my friend & I ate there two mornings in a row (we stayed @ friends around the corner) She liked what I had & I liked what she ordered, so we switched the next day. Somehow, it was $3 more the next day, weird right?
author: James G.

description: oh crepes...my old faithful.  We used to literally eat here 1 time per week but cut back on eating out.  The french toast is OUTTA control! so freakin good.  It is made w/ challah bread, cinnamon, OJ and topped with bananas and strawberried.  They also have tons of crepe (duh) and you can make your own. so if i feel like being healthy i will get egg whites and veggies.  They all come with mixed green salad and home fries.  The owners are really nice too.  And it used to be a comedy club back in the day and Robin Williams got his start there!
author: Natasha L.

description: Banana coconut pancakes were fabulous! REAL coconut, thickly cut. Not sweet at all, which was nice for a change. Apple turkey sausage not so exciting at all. Roasted potatoes and side salad are a nice touch with the crepes. Makes for a filling meal.
author: Stefanie E.

description: Wow, I am surprised by the recent low star reviews ---- because this place is AMAZING!!!! I have seriously eaten there 4 times in the last 2 weeks. I had always passed by it on the NJudah but just thought it was another Crepevine or BeanBag.....DO NOT BE FOOLED...the food here rivals any other crepe or pancake place in the city by far. I love the pesto crepe and their pancakes....what can I say....I bring out of town friends & family here all the time and they flip their shit when they eat here. The potatoes are no Boogaloos....they actually are pretty tasteless, so skip the carbs and get more salad. Their banana chocolate dessert crepe is excellent. They are open until 10pm on weeknights which is so nice for when you are craving pancakes for dinner.
author: K B.

description:
o.k. here's the deal. they put carrot shavings on their caesar salad. yes carrot shavings. can they legally call it caesar after this addition? you be the judge. i personally could care less. i get mine with the chicken. it's filling and downright tasty. 

never had the crepes, not interested.

the sandwiches ain't anything gourmet, but they hit the spot. they come with a small side salad and roasted potatoes so you won't leave hungry.

the constantly changing art on the walls makes me want to stab my eyes out so i get my food to go.
author: Ricky J.

description:
man at counter; nice.
waitresses; cold as ice.

i had the portabella omelette with spinach & gouda.
my bf had the sausage, egg, green bell peppers, & cheese crepe.
both really were tasty.
potatoes are okay...i am a fatty so i like greasy crispiness....god forbid potatoes taste like potatoes...ha ha ha...but they eventually grew on me.
oooh we had mimosas...sloshed by two! i am classy; what can i say.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
The french toast so tasty you don't even need syrup!   Yum!

Bring cash - because they don't take credit cards.
author: Khloe M.

description: Some things are pretty good, but other things are really not.  I've enjoyed brunch here, but left most of my lunch uneaten on the plate.  If you want brunch in Cole Valley and don't want to wait for Zazie, this is an option along with Bambino's, but Bambino's is better.  Crepes on Cole is a distant third.
author: Laura B.

description: Good crepes and other breakfast fixin's, a nice place to hang out for a coffee, close to the park.
author: Vadim A.

description: This is a good place if you have a hankering for crepes. Not the greatest place but definitely a great value and they have a great variety. I ordered the chicken pesto crepe and it was tasty, but dry. I do have to say, though, that their beer on tap is $2.50!! Definitely will go back, even if simply for that. And the dessert crepes were definitely a highlight.
author: Rachel F.

description: Buttermilk pancakes were good, coffee was the perfect temperature and the atmosphere is nice.  I will go back.
author: Joann P.

description: We were just here NY eve for some delish breakfast..i love that they have outdoor sitting so we can bring stew and lily, i love their crepes and omelets thats what we always get from here...the only downside in this area is that its hard to find street parking and it gets a lil crowded..overall this place is awesome..service is great!
author: Jo Z.

description: Near impossible to find a seat on Sat/Sun mornings but the crepes are worth it.  Order fast, be a harpy to get a seat, eat and then get out before someone stands behind you indicating they want your table.  American portions (=big) and good orange juice that can ease that tinge of a hangover.
author: Allison K.

description:
i like this place.  the ambiance is laid-back and casual.  it makes for a very good breakfast experience and i feel like i've woken up on the right side of the bed after eating here!

i've only ordered the bon jour crepe and the pesto chicken crepe.  a little inconsistent, but not enough to stop going and trying out their other tasty bites!
author: cindy c.

description: Have to agree with Sarah.  Totally medicore.  If you like flavorless eggs and fried potatoes that don't taste like anything, then this is your place.  Boring and tasteless.  I don't see the point.  Go up the street to Zazies and endure the wait.  At least they serve flavor!
author: Brent F.

description: It always surprises me to come across a restaurant that doesn't accept credit cards. I rarely carry cash, but fortunately had some on me the morning I came. The chalkboard menu is cute, but there were almost too many items to choose from. I placed my order...and then waited. And waited. And waited some more. I don't think I waited as long as the man sitting next to me, who was clearly irritated at the slow service on what I could only imagine was a typical Sunday morning for a *crepe restaurant.* The food was good, and maybe if I'd ordered a crepe I'd have raved a little more, but it really wasn't all that exceptional.
author: Jessica R.

description:
it was a pretty good breakfast crepe.... but not the greatest i've had.  maybe i should try one of their sweet ones.
i remember the portions were pretty big so you won't  leave hungry
author: charlotte s.

description: Great place to study and the food's about like at squat and gobble.  I like the chicken pesto sandwhich, blueberry pankcakes, and blintzes - but not all at once.  So the dessert... no so much, and it's cash only.  You could get a crepe which are good but steer clear of the vegan cookies unless you're used to them.
